review_text:
This is a comment just to say how much I'm looking forward to this book! My plan is to listen to the audiobook with hopes that Matthew McConaughey narrates it himself so I can get wrapped up in that warm, friendly, country-boy voice of his as if he is talking directly to me.

I will update this review after October 20, 2020.
Edit Oct 20: Reading now... review coming.

Alright alright alright...5 easy breezy stars. It felt like I sat around with him over a glass of scotch and he told me stories of his life. He‚Äôs witty, funny, smooth, and worked his literary skills through my heart. I laughed out loud, I paused to write down deep truths that resonated with me, and I face palmed at some of his antics. Do yourself a favor and listen to the Audible, he narrates! Oh yes!!!

His life has been interesting, to say the least. I love his passion to constantly be

It‚Äôs a love letter. To life.

Indeed it is. McConaughey is a guy who really pursued his dreams. (view spoiler)

What I most liked about his writing is that it's not polished: his thoughts, adventures, stories, all are raw, spiced more often than not with humor and self-irony. He is charming, funny, thoughtfu

5 Stars to this book. I loved hearing Matthew read his own book. He added his signature voice, animation, and laughs and made this book absolutely perfect. Its a memoir and personal reflection and humor and even a bit philosophical. I looked forward to listening. He owned his mistakes (and laughed at himself at times) and was not negative, he was always looking for ways to grow and improve himself. I have nothing but respect for him and this will be one of my Top 5 books of 2020. I Highly Recomm

Absolutely amazing. Not your typical biography. Filled with nuggets of insight. Profound letters, prose, and poetry. McConaughey shows not only his life and the ‚Äúgreenlight‚Äù moments, he dives deep into himself with his most vulnerable essence. A joy to read.

Alright, alright, alright.

I'm not gonna lie, I really enjoyed this one. I didn't expect to, I was skeptical to say the least, but I ended up loving the heck out of the audiobook narrated by Matthew himself.

This one is quite a treat. Full of insightful little thoughts and proclamations, quirky stories (that are almost unbelievable, tho completely and amazingly believable because they did happen), anecdotes, humor.. It was just so pleasant a book to listen to. A great insight into Matthew's past,

I'm only half way through the audiobook but had to pause and write a review. I will finish it by this evening but have already heard enough to say this is the best autobiography I have ever listened to. McConaughey narrates his book and the performance is outstanding to say the least.

I was on the fence at first about even giving it a listen, thinking it probably won't be my cup of tea. The first 10 minutes or so, I was beginning to think just that. Then it all changed and I was hooked. It's ver
This is more a summary of a journal than a book, but its as interesting as our cultural icons get, and being native son of my part of the world there is plenty I can relate to.

A rambling book with great stories but flawed execution. McConaughey was a C student in college, claiming he was normally an A student but wanted to devote time to real world instead of books, and at the end of this books says he'd rather "take an experienced C over an ignorant A any day." Well, this book is a C at best and could have been an A if he would have been less self-satisfied and allowed others to guide him to objective conclusions. Instead it's all about subjective Matthew living his

Alright, Alright, Alright! Greenlights by Matthew McConaughey....what can I say?

This book was fun, it was entertaining, it was interesting. It made me laugh so much and it broke my heart. Matthew has been one of my favourite actors since A Time To Kill. I loved hearing his behind the scenes stories about making his movies.

But it is so much more than that. Matthew really is a born storyteller. Greenlights covers his life from being a kid right up to the COVID-19 pandemic. It is stories from his

user_name: Kim ~ It‚Äôs All About the Thrill
review_text: Ahhhhhh...I am totally listening to Matthew McConaughey! ‚ù§Ô∏è Holy crap!

Oh lord, was this annoying. I love a good celebrity memoir, but not when riddled with self-help tidbits. If McConaughey had stuck to personal essays without all the cheesy, self-satisfactory interjections (‚Äúprescription!‚Äù and ‚Äúnote to self!‚Äù and ‚Äúbumper sticker!‚Äù), I‚Äôd have liked it more, even though the stories themselves felt very anecdotal and lacked depth. Unless you‚Äôre a massive fan, I can‚Äôt recommend.

Another narcissistic actor who loves to hear himself talk! This book was very preachy and about as deep as a paper cut! What have I learned about Matthew? I've learned that I never want to be stuck in a room with him!
This book needs to be consumed in audiobook form. With the stories and the accents

YOU CANNOT MISS THE AUDIBLE VERSION OF THIS BOOK!
read by the man himself

On the one hand, I read this book in less than two days over the course of a rainy weekend.

On the other hand, I have been keeping notebooks in which I wax poetic since I was eighteen and this book has inspired me to never ever share them with anyone.
Oh Boy. Alright, alright, alright. Did I enjoy this book! I love that the author reads / acts the audiobook himself. Great lessons about life / family / work and finding your inner self üëå

I've been crushing on this man for the last fifteen years.
So you best believe I pre-ordered this book immediately.

Matthew McConaughey has been keeping journals, diaries, and random writings for the past 35 years. Greenlights is all of those writings in one perfect little book. We get to hear about his childhood, his rise to fame, his Hollywood hiatus, his wife and kids, and so much more.

I have to say, the first 25% of the book was not the spark I was looking expecting from Matthew McConaughey.

LOVED! Amazing, amazing, amazing. So authentic and genuine. Matthew has lived an impressive life. He loves being a dad, loves his wife, and has tried to remained true to who he is. Hilarious story telling, tidbits of life tips along the way, and lots of greenlights. Highly recommend listening since he narrates it!

Matthew McConaughey is one heck of a story teller!
I listened to this on audio book and was truly engaged the whole way through.
This book is raw, witty, insightful, uplifting and had me laughing out loud

And lets be honest, with that voice, I would listen to McConaughey read the phone book!

I heard the audiobook read by the man himself and considering he is an Oscar winning actor, he sure knows how to perform a book well.
This was charming, honest, hilarious and written better than I expected. Through the fetishisation of Lord Byron and the Amazon River, Matthew‚Äôs amateur poetry and writing in this memoir has beautiful lessons to convey, yet in the spirit of his Lincoln ads, it sounds more profound than it really is.

I‚Äôve been looking forward to reading this for a few months and it was more enjoyable than I could have imagined. A refreshing reminder of how down to earth and human some high profile people can be. However, it‚Äôs an important account and reflection on life, regardless of who the author is. I started reading it 5 hours ago after picking it up at a local bookstore and didn‚Äôt put it down until I finished it. Quick and easy read.

Never have I ever read a book about the soul written in that way.

I've read books about the mind, successes and all that stuff.

This book has some things about success. It's called Greenlights after all. But this book is about the boat shaken, the frequency, and the story of a man who connected to his own natural frequency. It's raw, honest and most of all it's damn funny!

That's a book I want to have on my table and read throughout life.

5 stars for the Greenlights audiobook; the best oral delivery of a book I have heard. 4 stars for the contents. The stories were memorable and entertaining, and McConaughey uses these to inform his brand of folk philosophy. I found some of his framing of ideas to be quite novel. However, the second half of the book erred more on the side of uninspired clich√®s - a common sin of the autobiographical / self help genre. Overall, it is an honest and lighthearted memoir; imperfect, but delivered with

McConaughey is at his best in his own life and it's a whole lotta fun to be along for the ride. I loved listening to it, but I will also probably buy it because I actually think he's not only an amazing actor and person (lol @me fangirling hard!) but I think he's proved himself to be a great writer as well.

Will this be the best book I‚Äôve read this year? It damn well might be. Now I‚Äôve always like Matthew but I‚Äôve never been a STAN but fuck...after reading this I might be. I don‚Äôt know what kinda life I thought he lived but this was wild but also like in the most heartfelt and real way. As a southerner and a fellow Texan, I understand the charm and boy did it reel me in.
Last but not least and I cannot stress this enough READ THIS IN AUDIO FORMAT! He narrates the audiobook and him telling his life

So good! A voice like honey and stories that make you feel like you‚Äôve just settled in for a long chat with an old friend who leaves you feeling like you‚Äôve spent the day with a philosopher of life unscripted. What a story teller he is! I was blown away with the man behind the screen and what made him into who he is today. Highly recommend!

Overall I found this to be highly entertaining and written really fun and unique. But, literally the last page he goes into the ‚Äúracial injustice‚Äù of a drug addict who I will not name but I‚Äôm sure you can figure out. Whyyyyyy did he have to put that in his memoir?! Stop virtue signaling Hollywood! You aren‚Äôt woke, your annoying. Anyway, if that big black drug addict who killed himself with a life of crime and drugs trips your trigger, skip the last page.

This book was not my cup of tea. I feel like the crudeness was supposed to show transparency or vulnerability but it became distracting and gross for me personally. A lot of the journal musings were nonsensical and the whole experience was disappointing as I had hoped to find a human to human connection throughout the journey of the book, but just didn‚Äôt.

Matthew McConaughey‚Äôs Greenlights is an honest, enlightening memoir filled with humorous anecdotes, heartfelt reflection, a ton of outlaw logic, poetry, and not a single trace of ego. McConaughey writes like he‚Äôs telling us these stories by a campfire. It's just shy of 300 pages and I really could've spent a hundred more reading McConaughey's stories. It loses a half a point for that very reason (I want MORE), but other than that, this was everything I hoped it would be.

9.5/10

Probably the best book I've listened to all year apart from 'Can't Hurt Me' by David Goggins. The Audiobook version is an absolute must listen. This wasn't your typical chronological memoir with generic points but rather a flow of ideas and advice combined with gripping storytelling. McConaughey has a keen philosophy of red, yellow and green lights and defines these as his north-star. I laughed out loud at some of the stories such as the part where Matthew is an exchange student in Australia, es

4.3 Stars.

Well, it wasn't the 5 star read that I was anticipating, but the audiobook narrated by Matthew McConaughey himself, was exactly the comfort read that I needed at this moment.

Greenlights was uplifting, interesting, and the only thing (other than the election updates) that could hold my attention fully during this stressful week.

This was less of a memoir, and more of an approach or playbook for life.
There were personal stories, poetry, and McConaughey‚Äôs philosophy on how he has identif

5+ ***** Stars for the audiobook!!

I am now a fan of audiobooks (finally took the plunge) and Matthew McConaughey's narration of his memoir Greenlights blew me away!! A mix of adventures, life experiences, philosophy, poetry and introspection, I couldn't get enough! Light and heavy at the same time and one of the most captivating storytellers I've ever heard, this recording was an amazing 7 hour ride and beyond! I will be coming back time and again to all the gems and learnings in this little mem

Greenlights is a book that I wanted to savor, but instead, I finished in a day...because it was so good I couldn't put it down. MM tells stories that are at once relatable yet deeply remarkable. He's lived an interesting life and a privileged one, though he's also struggled. The way he writes, I often found myself saying, you too? His style is folksy/salt-of-the-earth, and there's a lot of wisdom within the pages. I loved this book, and after reading it, I have a great deal of respect for the au

full review: meganprokott.com/2020-nonfiction//gre...

Recently, I listened to a podcast interview with McConaughey and it really piqued my interest in his life so, I was very excited when I received Greenlights in the mail from Crown Publishing. I sat down on Sunday just to get a taste of the writing style, because truly you never know what you‚Äôre going to get with a high profile celeb memoir, and ‚Ä¶ I just didn‚Äôt stop reading. I read the entire book in one day and, needless to say, I loved it.

Personal reflection on his life growing up wanting to be a lawyer, trying out acting which later became his career, and going to other continents where he gained thrilling and sometimes weird life experiences.

Moral of the book is that all red and yellow lights are usually temporary, where we need to preserve and explore ways to do things, and later on those stop/pause signs will turn into greenlight and let us grow further in life. This is evidenced in his stories, and with the current ongoing p

An easy listen.
Narrated by the author.

Many of the tales are too fantastic sounding to be a part of a movie, yet they ring true because why wouldn‚Äôt they be.

For sure a book that just about any man in the 50-ish age bracket whose made his own way in this world will enjoy.

And if you‚Äôre 50ish and still here, we‚Äôll heck you‚Äôve made it pretty damn far. Take a 6hr break from life and listen to another mans stories.

I have to say that after listening to this one it is about what I expect from a book by Matthew McConaughey, fun, a bit zany and a bit spiritual. There were things that I didn't know about his life, some things that were infamous through the tabloids. All in all the book was entertaining, a bit kooky at times, but in a good way, which fits the author.

I burned through this one today! So fast in fact, that it felt like I had my own...Greenlights! It was full of adventure, appreciation for life, truths and done in the art of a great storyteller. McConaughey's biggest and most constant role...a person becoming.

So happy that my 52nd book of the year is by Matthew McConaughey! One of my favorite actors.

Matthew's book both tells you a bit more about him..and reminds you to just keep livin'
Matt's personality comes through very clearly in this book, so if you enjoy it like I do that is certainly a plus. Overall the reflections are a touch cliche and shallow, but still a nice read.
All right, alllll riiight.
This audiobook was a pleasure to listen to.

Listened to the entire book in one day while knitting... I laughed, cried and was inspired and impressed with his sentiments and passion for life. Definitely recommend the audiobook as he narrates the book himself.
A solid 3.5 audiobook. He‚Äôs great as the narrator and his personality shines thru. Fun, quick read.
I read the book and listened on audible at the same time and found the experience wonderful. I may be biased here with 5 stars because I love this man.

I listened to the audiobook version, read by the man himself, and seriously - it‚Äôs the only way to go. Can‚Äôt imagine having ‚Äúread‚Äù it any other way (although it would have still been great.) If you can listen, go that route! His voice makes it all the better!

Love, a fellow former East-Texan and current Austinite ü§ò
Enjoyed this one. Full RTC

Shockingly good! I knew Matthew McConaughey was a great actor, charming, sexy, and fun to watch‚Ä¶ But I had no idea how intelligent he is, what a great writer he is and how much wisdom he possessed!
I thoroughly enjoyed the book and recommend the audio version.
Two thumbs up!

I listened to this on Audible because I saw that it was McConaughey himself narrating. Hands down best audiobook I have ever listened to. It was a masterful performance and the writing was spectacular -- poetic, moving, and wise. Very pleasantly surprised with this book; McConaughey has a lot more wisdom about him than most would presume before reading his book. Five stars all the way.
Really enjoyed listening to the Audio version. Laughed, cried & never got bored. It was more than alright, alright.

Open and insightful glimpse of a life well-lived.

McConaughey is one of those actors, twinkly-eyed, easy-going, almost effortlessly buff and charming and likeable. And guess what? You'll probably think the same of him after listening to this audiobook of his life (or reading a paper version).

I wasn't after a tell-all-Hollywood-gossip memoir. And that's as far from this as you can imagine. This gives us a life of someone pretty normal in many respects - okay, a quirky family but one that gave a so

I loved this book! Yes, he rambles and maybe some of the stories are a little fabricated--I have no idea one way or the other. However, after finishing it, I really admire who he is as a human being and what he is trying to accomplish in his life. He inspires me to be more wanderlust and take more risks; to be more free-spirited. I really struggle with being free-spirited--that's for sure! What a great example of it!

The opening story is a jaw-dropper and really draws you in to learn more about h

I'm waffling on my rating. This was an Entertaining (with a capital E!) audiobook, and I would highly recommend that anyone who loves, likes, dislikes, or hates McConaughey listen to it. It probably won't change your opinion of him, but it will absolutely hold your interest!
The stories told in Greenlights are fun and funny and interesting and completely nuts, but I suspect they're also made up... at least in part. McConaughey does a fantastic job telling them, to be sure! He's inappropriate, as

Not your typical autobiography - really made me view McCanughey in a different light. The audiobook was wonderful, his performance and personal reading of this made it possibly the best audiobook performance out of all the books I've ever listened to.

McCanughey's mindset and life perspective is beyond unique. I also absolutely loved his "bumper stickers" & "notes to self" that he mentions repeatedly throughout the book.

"Note to self: The arrow doesn't seek the target, the target draws the arrow

Matthew mcconaughey is not my favorite actor. Infact, I can't even pronounce his surname properly. But if you have not watched "True Detective" and "Dallas Buyers Club", go ahead and watch now.

And if you don't have time, watch his Oscar acceptable speech.

Alright, alright, alright!

Why should you or anyone listen to a memoir of a 50 years old Hollywood A lister? Because....... You have to..

Three things -
1. Don't read, listen. Audible baby. This is the first book (out of 126 audible listens) th

The first audiobook I have ever listened to because I don‚Äôt think there‚Äôs any other way to consume this book (my friend did gift me a hardcover copy though, so I will be able to look at the picture content. I will get the full experience.). Besides an incredibly uncomfortable first part which was him telling traumatic stories as if they were funny, the rest is pure McConaughey. Slightly incomprehensible, slightly ridiculous, charming because every absurdity is said with the utmost sincerity. McC

Alright, Alright, Alright!

Matthew McConaughey's memoir can be enjoyed most on audio! Don't miss the opportunity to hear Matthew McConaughey read his own work as sprinkles his words with laughter and enthusiasm. This isn't your typical memoir. McConaughey reveals his pivotal life moments (Greenlights), but he's vulnerable about his red light moments that eventually led to Greenlights. He's candid about his upbringing and I really enjoyed the man behind the image. Reflective and sincere, I found M

Who knows how long it would have been before I came across this memoir hadn't it been for my grandma having a morning talk show on during our recent visit. I was able to catch the ending of an interview about this book. Downloaded it on Audible, well pre-ordered it, and it automatically downloaded at midnight the day of its release. Sadly I had to wait a bit to finish my previous book but I devoured this once I started.

It's not your typical memoir in that he doesn't discuss some great adversity

There are books that inspire you to think. Others to hone a craft. Matthew's book --I can't bring myself to address him otherwise-- inspires you to live. This is, as he says himself, a love letter to life, a reflection on how to face that life and the challenges and opportunities it presents and how to turn those pesky red lights that come into life as greenlights. Yes, I'm pretty sure that 40% is BS, but who cares, this is storytelling at its best and "edu-tainment" at its finest. My favorite b

Matthew McConaughey is a good storyteller, I‚Äôll give him that. In his memoir he talks about a lot of things in his life and his family, and his adventures, although I suspect McConaughey is making at least some of the stories up. Most of them occur before he becomes famous, and they are the ones I like the most, but as he becomes a movie star - that's when the book starts to fall apart. There's barely any insight into Hollywood, he hardly names his co-stars, and there are no behind the scenes ac

I don't even know why I started the book because I'm not a hardcore fan or anything and maybe The Graham Norton Show is the reason I wanted to see what this book is about. On that show he talked about some of his somewhat weird experiences in life and I thought: Wow, who knew? He is a great storyteller. And now that I finished the book I feel like I know what kind of a person he is and I like him better for it.
I loved it. I'm not self-help reader and I don't believe they do help but I think this

Let me be clear, this is not your typical memoir. Oh I loved this! Matthew is a thinker with a deep inquisitive intellect. He‚Äôs very bright and has a fantastic way of expressing himself. It took me a minute to get into the cadence of this book that is filled with lively stories, anecdotes, favorite quotes And lessons he‚Äôs learned through his first 50 years. He‚Äôs not your typical celebrity and that he doesn‚Äôt take himself too seriously and he‚Äôs not all about the fame that comes with that celebrit

I chose to listen to this book on Audible so I could enjoy Matthew‚Äôs voice and fun, quirky personality. I don‚Äôt read a lot of memoirs, so I was a little skeptical of one written by Matthew McConaughey.
What a pleasant surprise! Greenlights turned out to be one of the best audiobooks that I‚Äôve ever listened to.
He uses colorful language to share the stories of his life, offering memorable quotes and anecdotes. In the way only Matthew can, he made me laugh, he surprised me, and he taught me life les

I needed this book. Thank you Matthew McConaughey, it‚Äôs outstanding. I highly recommend the audible but then after listening to it I actually had to buy the hard cover too. I know, I‚Äôm obsessed ha. Of course he narrates the audible and is just THE perfect storyteller. He reflects on his past while giving insight on his mistakes and successes. He‚Äôs quite witty and funny throughout the book with that smooth southern charm. He‚Äôs honest and humble while being inspirational. There is a collection of

An absolute delight to go through. I've read some wonderful books this year and this one is the best by a mile. Matthew's quirky tales and insights (and insightful bumper stickers) made this such a fun read. I was so genuinely happy to consume this book, that I got through both the audiobook and the physical book in less than a week. The audiobook is narrated by him which makes it all the more fun, and the physical book has the photos to go with the stories.
Read this. Listen to this.
Greenlight!

This is the best memoir I‚Äôve ever read and I wish it could have kept going. I purposely took my time with it.

Greenlights so simply narrates a life learned, urging us toward our personal wins and successes without telling us WHAT those successes are to them or should be for us.

I‚Äôve always liked Matthew McConaughey as an actor, and he seemed like a nice enough guy. But after reading all of his deep insights, world travels, risks and spiritual teachings‚Äîwow, he has my total respect and admiration

Man what a ride!

His book was more than all right all right all right!

It‚Äôs filled with some of the best story telling I‚Äôve ever read.
Lots of stories and experiences in his life.

It‚Äôs different than any other book I‚Äôve read as well. It‚Äôs like a mirror. It makes you look into your life and question who you are, what you‚Äôve done, and many more without trying.

It‚Äôs about balance and not trying to hard. It‚Äôs about being and living who you really. Not acting, not trying but simply being. Livin your

There are some books that don't really translate to audiobooks (I struggle with fiction books with a lot of characters - can't keep them all in my brain!) but some are infinitely improved by being audiobooks. This is one of those books. If I were to have read the book with my eyes, I still would have heard it in McConaughey's voice. But I would not have heard his Australian accent or his hoots and hollers when reading an aside and that would have been a major loss.

The only other books I can rem

I did not expect to love this book as much as I did. While I'm an unabashed fan of Matthew McConaughey, this book might even surpass my favorite films of his. The audiobook edition is read by McConaughey himself and is definitely the only way one should experience this memoir. His casual ad-libs, southern drawl, and ease in front of the mic aid in the atmospheric retelling of stories and lessons from the first fifty years of his life.

A memoir that is quintessentially McConaughey full of his sayings, aphorisms, and crazy stories. He finds a way to be insightful in own voice, which was the narrator in my head as I read. He creates a unique form by including his notes, transcripts, drawings, and photographs to create a scrapbook effect. It's hard not to like him more after learning the root of his values and earnestness he employs to impart them to the reader.

Blown away. His insight, his storytelling ability, his vulnerability and that voiceü§¶üèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è
I got all the feels during this book. It had so much value and meaning. Made me reflect and think so many times. Loved that majority of it was focused on his life outside of film and barely touches on his accomplishments...so much more about what actually made him the man he is. I‚Äôm so sad it‚Äôs over. Do yourself a favor and listen to the audiobook, you won‚Äôt be able to do it justice reading it yourself. His

Lives up to the hype. Super short audio book (6 hours) which was also refreshing!!

Matthew‚Äôs an amazing story teller, and the audio book showcased it. I also enjoyed the armchair expert podcast episode where he talks about the book (but it has spoilers so maybe listen after).

There were many times I stopped and skipped 30s back to relisten/reflect. Honestly think I might buy the hard copy just to be able to more easily peruse the bumper stickers/notes to self. If you even 10% enjoy Matthew McConau

This is exactly the book I needed in 2020. I wish I could make an exception and give it 6 stars instead of lousy 5. I enjoyed it that much.

Tip: Do yourself a favor and listen the audiobook with his own narration. It‚Äôs gonna take it to a whole new level reliving moments with the author himself.

‚ÄúWe cannot fully appreciate the light without the shadows. We have to be thrown off balance to find our footing.‚Äù

2.5 Stars on a generous curve. This book could have been re-titled after a Minutemen song "Shit From an Old Notebook". McConaughey describes "Greenlights" as a playbook, but I am baffled by what that even means. He is a born raconteur, and by far the best parts of this book are the epic stories. He is also given to hippy-dippy mysticism, self-help sloganeering, and a towering sense of self-regard. If you believe that McConaughey's life can serve as a blueprint for life choices, I recommend that

Very McConaughey. He‚Äôs my favorite actor, but I really didn‚Äôt enjoy the story. It was fun to listen to the audio book, felt like one of his movies. But I did miss out on the pictures. He‚Äôs like one of those friends that really embellishes stories, so you can only really believe 50% of what he‚Äôs saying.

I don‚Äôt regret my time with the book, but definitely not missing out on anything if you skip this one. Just watch one of his movies instead- you‚Äôll enjoy it more.

This is a short review of the audiobook version of this title.

Have you ever spend an evening with someone you know (or a stranger) drinking beer or wine just chatting and listening to their travel adventures and life stories?

This is exactly what's this audiobook's been like for me. It's been like sitting by the fire, in the middle of the night, listening to my mate Matthew telling me tales about his life's adventures. What a beautiful man! Amazing! Didn't want it to finish. I don't think it wo

It's pretty much what I expected. A nice short read that rotated between amusing, funny, thought-provoking, and at times, a little hard to follow. I don't pretend to fully understand some of the poems and thoughts he shared, but I didn't expect anything less. He's a hoot and I would have liked to have heard more of his stories. I was a little sad when I got done. Enjoyed this look into who he is.

Well...this is truly one of the best celebrity-penned memoirs I have read to date. Not many of them do well at penning their own stories. Of course, Matthew McConaughey nailed it. What an interesting life! My jaw dropped by page 22. I knew he was a character. He marches to the beat of his own drum and it works for him. Back stories to movies always interest me, and there are plenty in ‚ÄúGreenlights‚Äù.

Got it on audible which is read by Matthew, it was a book that I was always looking forward to hear more about, full of life's dilemas and thoughts that I believe some of us share at one moment or the other. It is written in a way that made me feel like I was in a room chatting with Matthew about his life and where he would pass me some advice, loved this feeling, definetely a Green Light!

Sorry, I didn't think the book was all that awe-inspiring. I read it over a 24 hour period and was like "meh". The reviews reflect that the book is very revealing. I don't even recall much about sexual assault or abuse. I think he copped out on what he really thought of his father. I thought his father was an abusive alcoholic redneck. They commented that he wrote the books isolated for 52 days in the desert in a place without electricity. It reads more like he wrote between takes of his Lincoln

The audible version of this book is the only way you should devour it! Funny and inspiring, Matthew tells his story as a Greenlights and purposes. I can see that he is more his characters than we know. Five stars, easy!

I've tried going to therapy and I've tried taking anxiety medication and neither were for me. That does not mean that those things won't work for someone else. Mental health treatment is not a one size fits all type of thing.

For me these are the things that work for ME (these are not recommendations for anyone else)

1) taking time away (a day or two)from everyone (total solit

This is a complex review for me!

I got to read this book as an ARC and I was super excited about it since I am first-year therapy graduate student. I think that I was coming at this book from a different angle. The book is from the perspective of a client in therapy, specifically group therapy. Christie is a very successful law student and professional who finds herself in need of help.

My main critique of this book (it is a memoir) was that I really struggled with ethical issues throughout the

I love reading advice columns and shows about people in therapy. I find the way people see their own problems fascinating, and I find them even more fascinating when taken through another person who is there to consider and possibly disagree with the way a person sees their problems. I am frustrated that I can't read a million books about people sharing their experiences in therapy. But I get it. Sometimes when I watch/read/hear these stories I think, "Wow, how can anyone be okay sharing this mu

An intimate debut memoir centering on group therapy and how opening up to strangers saved a life.

I‚Äôve often wondered how freeing it would be for a stranger or group of strangers to know my secrets. To have a group of people that did not hold back, judge or even tell you what to do. Simply a group of individuals
Thoughts soon.
Review to come but I definitely recommend this one.

This is difficult to rate because I didn't have any problems with the writing or how the author presented herself as a person, but the whole thing made my skin crawl. Everything Dr. Rosen did felt gross and unethical and over the line. There were so many times when Christie was about ready to quit going to group, and I was like "Good for you! Recognize that this isn't ok!" and then she always went back. I am glad that she ultimately got what she wanted and is in a good place. However, I don't th

I am a huge supporter of therapy, but this type of ‚Äòtherapy‚Äô is unethical and just plain wrong. What a weird thing to decide to write about and share with others..

Oh wow. Five stars all the way around.

I see the value in the way he makes everyone uncomfortable and let‚Äôs them feel things and get angry and work through it as a team. Having a support system is so important. Having a place to go every week at an exact time to keep the feeling of purpose alive in people who are struggling to

I applaud the author's desire to seek help, but the group she attended came across as "cult-ish" and/or something that would be endorsed by Gywenth Paltrow (Goop). Any group that requires you to come to their organization 3 times a week for 90 minutes $800/month screams cult-ish. This kind of "therapy" is not realistic or sustainable for the average person. Christie is a recovering bulimic, and after completing a 12-step program, she continues to be extremely unhappy. She is tired of feeling alone and miserable. We meet Christie as she aimlessly drives around in her car, wishing that she were dead. Christie is a promising law student turning lawyer. She is also in recovery from an eating disorder, insecure, anxiety ridden, lonely and a total mess. Her friend suggests that she embark on a journey of group therapy, and she does. Enter Dr Rosen and his groups.

Review of the Amazon Original kindle eBook (2020)

Funny short essay about writer/actress Mindy Kaling's hiring a baby nurse when after giving birth to her daughter Kit.

Help Is on the Way is one of the six-part Nothing Like I Imagined collection of autobiographical short comedy essays by Mindy Kaling available through Amazon Originals.

Nothing Like I Imagined


Since this is a collection of quick personal essays I‚Äôve decided to review them all in one swoop anthology style.

This will make you yearn for the love of your mother or a mother like. God knows what you need when you need and he will give it to you.
Heartwarming.

This essay explored Mindy's expectations versus reality when it came to adjusting to motherhood/ child rearing; expectations which were largely influenced by her late mother who didn't have a baby nurse and didn't rely on a nanny or babysitter, instead opting to depend on extended family to help raise Mindy. She's been more or less a part of the pop culture landscape since The Office, which is a long time, and her works are worth reading.

As always, it's honest, hilarious, endearing and a crisp short read! I think I'm definitely going to finish reading this series quick and pick up any book that Mindy writes in the future.

3.5 stars. I'm giving all 6 essays in this collection the same rating since it *is* a collection. Mindy is a fantastic writer but I mostly found this collection "meh". Perhaps it's because there were only 6 so I felt dissatisfied--I don't know. I just didn't feel as connected to her as I did in her previous books. I'd still recommend the collection--it's a fast and light read, and Mindy's writing voice is extremely personable.

Admitting you need help is one of the hardest things to do as an adult. I‚Äôm happy Mindy used her celebrity status for good: opening up about her journey into motherhood and showing that it‚Äôs okay not to be okay. I don‚Äôt yet have children of my own but hope to some day, and I can only imagine the constant fear of whether what you‚Äôre doing is right, perfect or ‚Äúnormal.‚Äù I‚Äôm glad Mindy found her own normal.

My favourite one so far out of the collection. I have three more to go!

This was such a sweet, heartwarming essay on her first pregnancy & the relationship she built with her daughter‚Äôs nurse, Rose. We also gain some touching insight on Mindy‚Äôs relationship with her mother & her fears about motherhood and the apprehension of asking for help.

I will read anything & everything Mindy has to write! Definite 5 stars for this one. Also - that knee quote made me LOL.

"Don't complain, don't explain"; it's a quote Mindy's mother lived by.

In this part of the series she talks about her decision to hire a baby nurse and how that plays out for her. It's emotional, comedic, humane. What I liked about this part is that she has humanized a 'celebrity mom'.
She compares how motherhood was for her mother vis-a-vis herself.

She is single, has lost her mother and is somewhat terrified about motherhood. She finds her way eventually. Kudos to her!

Lovely perspective on asking for and receiving help

I love Mindy's conversational style and clean writing. This is a wonderful, emotional fast read that touches on a very difficult thing for many people...asking for and accepting help. Mindy shares her thoughts and emotions so openly that it reads like an email or text from a friend rather than a story you downloaded and read first thing before getting out of bed on a Saturday.

All of the feels

This essay, like the others released in this collection, has made me laugh and cry. Mindy Kaling has long been my idol, and her honesty and voice are comforting. Although in this particular essay she talks a lot about her doubts and fears, I still find myself asking, "Is there nothing Mindy Kaling can't do?" This is a must-read if you love Mindy Kaling and/or good quality writing.

I‚Äôve said this so far after each one of Mindy‚Äôs stories, but this one is my favorite. Mindy‚Äôs story about life postpartum without her mom really resonated with me. Like everything she writes, it is hilarious and brilliantly written. She describes things in a way that made me feel like I was listening to my friend tell a story. There were also some really touching parts that will stay with me. Short and sweet‚Äî I hope she never stops writing.

Help Is On the Way is a short story in the Nothing Like I Imagined series by Mindy Kaling. You can read these stories in any order.

I don't know what it is like to be a single mother, but I can imagine from what I've seen friends go through that it is no walk in the park. I'm glad Mindy found someone to help her get through those initial scary times and develop the confidence to rock motherhood!

Also, I saw what you did there at the end, Mindy Kaling....Fortunately, it wasn't a spoiler!

This essay from the Amazon short collection of stories by Mindy Kaling also made me a laugh. In this essay, she talks about how her baby nurse, who she didn‚Äôt think she would need, turned out to be a blessing in disguise as she helped her tremendously to deal with the challenges during the early days of motherhood.

I didn't want to like an essay about a famous person who had the luxury of hiring someone to take care of their baby. However, I can't help but love the bond between Mindy and the baby nurse. I love the way she steps in and provides such a comfort and help for Mindy at a time when Mindy misses her mom so much.

Pregnancy reality check

Kudos to Kaling for writing this book. Pregnancy and motherhood can be difficult for anyone, regardless of the mother's income and resources available to her. I enjoyed reading her stories of woe and realized that being a single parent is a tough path to follow after achieving Hollywood stardom. Kudos to Kaling ü§†

Another delightful snippet from the world's most delightful celeb. It must be difficult for her because she writes in a way that makes me, and I'm sure all of her other billion fans, feel that we actually so know her.

Whether it's a TV show, movie, book (audio, please!), I will be the first in line to hear what she has to say.

It was good to read about Mindy's own experience through having her baby as a single mom. Happy for her that despite the anxiety and fears she had Rose as her support system. Every woman could use a mother figure when she herself was on the edge of becoming a mom.
It's a hard thing to explain, it just is..

The one in which she discusses new motherhood, and the difficulty of asking for help. Definitely a more emotional one, but Mindy cuts the more touching moments with bits of her relatable humor. Leave it to Kaling to write a short story about being a parent that any young woman (and, frankly, any woman) can see herself in.

Funny and honest

Mindy, as always, is both funny and honest. She has the ability to pull at you heartstrings and make you laugh at the same time. I‚Äôm looking forward to enjoying the rest of this series of quick reads.

This one was my absolute favorite. I LOVED these 6 books released today (10/6/2020) by Mindy Kaling. I would recommend reading them and then listening to them. I could listen to her all day telling stories. They were funny, uplifting, touching and get 5 stars ‚≠êÔ∏è from me.

This set of essays really made me chuckle, the view of motherhood pre- and post-event is something exceedingly relatable, even if I couldn't relate to hiring a Rose! I still loved reading about the relationship with Rose and thoroughly enjoyed this entry in the series.

This essay is about how Mindy hires a baby nurse to assist her after the birth (and subsequent months after the birth) of her daughter. It‚Äôs not relatable to me, but I see how it could be for other single moms. 4 stars for keeping it clean.

Five epic stars. More women need to talk about their pregnancies and what comes after -- and Mindy Kaling is talking about how it feels to come home a single mother, the worries you have, and how you find a support team (even if that's a nanny) to help you.

Not a parent, but I am a daughter. So from what I read, Mindy and my Filipino-American family have similar values. Loved hearing about the ups and downs of motherhood as well as the sense of found family with Rose. Honest and hilarious.

We All Need A Rose In Our Lives

Funny & light-hearted, even though the small-talk at parties "shivered me timbers" making me nauseous. Introverts arise & make an alternate plan! But read this since it won't hurt.

We all need help sometimes

Candid and moving story from Mindy Making about her life during her pregnancy, not having her Mom there to help her with advice and help after her pregnancy.

This was a really cute essay on Mindy's path to motherhood and all her insecurities around being a mother. Admitting you need help is hard for anyone to do, and it's honestly comforting for Mindy to be so open and candid about all of her struggles (while also making me laugh).

This is one of three or four free Audible offers of Mindy Kaling's writing and the first I listened to. In this one, Kaling talks about hiring a baby nurse, how strangers can grow to become family and, ultimately, accepting that it's okay to ask for help.

This essay is about Mindy having a baby and hiring a baby nurse to help out.  Sometimes it is hard to ask for help as adults; but they say it takes a village to raise a baby. Loved reading about Mindy‚Äôs relationship with Rose. A heartwarming and honest read!

The general review: a series of essays that don't quite add up to the length of her two prior outings, each bite is nevertheless a nice look into Mindy Kaling's life and thoughts. She's been more or less a part of the pop culture landscape since The Office, which is a long time, and her works are worth reading.

The combination of honesty + money + gossip + flaws is what makes this story great. We all have the same issues around donating and charity, I think, it's just rare that someone is open ab

This was the perfect way to wrap up Mindy's essay collection. It started with a funny story and, like Mindy does best, took lighthearted, fun stories to talk about deeper things. She talks a lot about her issues with generosity and overcompensating as a minority compared to the white men in the industry, as well as her struggles with constantly wanting people to like her. I think this is something that almost everyone struggles with, but it's not something that especially celebrities talk about

So this was a good read. A few lines made me pause and think and I immediately related to how I felt.
The one good part was how she drew the differentiation between GIVING and GENOROSITY

being generous is being absolutely above expectation. Even a thank you, to the point that it may look like you don't care, but you should care but not care for the after in a way that doesn't make you look callous or irreverent.
One of the better essays
I also loved how she took us through her day and broke the

The story/lessons she learns about being charitable without recognition is endearing and relatable. I thought it was a nice way to end the series of essays, but then she throws in an ‚Äúextra‚Äù of her daily life. While I enjoy reading about her daily activities in that witty way she has of telling stories, I could have done without the swearing. Ending the book with the F*word put me off the whole thing. I‚Äôm being generous in giving it 4 stars.

3.5 stars. I'm giving all 6 essays in this collection the same rating since it *is* a collection. Mindy is a fantastic writer but I mostly found this collection "meh". Perhaps it's because there were only 6 so I felt dissatisfied--I don't know. I just didn't feel as connected to her as I did in her previous books. I'd still recommend the collection--it's a fast and light read, and Mindy's writing voice is extremely personable.

This is actually the last part of the whole series. It's a good way to end it. It also includes a 'day in my life' kind of part at the end for people who are interested.

In this book she has shared an incident in which she hasn't shyed away from criticising herself. She's aware of the difference between generosity and giving.
She recognises her past mistakes and has grown above them now. It's like a coming of age tale squeezed into an essay.

The whole series was a good read all in all.

Authentic, funny, vulnerable

Mindy Kaling has such a real voice. She is able to talk about her life in a way that gives you a peek into the celebrity world as well as the real world foibles of a human being. I love her humor, which is both self deprecating and quick witted. As a fellow second generation American Tamilian, I am very proud of Mindy Kaling‚Äôs ability to talk about the immigrant experience in such a down to earth and relatable way.

In her final essay, Mindy talks about treating an A-list celebrity and his family to a Christmas dinner in Hawaii but not being thanked for it at the time and feeling bad about it. I wish she had named the celebrity!

A day in the life of Mindy Kaling was bonus content which was fun to read about!

Very intriguing and thoughtful essay

On what it means to be generous. I loved how Mindy took the reader on her journey of how her attitude and perspective on what it meant to her to have ‚Äúmade it‚Äù and how she tried to leverage it into relationships with others. I especially loved the ending as it truly shows the introspection and growth she has achieved along her journey.

In the story, Big Shot, Mindy talks about how she chased acknowledgement from others; paying for meals just to get some recognition in return. I can relate -- I always want people to like me although I don't like them. We should live life on our own terms.

I also loved seeing the behind-the-scenes portion as a producer.

The Single Life
Review of the Amazon Original kindle eBook (2020)

Mindy Kaling relates her feelings about being single at couples parties and fantasizes about what they think of her. Her imagined perfect partner is Coach Taylor (as played by Kyle Chandler in the Friday Night Lights TV-series).

Searching for Coach Taylor is one of the six-part Nothing Like I Imagined collection of autobiographical short comedy essays by Mindy Kaling available through Amazon Originals.
It's about her life as a single mum and her thoughts on having a husband- pros and cons.
The topic in the one did not resonate as much as the others with me. But, it was still entertaining to read (and good for my reading goal).

This one was tough to read. Although I found comical her list of reasons why she doesn't regret being single, her bashing of married people and a husband in general was regrettable. She clearly does not understands the real bliss and commitment that come from fighting for and working on the covenant of marriage long term. Her whole view really is a commentary on how marriage is viewed and often handled by many young single adults today, as well those choosing to live together before marriage.

In "Searching for Coach Taylor" Mindy outlines the complexities of being a single parent, her feelings about wanting to find the right person but at the same time valuing her independence, how non-single parents react to her choices by pitying her, her ideals when it comes to a potential partner/husband and the challenges in finding someone who fits those ideals, as well as the pros and cons of being married.

I thought that Mindy hit the nail on the head when describing the judgment that people

The general review: a series of essays that don't quite add up to the length of her two prior outings, each bite is nevertheless a nice look into Mindy Kaling's life and thoughts. She's been more or less a part of the pop culture landscape since The Office, which is a long time, and her works are worth reading.

This story is the spiritual successor to all of Mindy's essays on the nature of friendships and relationships. It is excellent, and it doesn't really need very much in the way of explanati

This one really benefitted from the Mindy's audiobook performance. Her delivery of "OMG the new artisanal coffee shop on Larchmont! OMG Fleabag! OMG the president!" amped up the joke by several notches. I loved the line about the fact that wives never mean it when they say they hate their husbands, "It's like me joking that I hate Dick Wolf procedural crime dramas when we all know I treasure them more than my family." Well this was glorious. Though I am a tech-savy Gen X woman, I haven't gotten behind the audio book exlerience. But I can see listening to Mindy Kaling herself read me her hilarious essays is going to be a very enjoyable experience.

I read Mindy's 1st two books, and loved them. This essay met my high expectations (and I've never even seen Friday Night Lights!). Can't wait to dive into the others!

3.5 stars. It was ok. A short story about how her personal choice to be a single mom is great for her right now, and one day before she dies she might have a husband. She makes some assumptions about married people (both women and men) that are completely false and only reflects her opinions and shouldn‚Äôt be considered factual at all. There is some swearing, which is always a negative for me. Overall, it was just ok.

This part of the series is like actually listening to her, rant about being single and having to deal with others in this regard. But it isn't so bad. Some references I did not get but they didn't seem specially relevant.

It's about our expectations and the reality of romantic relationships. She has very well enlisted the pros and cons of being single. Again inspiring us along the way. I can't thank her enough.

3.5 stars. I'm giving all 6 essays in this collection the same rating since it *is* a collection. Mindy is a fantastic writer but I mostly found this collection "meh". Perhaps it's because there were only 6 so I felt dissatisfied--I don't know. I just didn't feel as connected to her as I did in her previous books. Is still recommend the collection--it's a fast and light read.

Mindy Kaling does not have time for your pity about her choice to be a single mom. She's taking aim (and hitting target) on why she's pretty sure she doesn't need a life partner to have a fulfilling existence (and good for her). The section about why she kind of wishes she had one anyway did make me appreciate my own dude all the more.

This woman writes well but it is all fluff. There is no depth whatsoever and seemingly no awareness of her enormous privilege. I keep hoping there will be something more, because Mindy is clearly intelligent, but... Nope. I have absolutely *nothing* in common with her. Not one thing. Except maybe that we're both mothers. And we both love The Good Wife.

Fun and open

This short story is fun and open on the aspect of being a single mom and the thoughts that there are some benefits of being the single parent without feeling the guilt. It at times can be hard to see when you are in a commitment because there are compromises that are made that we forget even take place because they come as second nature.

We've been watching the Mindy Project (a rewatch for me, first time for my husband) so when I saw this series of six essays by Mindy Kaling it was an obvious download. The Kindle version is free to Amazon Prime members and after you download them you can access the audio free as well. Obviously I listened to this in audio read by the author - this is a buddy adventure story about Mindy and BJ Novak, one night in Los Angeles....

The Goodreads community was not quite as here for this one, but I was. Honestly, any BJ/Mindy story is a hit, I'd have fun reading their dry cleaning receipts. But this is sufficiently more fun than that.

A really mellow drifter attempts to steal B.J's laptop. The drifter posing as an Office fan. B.J interrogating while Mindy blocks his exit via pining him in the driver's seat by standing in front of the door and her 8th month pregnant belly. A story!

Confirmation that B.J. is the exactly the typ

Please Like Me (But Keep Away) - 4 Stars - This essay reviews the time when Mindy moved to LA to write for the office and had to find/make friends as an adult. A most daunting task indeed. Funny essay about a night out with BJ Novak and a homeless person. So funny! I just love the way she tells a story!

Mindy's obviously a great storyteller and as I was reading, I could just picture everything that played out, almost as if I were watching a show; I could totally see how each essay could be turned into one-off episodes on YouTube. Anyways, the drifter incident was bizarre and the Mindy-B.J. duo were hilarious, but the best part was how Mindy summed up her reaction to the drifter (and all of his weirdness) with a "y tho?".

3.5 stars. I'm giving all 6 essays in this collection the same rating since it *is* a collection. Mindy is a fantastic writer but I mostly found this collection "meh". Perhaps it's because there were only 6 so I felt dissatisfied--I don't know. I just didn't feel as connected to her as I did in her previous books. I'd still recommend the collection--it's a fast and light read, and Mindy's writing voice is extremely personable.

The general review: a series of essays that don't quite add up to the length of her two prior outings, each bite is nevertheless a nice look into Mindy Kaling's life and thoughts. She's been more or less a part of the pop culture landscape since The Office, which is a long time, and her works are worth reading.

Drifter Chronicles!

My 5th short story read from Mindy on her super wierd yet super funny encounter with a homeless/drifter man and her friend,  B. J.. I can literally visualize how Mindy and B. J. from 'The Office' would have enacted such a scene.

The nice part about Mindy's writing is she shares simple stories about her life, ties it back to some lesson she learned or an observation about the larger truth of the world. This coupled with her writing makes it relatable and hence it works!

This part of the series had a lot of references I didn't get. The story also seemed pointless to me; except for her own condition at the time and her surprising, real bravado! That's a treat to look out for.

The other parts in this series are better than this one and have more substance.
It is mysterious though and like a scene from a movie, the events play out perfectly; much like fiction!

This short story was about a weird, funny story that happened to Mindy and B.J. Novak. I really enjoyed it and it was a fun story to hear, but it felt a little out of place. It's kind of a different wavelength from the other stories she has shared so far, and I feel like it shouldn't have been a standalone. But either way I enjoyed it.

Nice quick lunchtime read. Nothing extremely spectacular, but a nice quick break from reality when/if you need it.

Somehow both exuberant and enigmatic, Lenny Kravitz has always occupied a quaint corner of the cultural space, both as artist and person(a). Here he looks back on an extraordinary upbringing (mixed-race, multi-everything), in which he seems to have met everyone and seen everything, with disarming verve, honesty and humour. Where‚Äôs the rest of it?! The book was really well written and felt really honest. Especially about his lack of money and semi-homelessness. But I feel like I only read the first 2/3s of the book. Where is the rest?! What happened when he returned to the US to tour? Why did he and Lisa Bonet divorce? How did they raise Zoe? What does he think about her life, career, etc? Does he like Lisa‚Äôs wrestler/actor boyfriend? What has he been doing for money the last few years? What‚Äôs his mother doing? Are

I just recently finished Lenny Kravitz's memoir, Let Love Rule. I listed to the audiobook and he narrated it himself, I love when authors do their own narration!

Let Love Rule, titled the same as Lenny's first hit album, was the story of his childhood up through the birth of his daughter, Zoe, and the release of his first major album. He went into detail about his relationship with his mother and father, his move from coast to coast, his close bond with family and friends, and his passion for mus

If you like Lenny Kravitz‚Äôs music, you will like this book. It is amazing what a life he has led, the people he has met and learned from, and what a balanced person he seems to be. I like the fact that it is read by him as well. The only bummer, I suppose, it that it begins with his life as a youngster but only goes through his Let Love Rule album. I had hoped for more, but I suppose there will be follow up books.

Hungry for more

My mind kept wandering throughout this offering, wondering how an almost lifetime could be crammed into these limited pages. Well, it couldn't, and now I'm hungry for more. I don't feel any closer to understanding Lenny's lived experiences and yet I could finally see how love shaped his path to self-discovery as an artist. Left me feeling sad for his apparent wanderlust and continuing reinvention.

3 1/2 to 4 stars. I love Lenny Kravitz. He‚Äôs my secret boyfriend but doesn‚Äôt know it. I listened to the audiobook and he narrated, which had quite the appeal, but he was very monotone and it made the story kind of boring. The book was decent enough, interesting, but I wanted more from it. It seems there will be a ‚Äúnext era‚Äù coming and I‚Äôll be interested in that. This was good but not as good as I had hoped.

This book, while well-written was very focused on his early childhood and family life. He ended the book around 1990 when his first album was released. If you are looking for a book about his rise to fame and celebrity, I would skip this one. The writing was very beautiful but ending the book when you're career is just taking off seems an odd choice. Maybe this means there will be a second book of his memoirs? Not sure...

Although I‚Äôve never really spent much time listening to Lenny‚Äôs music, I thoroughly enjoyed listening to him read this book. He is very introspective and deep. His deep love for his extended family and strong creative genius comes through loud and clear. I decided to read (listen) to this book after hearing him interviewed on a podcast. His voice as narrator is mellifluous (don‚Äôt you love that word?!)

This book is amazing. I need more musicians to do audiobooks. I absolutely loved hearing Lenny sing a few lines from songs he sang as a child to those he put on his album. I loved learning what made him who he is, what influenced his musical style and his fashion sense. I got it all and so much more in this book.

I listened to the audiobook which is ready by Lenny himself and made this so worth it. Lots of good memories in here of his mother and his relationship with his father. Most of the book covers his childhood and slow rise to fame with the release of his first album. His marriage to Lisa and their first child is also mentioned. A very nice memoir if you are a Lenny fan.

Love Lennys music and style this book isn‚Äôt going to change that. However felt it was heavy on the name dropping and famous connections and light on substance , emotion and depth of what makes him tick. Why such a conflict with his dad ? Found I lost interest here and there . Maybe he‚Äôll go deeper for the next 25 years of his life memoir.

I loved Lenny‚Äôs book. I listened to him read it, and he even sang some parts of it. He‚Äôs such a sweet soul. I thought his story was fascinating. Lenny worries about his hair and clothes a little too much, but hey, how can he be the king of cool without worrying about his hair and clothes? üòÇ I can‚Äôt wait for the follow up book.

Nice memoir by one of rocks most chill legends. Great stories of him growing up in New York with his mixed race parents and learning about life from his African-American family as well as his Jewish family, who lived in different neighborhoods in NYC. Lenny shares his philosophies and influences as well.

I saw this book on my library's New Biographies list and thought, "I bet Lenny Kravitz has had an interesting life." He has, and with David Ritz he does a good job recounting his story. My only complaint is that the book ends with "Let Love Rule" atop the charts, he and Lisa Bonet deeply in love, and the birth of their daughter, Zoe.

I felt shortchanged as this memoir only covers his first 25 years when he is young and lucky. He doesn't even address his divorce from Lisa Bonet. Audio is the way to go because Kravitz's voice is beautiful and he sings a little of his music -- wish it had been more. His reflecting on his teen years before cell phones and the internet calls attention to what a different world we are in today.

This was disappointing. It was simply written and focused mostly on his life prior to age 20. He only gets into his relationship with Lisa Bonet towards the end and then leaves it with a "to be continued" which means there will be another book that will actually focus on his success as a Rockstar and what happened for him and Lisa to separate. Ugh!!!

Very well written. It is the story of the first 25 years or so of Lenny Kravitz. Love between him and his mother and the conflict between him and his father. Lenny was a creative kid but a terrible student. He found his peace in music. From Manhattan, Brooklyn, LA and the Bahama‚Äôs he made connections that help propel his career.

I was pretty disappointed in the writing. Nothing of Lenny Kravitz's personality showed through. I feel like he used his fellow writer to help tell a story that he, himself, would have been better at putting into words. This book just really felt shallow compared to the real word creativity of the man. It's very rare that I give this kind of review to an autobiography.

I was expecting more of his story. It ends with "to be continued." Interesting memoir that shows the struggle it takes to make it in the music industry, with family baggage in tow...the good, the bad and the ugly. Lenny did a great job narrating.

I finished this book in one day. I have always loved Lenny. He has such a beautiful soul and heart. I really enjoyed learning about his family and all the special people he surrounded himself with. He is very candid and ever humble.

As a major Lenny fan I couldn‚Äôt wait for this book, and I got both the audible and hard copy. I highly recommend the audible version though, you‚Äôll be treated to a mini concert. An amazing story and really hope he writes about his journey after Let Love Rule next.

This beautiful story by a beautiful individual enthralled me from the first word. Lenny reading his story made for a compelling read that I didn't want to end. His voice and emotional tone made me feel like I was living the history by his side. The song samples were icing on the top!

I've had a thing for Lenny Kravitz for quite a while and I enjoyed the hell out of this book. It only covers the time up until his daughter, Zoe, is born, so we are missing a good 30 plus years. And I normally hate that, but there is so much beauty in his story...I just can‚Äôt complain.

I love Lenny Kravitz and his music. It was interesting to hear of his dedication and love of music, but I found this book more about the telling of a super privileged life, although trying to describe hardship.

This was so good - I had to make myself put it down to go to bed last night! I am kicking myself for not listening to him reading the audio version because I can imagine that only made it even better! I can‚Äôt wait for the next book!! üòç

This biography was well-written, and portrays a really interesting life. It ends with the release of Let Love Rule (Lenny's first album), so I'm anxious to learn more about his subsequent life. I think Kravitz has a really interesting story to tell.

One of the more enjoyable autobiographies I've read. I just wish it had gone on for longer, as it ends just as Lenny starts to have success. Though I enjoyed reading about his unorthodox childhood. Overall, I would recommend if you're a fan.

Let me save you a read: Lenny Kravitz does not like his dad, lives off the largesse of different women (mom, girlfriends, Lisa Bonet) while he tries to find his sound, and drops the names of all the famous people. Super annoying & kinda boring.

Finished it in two days and so sad when it was done. Felt like we were just getting into really good stuff. Gonna be a long wait for the next one. Love his honesty, his relationship with his mom and his grandparents and of course all the name dropping.

I enjoyed the audio version, which was read by Lenny. I didn‚Äôt know much about his background except that he had been married to Lisa Bonet. This book covers the first part of his life up until he finally starts to make it big as a musician. It‚Äôs a short listen at 6+ hours.

Lenny Kravitz has had a fascinating life that has intersected with so many amazing people. It is interesting to hear him talk about troubles with his father, yet simultaneously see how his early exposure with music was cultivated by his father.

To Be Continued?

I really enjoyed this book a lot, I love Lenny Kravitz. BUT... and apologies if this is a spoiler in any way, maybe as the title says, it only covers up to him putting out Let Love Rule and then ends. It kind of reminded me of how‚Äôs Fleas autobiography read.

Highly recommend the audio version since Lenny reads it. It sounds like he was meant for stardom from an early age crossing paths with famous people. Family is important to him and it comes across in his writing. Definitely an interesting and enjoyable book. Did I mention he sings?

This memoir is chock-full of information, and it moves along at a rapid clip so it‚Äôs never boring. I‚Äôm not sure I saw into Kravitz‚Äôs soul here, but I enjoyed tagging along on the adventures of his early life.
An inspired telling of an iconic artist's journey of self discovery.
A celebrity memoir with all heart and no ego. What a sweet soul.

Straight from the heart, like his music

I really like how he describes the way to his first album. Is both inspiring and humbling to know how much has gone into it
I have been an absolute long time fan and I just loved this book. What a story, what a talent..looking forward to the next book!
I couldn‚Äôt put it down. What an intriguing life this man has led.
Listened to Lenny tell me his story thanks to Macmillian Audio. Loved it. Was sad when it ended. It was like listening to a trusted friend tell me their story.

Just like Michelle Obama's Becoming and Trevor Noah's Born a Crime, Lenny Kravitz' memoir Let Love Rule is deserving of 5 stars. It is so sweet, reflective and endearing. It hit only on his first 25 years, but I am a bigger fan of this man now.

Cait is a hiker and a blogger who has "opted out" of society's expectations and carved out her own life, on her own terms. This book is her "field guide to leading an intentional life."
But for something claiming to be intentional, this book doesn't seem to know what it wants to be. Instead of inspiring it's all so.....banal....and bland.

I was SO looking forward to reading this book because I loved Flanders' previous book, Year of Less. This one was disappointing. The premise sounded great - "opt out" of the expected paths and find your own way/adventures. She writes the book with "opting out" being an analogy to hiking. But, like many reviews said (and I didn't want to believe) it was VERY repetitive and used the same few examples over and over and over. And most of the examples were pretty vague, so it didn't have much impact.

Thank you to the publisher for providing me with an eARC of this novel via NetGalley in exchange for an honest review.

My honest to god gut reaction while reading this was: Cait...girl...please tell me something I don't know.

I appreciate the message that Adventures in Opting Out is trying to deliver. I fully ascribe to the belief that we should live our own lives fearlessly the way we want, not how other people want us to live them. Make messes, go on big or little adventures, find your niche com

I was so looking forward to Cait‚Äôs second book but it feels bland, repetitive, and overly simplistic. It‚Äôs actually painful to write this because I so enjoyed her first book and also her Instagram posts.
Please no more self help books based on a hiking analogy.

I read and enjoyed the author's first book. This one didn't hit home with me quite as much. There are some good bits about opting out from "regular" life and following the life path that suits you best. Flanders tried to parallel opting out with hiking terminology and it sometimes works, but at other times just feel a little gimmicky. From reading the book, I know the author was trying to make the information here more generalized rather than sharing more of her own story but I think this book w
Meh. I didn‚Äôt like the first book so don‚Äôt know why I thought this would be any different. It‚Äôs not that it was a bad book - I just didn‚Äôt get the content I was hoping for.

Dang. I really did like The Year of Less and I like Cait's voice, but I just did not feel a connection with Adventures in Opting out. Small sections of the book landed solidly, but overall I didn't feel like it had much value for me. Too bad.

I really like the message of this book, listening to your gut, managing the pushback you might get from opting out, keeping important people in your life even if they might not understand‚Ä¶ I think the tone and writing style just didn‚Äôt work for me. All of the analogies were cute but didn‚Äôt always make sense, and it veered more into self-help and giving directions rather than telling the story of how she spent a year traveling from place to place. I had low expectations after reading the other reviews, but I was pleasantly surprised by this book! I was a longtime reader of Cait‚Äôs blog, and loved her work. It was a grounded voice that resonated with me, and was a refreshing change from the rest of the Canadian personal finance blogosphere.

I read her first book and didn‚Äôt enjoy it - perhaps it was better for readers who were new to her as an author, but it was more or less a reprint of her blog.

When this book came out, I gave it a try. She‚Äôs written how this book feels a lot different than her last one.

This book had me with this....

"We all follow our own path in life. At least, that's what we're told. In reality, many of us either do what is expected of us, or take the invisible, but well-worn paths that lead to what is culturally acceptable. For some, those paths are fine-even great. But they leave several of us feeling disconnected from ourselves and what we really want to do. When that discomfort finally outweighs the fear of trying something new, we're ready to opt out."

This book is hard to categorize its part self help, part memoir part travelogue. The author focuses on the idea of it being okay to "opt out", choose to live some aspect of your life in a way that's different than others expectations, if it doesn't hurt you or other people. She talks some about her own opt out of having a permanent residence and deciding to travel around Europe for a time but also interviews others who have had their own opt out. She uses a hiking analagy throughout.

I overall l

I‚Äôm disappointed to write this review, as a great fan of Cait‚Äôs blogging, social media, and first book. I feel this book missed the mark. I was really excited to dig into this book after loving Cait's first book, The Year of Less. The tagline says it's a field guide and that's exactly how it feels when you're reading. While none of the advice is groundbreaking per se, it does give helpful reminders and encouragement from a friend who feels like a fellow trailblazer. I adored Year of Less and preordered the audio of this one because I was so excited. But. I get what she was trying to do with the hiking analogy format but it didn‚Äôt work at ALL for me. I wish an editor had realized how much powerful it could have be

I loved Cait‚Äôs first book and I love this one as well, though they are very different. This one is for all those who are drawn to the path less travelled. Follow along as Cait shares some of the paths and experiences she intentionally chose to leave behind, and what she was able to find as a result. A timely reminder that we only get one chance at life and the book provides a guide of sorts for how to navigate leaving the ‚Äúnorm‚Äù behind and finding your own way. Highly recommend!

Absolutely loved this book. It doesn't feel like a self help book, but it really makes you feel good about making choices that are right for you even if they aren't mainstream or they seem daunting. The writing feels like a friend chatting and it's relatable.

Flanders uses an extended metaphor to compare making different life choices to the elements of a hike. I really liked her first book, which felt personal, compelling and left me ruminating for quite a while. Sorry to say that this one feels distant, bland and highly repetitive. She works very hard to break down the hiking metaphor into infinitesimal pieces to keep the theme going. Nothing too profound here, but made me think that I can still opt out on a smaller scale ( given my age) and realized that my ex had opted out a long time ago & I did not realize it!

I love this book. It's full of nuance and real stories, not platitudes or sweeping "advice" like so many other books in this category. This is one where, if you go through it too quickly, you could miss the real magic. Cait is a joy to read; it's like catching up with an old friend. And I loved reading her travel reflections and stories throughout!
I‚Äôm a big fan of Cait Flanders, but this felt like it fell short. There is good content, but the story isn‚Äôt captivating. 2.5 stars.

I'm very conflicted in this review as I love Cait Flanders and really enjoyed her debut The Year of Less. This follow up somewhat missed the mark for me. Adventures in Opting Out is an interesting read and parallels the author's journey via the idea of hiking/mountain climbing. Each chapter develops starting from the bottom of a mountain until one reaches the summit. The author faced many challenges along the way, both in her personal life as well as on actual hikes and a trip to Europe. There are many lessons here that apply whether you need to change direction completely or

Cait Flanders is one of those writers where I feel like we're friends even though the closest we've ever come to talking was when she commented on one of my Instagram posts one time (which made my day). She's written another encouraging, compassionate, comforting read on living life on your own terms, perhaps especially necessary in these times. I felt this book lacked focus. It kept shifting from being a book about a year of travel to how to hike to analogies of hiking and opting out of something your life. Towards the end of the book she talks about how when she got her self out of debt she ‚Äúbought‚Äù herself a coffee and went down to the beach to celebrate. If you need inspiration or support during a time in your life when you want to change your path, this might give you that helping hand. As someone who plans every trip, every adventure and wants to know what I‚Äôll do along the way, this book helped me see the joy of giving a new path a try without having to know all the answers before I start.
