I read the kindle version. This book just comes at a perfect point for me, as I am about to navigate some drastic and intentional life changes. The purpose is really to help the reader navigate their opting-outs, with a special focus on the emotional aspects. Really recommend it as a practical guide to anyone looking to change any aspect of their life, and being at a counter current of folks close to them. It's tough and Cait offers a helping hand

I generally don't love books that have an "instruction manual" style/vibe so I knew going in that this might not be my favourite, but I've enjoyed Cait's other work and was glad to see that the style, personality, and warmth present in her newsletters carried over here. It was a lovely read and I came away with a few ideas to chew on/some much needed reminders, which is exactly what I'd hoped for.

Not exactly what I was expecting. I was thinking it was a book about living off grid. It's not. Disappointed, but the book was interesting, in it's own way. I could relate to it, a bit. In my own way, I opt out ocassionally, too. This will appeal to some young person, life's a journey; don't waste it. You should go out on limb and try new stuff, explore while you have the chance. Time enough to maybe pick another route. You have time and it all works out!

Cait Flanders spoke to my heart in this beautiful, affirming book about choosing the path less travelled. As a childfree, self-employed, serial renter, I have consciously left many of society‚Äôs expectations unmet; but that doesn‚Äôt make the road any easier to walk. Cait normalises every rollercoaster emotion whilst reminding me of the true importance of living in a way that is consistent with my values. I feel refreshed to keep striving forth with courage and ‚Äòhike my own hike‚Äô.

The underlying premise of the book has a lot of promise but the execution just wasn't there. I liked the analogy threaded through the book of hiking and making choices to 'opt out in life.' However Caits examples were not that inspiring or great. One that came up a few times was Cait living in another country but not being able to find accomodations that meet her budget in a few weeks. Would not recommend.

This book was such a wonderful read! Cait has carved a unique and intentional life for herself, and her honesty and candid writing are refreshing. Even as someone who lives a fairly normal, unadventurous life, this book challenged me to look for ways the status quo isn't working for me and to examine them. What a wonderful second book from Cait Flanders!

A refreshingly honest and thoughtful reflection on taking the road less traveled. Heartwarming and encouraging and exactly the kind of book I needed during a year where everything we were told about how to live has come into question -- the best and most beautiful adventures come from "hiking your own hike," not anyone else's. Highly recommend!

I like Cait‚Äôs writing in general, and I liked this book, but I‚Äôm not sure I loved it. I think I wanted more of her story during this particular opt out. There were absolutely good reminders and lines I‚Äôll think about and write down, but I‚Äôll have to see if I think about these analogies through my own future adventures.

I think this book would be really helpful for me if I hadn‚Äôt already gotten over the hump of needing other people to agree with or understand my life choices. If you‚Äôre looking to change something (especially something dramatic), she gives you a roadmap for trusting yourself to know what‚Äôs best for you.

I cannot praise Cait‚Äôs first book enough so I did what I never do and bought a copy of this book when I found out my library didn‚Äôt carry it. I enjoyed the read and continue to learn so much from her life experiences. I will say that I didn‚Äôt totally love the flow and found the anecdotes repetitive. Overall, I admire the author and will continue to support her work and message.

I followed Cait's blog for many many years and I enjoy her outlook on life. Unfortunately I felt like this book didn't have enough substance. Cait uses a hike as a metaphor for following your own path in life. That's basically the book in one sentence. It would have been more impactful as a number of blog posts or newsletters.

Author Flanders wants to give a path to executing a live of value. But there is an attempt to become beyond the usual stuff. She says we need to get ‚Äúopt out‚Äù as a way of doing something new and important. The best of the book comes in the last quarter of the book when she uses gives us a new way to see what is necessary to make a difference in one‚Äôs life.

I liked the overall read about how to improve one's life as an analogy of climbing a mountain. I would have preferred to read more personal impacts/stories of how the author achieved this instead of just talking about the steps. Overall it was a quick read - would give 3/5 stars.

Amazing

I read caits first book and it became my favorite book , now her second book here is my new favorite. She's an in credible writer and speaks from the heart. Life changing words that came at my own stage of life of choosing multiple opt outs.

I loved Cait's first book. But this one didn't have much of a take away for me. I found it repetitive and vague. It's too bad because Cait has had such an interesting life. I wish she had've shared more about herself in this book.

So many tidbit of wisdom about the paths in life we've taken and yet to have taken. It's an inspiratonal account of how one might broach the topic of changing one's own life, someone one step at a time, other times with a leap.

The Dead Are Arising is the collaborative effort of Les Payne and his daughter Tamara. For the heralded columnist this is his opus, a thirty year labor of love. For Tamara Payne it is a testament to her father as much as it is to Malcolm.

This is great companion reading to the Autobiography of Malcolm X. It parses through Malcolm's life using interviews with his siblings as well as many people who knew him personally in order to flesh out a full version of his life. It gives you a better idea of who Malcolm was in all of the major phases of his life. Ohhh maaan! Riveting! May very well be the best book ever written about Malcolm x. Mor to come.

The first is the story of Louise Little standing on the porch of her Omaha home, confronting the Klansmen who came to threaten, if not murder, her husband ‚Äî who was in Milwaukee at the time. Surrounded by her three children, the eight-months pregnant Louise faced down the Klansmen. A month later, she gave birth to her fourth child: Malcolm.

I appreciated how this book really expands on The Autobiography of Malcolm X and how it differentiates the incidents and people in Autobiography from the more detailed reality of what actually happened. What a fascinating and powerful individual, filled w/ contradictions, and in the end, great promise. Years ago, I read the Autobiography. A worthy biography about an amazing American.
My 4th X bio. This and the marable could not be more different, but both are necessary.

In any history of the previous century and its racial unrest, Malcolm X must play a prominent role. From a hustler to a prophet, from a spokesman to an apostate, from a victim to a martyr, Malcolm embodied so many contradictory roles and phases that it's sobering to realize that he died on the cusp of his fortieth year (much like his contemporary and supposed rival for the hearts and minds of Black people, Martin Luther King, Jr.). As I mentioned in one of my status updates while reading, Les Payne throughly summarizes Malcolm X's childhood in the Midwest and then speeds through his young adulthood in Boston and New York until Malcolm converts in prison and joins the Nation of Islam. That is mostly the reason why I subtracted a star from my rating.

A very even handed look at a very intersting life. I was 13 when Malcom X died and he was a figure that was difficult for white Americans to understand and certain difficuot to embrace. This terrific biography explains how he arrived at being a black activist after a very difficuot childhood laced with discrimination and violence. This was a complicated man, not all good, and certainly not all bad.

The premier and seminal biography of American hero Malcolm X. This biography has the depth, breadth, and sensitivity of a classic. Finally, a biography that contextualizes events of Malcolm's life, 'connects the dots' for nonhistorian readers, and examines the personality of Malcolm without sweeping his faith under the rug. Throw out all your other biographies of Malcolm.

i only read through when he went on the hajj as I just cant bear what leads up to the assassination. His assassination is so depressing to me

Terrific, insightful book. Especially strong on his family, the death of his father, and early years in Boston. The chapters on his meeting with the Klan, at Elijah Mohammed's behest, and his execution were excellent. A balanced, informed, and interesting read. The focus on his youth and early criminal years is especially welcome as new material is uncovered and investigated in some detail.

Enjoyed Marable's biography more but the details given about Malcom X's early life and his assassination are unparalleled and obvious that this is the most thorough recounting of both ends of his life.
SM
Several years ago I realized I knew very little about Malcolm X - this well written, well researched biography proved to be an excellent introduction. Highly recommend.
Astonishing!! Many new findings
MALCOLM X WHAT AWESOME MAN LOVE YOU MY KING.
A remarkable biography, beautifully written and based on exciting new source material.
After reading this book, it feels like in some ways, I know less about Malcolm X than when I started.

The defining difference between this biography of Cary Grant and any other biographical documentary I have seen (I have never attempted to read a book version for a variety of reasons), seems to be Scott Eyman's aim. Clear from the very beginning, and remaining so with every page turned, Eyman lacks any sort of devious agenda ‚Äî gossipy or pointed ‚Äî other than forming an accurate-as-possible, incredibly detailed account of Cary Grant's life and work, mainly where those two intersect.

Cary Grant is one of my all time favorite actors so I jumped at the opportunity when I saw Cary Grant: A Brilliant Disguise by Scott Eyman pop up on NetGalley. Luckily, I managed to get approved and now that I've read it I can say this is officially one of my favorite biographies of a classic Hollywood actor. I knew some about Grant's life and work going in, but this book presented quite a bit of totally new to me and fascinating

This book opens with a moving description of the last day of Cary Grant's life. Unfortunately, it is a downhill slog from there. The author does a good job of describing how Archie Leach transforms into Cary Grant, but many parts of the book tend to be tedious and repetitive. It could have been a much shorter biography and captured all of the salient points of the book. I only recommend this book to die hard Cary Grant fans. Others will most likely stop reading or skim to find the good parts.

Cary Grant is still my favorite actor ever, but after reading this biography I wonder if he would have been someone I would have wanted to actually meet. Eyman is very candid about Grant's shortcomings and character flaws, but balances this by delving into why Grant had some personal issues (like his many divorces, with more than one ex claiming he was just an awful person to be married to). Eyman's hypothesis is in the title of the book itself-"A Brilliant Disguise": he argues that "Cary Grant"

Excellent biography that details Cary Grant's difficult childhood, early days in an acrobatic dance troupe, his stellar film career, five marriages and life in retirement. As the title implies, Cary Grant was a fabrication created by Archie Leach and that persona was one that he carried over into his private life, at least when he was interacting with others. In private, he was haunted by feelings of guilt toward his parents and he struggled to maintain relationships with women.

I have had very few heroes In my life; I have even fewer heroes emerging out of Hollywood. One of those very few is (was) Cary Grant. Scott Eyman has written a terrific biography not only about Cary Grant But also Grant‚Äôs alter ego, Archie Leach. He explores at length the trauma of a tough childhood as well as the opulent lifestyle of a mega-wealthy s

A wonderfully thoughtful book about Cary Grant that shows how human he was, his fears, his strength and what he cared about. Scott Eyman has written the definitive biography of Cary Grant. Even more fascinating, he has done this with the elegance and grace that befits the unforgettable Mr. Grant. There is no one today who could replace this actor AND the man. Hollywood doesn't exactly remind one of dignity and class in any age particularly this modern age. But it is wonderful to remember that there was a time in which a Cary Grant reigned. Mr. Eyman avoided the ugly and corrected the misperception

Thanks to Simon and Schuster as well as Netgalley for this advanced copy of Cary Grant a biography. Cary Grant is my favorite actors, so I was thrilled to see a book written about him. There were some things I learned about Mr. Grant that I didn't know before but wasn't too surprised to find out. Besides a few escapades he was a.very kind person. This was a very detailed book that was very well researched. Every movie he made was talked about and what was going on in his life during that time. I

Fascinating reading. I had little idea about Grant's early history and his comedy background. More than just a very handsome face, he was extremely clever about pursuing his ambitions. He rarely took no for an answer and when faced with obstacles, he made a different plan. Oddly, I found his personality a bit unlikeable. The book is chock full of facts and dates and great Hollywood stories. Very well-researched, with a smooth narrative style that's only occasionally a bit dry. An enjoyable weeke

'Cary Grant' by Scott Eyman is a well done & informative biography. To be honest, the only thing i knew about cary Grant prior to reading this was that he is a huge legend. I haven't actually seen any of his movies. However, i love reading about the personal lives of stars so this book was very interesting to me. I found his unusual childhood intriguing and sad. My favorite parts of the books were the inside looks at his marriages.

I've always loved Cary Grant which my mother thought was funny since she saw one of his movies the night before I was born! He is the epitome of a movie star!! This biography seems to be very well researched and provides a balanced account of the man Cary Grant was. Was he perfect? No, of course not. Is anyone? Learning some less admirable facts about him does nothing to diminish my admiration for him as an actor and a true movie star - something in short supply in todays world!!

After you finish this book you'll want to watch a few of Grants movies. What an interesting and tortured soul - stingy with money yet generous of heart. The book held my interest from start to finish.
5 Stars. A must-have for any classic film lover. Eyman approaches his subject with care, compassion and just the right amount of critique. Recommended!

A little dry, but oh my goodness so filled with stories about Cary and his friends. Don‚Äôt read with a deadline. But do read it.

--Her sister committed suicide.
--Her marriage ended (she now lives in Denver, he now lives in Seattle).
--She had a cancer scare.
--She required major surgery.
--She has redirected her efforts into public speaking and abandoned her blog.
--This book has been canceled by the publisher.

So...DANG.

OMGGGG IT FINALLY HAS A RELEASE DATE YAAAAAASS

2020 BITCHES

Not gonna lie, the first book made me feel really, really seen during a period of depression, so I am super super excited for this follow-up because I want to be SEEN again :D

I want a copy of this so badly T_T
I would wait a thousand years for this book because I know it'll be great, take your time Allie Brosh <3

After seven years of waiting, I finally read it.

It was worth the wait y‚Äôall.

‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî-

Something good is finally happening in 2020!

Seriously though, Hyperbole and a Half: Unfortunate Situations, Flawed Coping Mechanisms, Mayhem, and Other Things That Happened, and especially "all my fish are dead" literally changed my life.

------------------------

Amazon just emailed me. There is no longer an expected release date.

In happier news, here's a corgi butt.

This was worth the wait (~5 years!, not complaining, you just need to know how much of a wait it's worth) - and I'm so, so happy that finally there is something that 2020 cannot ruin. Tempting fate? Maybe. Sorry Allie Brosh. But at the very bare minimum I can't be forced in any way to un-read this book.

As per usual with Allie Brosh and the mix of drawn and written storytelling that makes up her previous book and blog Hyperbole and a Half, there are pieces of this that are actual-laugh-out-loud f

When considering what to write in this review, I had a lot of thoughts floating around in my head akin to, ‚Äúa book doesn‚Äôt HAVE to funny to be good, you just made a pre-assumption the author is funny,‚Äù ‚Äúit‚Äôs not up to you to decide how someone gets to describe their experiences,‚Äù etc. Which are both true. But they also obscured the fact that, at the end of the day, I didn‚Äôt enjoy Solutions and Other Problems very much.

I wanted to. Oh, how I wanted to. Like every other person and their mother on

I had this long conversation with a friend of mine today about the need we all seem to have for answers. We call it different things but it all sort of boils down to this weird, innate need to understand what in the hell we're meant to be doing here. We, as a species, really can't seem to bear the idea that there isn't some grand plan in place that would explain the casual suffering, the loneliness, the soul destroying pain we all suffer through. We do not under any circumstances want to confron

This is finally ACTUALLY happening. I've been waiting so damn long for this and I'm so emotional right now. Allie Brosh is literally a huge part of why I'm still on this planet today. If you'll all excuse me, I'm going to go sob for a while. üò≠üíñ

I hope you will allow me to tell a little story here. Some years back, I was going through a bad time with my mental health. It‚Äôs been, what feels like a lifelong struggle, but this was a particularly rough period. I had been in the hospital and was then moved to a sort of group home to recover more. One of the counselors there had two stories by Allie Brosh printed out and we read them as part of a group activity. They were about depression and were real and sad and funny.

I felt seen. Like som

I really hate to say this (and I see I'm going to be in the overwhelming minority here) but I didn't care for this book nearly as much as the first one. I got halfway through before realizing most of the stories felt "meh". Made it 3/4ths of the way through before putting it down yesterday. And I honestly had no interest in finishing it but did for the sake of review.

Every. Single. Story in the first book is either hilarious or sad & hilarious. Most of the stories in this one are "okay" and for
I want this ALOT.

This book arrived at my doorstep and I almost couldn‚Äôt believe it. It‚Äôs real? Like, for real real? Because, like other lovers of the hilarious graphic memoir ‚ÄúHyperbole and a Half,‚Äù I had abandoned any hope of a sophmore book years ago. But then I discovered ‚ÄúSolutions and Other Problems‚Äù the day before publication and 24 hours later was chuckling along once again with Allie Brosh, in awe that this moment had come. I‚Äôd forgotten how much I‚Äôd missed her work.

Check out my review on booktube: https://youtu.be/Ni5Ew74Hknk

She has leaned into it. All of it. I have been on an existential journey.

I read this whole thing last night after I got home from work. My one complaint about it that I have right now is that hardcover is the wrong format for this book. My wrists hurt! It's so heavy! I mean, it's a beautiful book, but at points genuinely physically hard to read. I imagine if I had some sort of tablet or color Kindle that would be ideal. If you have arthritis or other hand/arm related mobility issues I feel this

I love this book, and I love Allie Brosh. That is a little concerning because I think she may be the tiniest bit insane, but I not only understand her, I think she's hilarious. Her strange little drawings show me more that a museum full of great art.
I hope it doesn't take another seven years before we see her next book, but I can wait. She's not only a little bit insane, she's also brilliant.

I was so surprised by how enormous this book is by comparison to Allie Brosh's first book. My daughter had preordered it, and while I knew it was coming out soon, I hadn't paid any more attention to it than that. It's beautiful, and worth the price.

I found this more poignant than funny, which is also something I didn't expect. Brosh has been through a lot in the seven years since Hyperbole and a Half was released, and those things have naturally left their mark. So there's a lot of introspection

OMFG I JUST REALIZED THIS FINALLY HAS A RELEASE DATE & I HAVE TEARS IN MY EYES! SO PROUD OF BROSH! I know how it feels to suffer from debilitating anxiety & depression and of her struggles in finish this book because of it & life getting in the way in the worst ways... AND I‚ÄôM SO SO SO HAPPY FOR HER! and for me! Because it comes out THIS MONTH! WOOOO!
GIMME, GIMME, GIMMIE, GIMMIE!!!! I JUST CAN'T FREAKING WAIT!!!!

I read Hyperbole and a Half at a time when I didn‚Äôt know I was depressed, but I found the comics ~relatable~ and funny. Now, I am fully aware, and Allie Brosh has crushed my heart to pieces again.

Solutions and Other Problems is so potent. It is, at times, the view inside my own brain. But also not. Brosh had a lot of terrible life experiences in the years between her first book and this one, out in September. She lays it all bare, alongside some fun comics about being a weird kid and having

I've been waiting for this book for so long, and I don't think it could have come at a more perfect (or needed) time. Allie Brosh opened my eyes with Hyperbole and a Half: Unfortunate Situations, Flawed Coping Mechanisms, Mayhem, and Other Things That Happened so many years ago, and while this tome is definitely tinged with more darkness, it a worthy successor.

Now that I'm a mother to two of my own impetuous children who, while not probably quite on the "Richard" level of creepy, definitely give

I think it's safe to say a lot has happened to Allie Brosh in the seven years everyone I know spent going, "Man, I just hope Allie Brosh is doing well, wherever she is." And this book really peels back the layers on that -- there are funny chapters and heartrending chapters and chapters that talk about truly awful things in small, simple sentences that sit there in your head like a rock.

Basically, this book is a testament to the power of keeping on, even when things are awful, and also on being

Absolutely worth the wait, and everyone's going to connect with a different story here. Favorites of mine that had me cackling included "Cat," "Richard," "Bananas," and "Loving Kindness." There is, in the middle of the book, the big "what happened to Allie in the last 7 years," which some of us who are periodic Googlers of her to make sure she's been okay know, but for many others, it'll be clear why she completely disappeared.

I loved this and I loved laughing, but I will say the unpopular thing

I feel bad giving this graphic novel such a low rating, especially when considering all the author went through since she published her first book, some of the traumatic events detailed in this one. I liked her first book very much as it achieved a fine balance between sadness and lightheartedness that seems to be lacking in this current book. For the most part, this book was a downer, even when the author was relating stories that were supposed to be funny. Not much of it was humorous to me, an

The long-awaited follow up to "Hyperbole and a Half" is at times funny, at times heartbreaking, and at times muddled. I think if you are looking for a "spiritual sequel" to Hyperbole and a Half or a book with the same well-cultivated, insightful humor and insight on childhood, adulthood and even serious topics like depression, you may be disappointed.

Considering the events in the author's private life which occurred in between the book's initial conception and the final release date, it is not s

I suspect many people will say this book isn't coherent or that it's a little bit all over the place, and that may be true but it is also exactly what the book intends to be. The whole point here is for Brosh to throw some not-entirely-coherent feelings at us and she makes that quite clear up front. Wanting something focused and clear isn't really in keeping with a book that is about how everything is actually terrible and random and now what do we do once we realize that?

If you have wondering w

Five years ago, I was given a pre-order of this for my birthday, because of course I was looking forward to another Brosh book like anything. I am sorry that life got so very much in the author's way, although I think we're all painfully aware of how that can happen. If just about the only good thing to come out of 2020 is the new releases, still that's a lot of good.
I am eager to dive in, but I am waiting until Saturday morning when I can look forward to lots of reading time unimpeded by work

After a seven year absence, Allie Brosh returns with a whopping 500 pages of illustrated essays that range from hysterical to heartbreaking.

Brosh made a name for herself with Hyperbole and a Half, her website-turned-book of autobiographical essays/comics. Not only were the essays funny and occasionally poignant, but their MSPaint illustrations added a layer of fun to them.

Solutions and Other Problems is the follow-up fans have been waiting for. None of the humor has been lost(her pets are still

I read Hyperbole and a Half when it was a blog and bought the first book gleefully when it came out. I reread several stories so many times (The Year Kenny Loggins Ruined Christmas and The Scariest Story were my favorites) for various reasons related to my own childhood, I guess. I didn't preorder this one when it was first announced, but I do remember seeing the release date stretch on and on, and I remember how sad I was. I googled "what happened to allie brosh" more than once since she disapp

Looks like I'm the dissenter on this one.

Hyperbole and a Half was, by turns, poignant, clever, insightful, and gut-bustingly funny. Some of the best sections involved the author discussing her battle with depression. While painful to read, there was a stunning clarity to the work. Through anecdotes and analogies, Brosh painted a comprehensible picture of a land which, thank God, I've never had to visit.

It's fairly clear, from the content of Solutions and Other Problems, that Brosh's life has tak

I tried I tried I tried to pace out the reading of this, to savor it, but two days was the best I could do.

However, that's okay. There's so much here that I know I will be revisiting. Some chapters are so funny I was nearly crying. Others are so sad that I'm still sitting with the weight of them. Brosh writes about death, isolation, loneliness, pointlessness. This is, somehow, a very 2020 book, despite being seven years in the making.

I said in my review for a 2019 reread of Hyperbole and a Half
*pterodactyl screeching*

30% the funniest things I have read in years, 70% absolutely devastating emotional stuff, I feel like I‚Äôve been blended.

Note that it goes pretty hard into grief (death of a sibling), nihilism, references to divorce and serious chronic illness. The author is very clearly writing out of being super depressed and having some seriously bad things happen, and while I found most of that extremely relatable it might be more depressing for you.

Pictures definitely worth a thousand words and there are 1

I've missed Allie Brosh so much, but it's now understandable why we had to wait so long to hear from her again. Just like Hyperbole and a Half, this collection is full of stories that had me laughing out loud only to be suddenly hit over the head with emotion and gut wrenching feelings of identification. She has a way of describing feelings in a way that drill right to the heart. I told myself I would read a chapter or two a day to savor this, but I think I secretly knew I would read it all in o

GASP!
NEED THIS NOW!

3.5 stars

Who has not seen the comics/stories by Allie Brosh? Case in point:

I was a follower of her blog, which is also the title of her first book (Hyperbole and a Half) and loved her work. But then she practically disappeared right when her book became a best seller. It was strange and worrying. This second book explains a lot about why she seemingly fell off the face of the earth for years, and well, it's not a humorous story unfortunately for her. And it's also a little unfortunate for the re
Her last book was one one my absolute favorites. Can't wait for this one.
I finished and immediately wanted to read it again. I probably will. I don‚Äôt know how to put into words how this made me feel. But I do know that I loved it.
I MISSED ALLIE SO MUCH. I‚Äôm so glad she‚Äôs okay.

If you find this relatable, then welcome to the club. We‚Äôre all fucking weird. Brosh‚Äôs illustrations are so delightfully awkward ... and grasshopper-like? ü§î They make me giggle. Love her writing style, too. This really heavy doorstopper of a graphic memoir was everything I wanted/needed it to be. It for real hurt my wrists, though. Damn.

(Updated August 26, 2016) I am well aware and understand the situation but it got pushed backed for another year (Now September 7, 2017) :'( Still, stay strong, Allie Brosh!

(Updated May 27, 2016) Oh dear... So that's why this book was pushed back. Her sister died :'( My condolences to Allie Brosh and her family. You take all the time you need.

(Updated October 26, 2015) THE RELEASE DATE IS PUSHED BACK BY ONE YEAR (Now set at October 25, 2016) :'(((

Update: 5 years later and I THINK THIS IS REALLY HAPPENING!!!???!!

I HAD NO IDEA A SECOND BOOK WAS HAPPENING annnnnd THERE'S A LIZARD ON THE COVER!??

Back in 2013, Allie Brosh published Hyperbole and a Half: Unfortunate Situations, Flawed Coping Mechanisms, Mayhem, and Other Things That Happened named after the blog she kept (and has finally updated with a new post!). I pre-ordered the last book and bought it as a Christmas present for pretty much every single person my husband and I knew that year (now our own copy seems to have mysteriously gone missing - which distresses me). Allie's blog (we are clearly on first-name basis, and would be g

As a huge fan of Hyperbole and a Half, I had to read this and love it. I just love Brosh‚Äôs unassuming sense of humor and hilarious drawings. The reflection of her weird labyrinthine mind on the pages, her fun childhood memories, unique visualization skills and imagination create yet another fascinating book. However, if I hadn‚Äôt read the previous book and thought of this as a standalone, maybe I would have liked it better but I know the author‚Äôs potential and what she‚Äôs capable of and that‚Äôs why

I loved Hyperbole and a Half, but this follow-up stumbled too much for me.

I enjoyed the first 150 pages pretty well despite a long and useless (day)dream sequence, but then the blocks of teeny-tiny typeset text started multiplying in frequency and size during a nothing story about cross-country skiing and arguments. More and more little words saying nothing much of anything. And then I started gritting my teeth every time those blocks came back throughout the rest of the books.

After the touching

I kept trying to walk away from this book because I wanted it to last.

I want(ed) more of a 514 page book.

You know the Leonard Cohen quote about a crack in everything?

This book is the crack in 2020 that will have lifted me enough to keep me going.

That is all.
weird, wholesome, and SO funny. allie brosh is doin it like no one else.
Allie Brosh's brain is fascinating. (Also, it really sounds like she's had a shitty past few years.) I'm going to be thinking about the Bananas chapter for a very long time.

upon learning of this new book:






SO EXCITED!
It's being published! <3

Another funny book!

Solutions and Other Problems by Allie Brosh is so terrific! I loved the first book and this one is just as good! Laugh out loud funny in spots to deep heart warming in others. Loved the clever and hilarious cartoons graphics! The cartoons alone are quite a hoot!

Solutions and Other Problems, Allie Brosh‚Äôs follow-up to her critically acclaimed first book, Hyperbole and a Half, had a lot to live up to.  Like many people, I‚Äôve been waiting for this book for years.  The book had been plagued with delays leaving her readers believing that the book may never actually see the light of day.

Then, out of nowhere, the book was scheduled for release in September of 2020.  Finally!  Something good in this horror show of a year.  However, as the content of the book s

This book is for the goofy blob people we were ten years ago who are now facing or have already faced really hard things.

I think many longtime fans of Brosh knew that the reasons for the book's delay and anticipated some of its content being different as a result, and like many, I'm just so grateful that it exists, and that Allie exists with us still. This book is different from the first -- less "adulting! i am the god of cake!" and more "mortality and loss and complex human loneliness o no" --

I laughed, I cried, and I felt very seen by this book. At the end of the day, Brosh is a master at communicating the sheer absurdity of life. She captures the way things can feel pointless, meaningless, and unfair even as we have to continue moving forward.

ebook

Harder to love than the first one. An intimate look at a gal who has had more than her share of trouble coping with the way her brain works. In some ways, I'm sure we can all relate, and in other ways, I'm sure we all say "thank goodness I'm not that confused/ disturbed/ ill."

But it's not exploitive or anything, not a daytime talk show confessional. It's glorious, heartbreaking, gorgeous, funny, and incredibly illuminating.

I feel as if I know myself and my loved ones better now, even those

Ooooh, Book Depository have a release date for later this year! https://www.bookdepository.com/Soluti...

I hope this one sticks, I can't believe I added this back in 2015.

*sigh*
One day maybe.
Hopefully before the current publication date on book depository (Publication date 31 Dec 2050)
Right?

ALERT!!!! ALERT!!!! NEW RELEASE DATE!!!
SEPTEMBER 22, COULD THIS BE IT????

I have never laughed so hard while being told repeatedly that life is meaningless and terrifying. Allie Brosh is a treasure and I hope she gets everything she wants. I'm not sure if I'm supposed to identify with Squirrel, the cat in an obsessive relationship with a mouse friend who is actually made of cloth, but I did. Hard. Also, it turns out if you are extraordinarily imaginative and perhaps prone to obsessive thoughts, as Brosh may be, a simple lovingkindness meditation can really spiral out

One of my favorite reads of 2020. Poignant, hilarious, tragic, and above all, extremely brave. Brosh gives you glimpses into her life since she all but disappeared years ago. She tells some, giving stunning glimpses, but she holds so much back. And that's a wonder. You can feel like you are inside her mind, but her privacy and reclusive nature keep you at arm's length. It's intimate and mysterious. But most of the chapters made me laugh out loud at least once, while one story had me laughing so

This book while not as tremendously funny as Hyperbole and a Half, it was excellent.

There's a lot of feeling in this book, I laughed and cried. I can't imagine living through everything she lived through, and still come out on the other side.

I would still highly recommend this book to people who enjoyed her first book.
Hilarious in spots, but mostly heartbreaking all the way through.

Allie Brosh is one of the only people who can write a book and make me laugh out loud. I‚Äôm so glad that she was able to finish this despite going through the worst period of her life. It's full of both sad and hilarious stories, but my favorites were the hangry banana fight and pile dog.

I got this in the mail when I was about 15 pages from finishing another 400 page book. I decided I‚Äôd just take a peek and I read almost half of this in one sitting. I highly recommend picking this up if you‚Äôre go

I have waited so long for new content from Allie Brosh and I am most happy that she is still here and still writing. However, I felt a lot of these stories felt like they would just stop at the end of a chapter right when I was getting fully invested in where that tale was going. But I definitely laughed and got choked up while reading and so it was still time well spent. Poop Mystery alone!
I read this in one sitting. It‚Äôs fantastic.
So funny it had me laughing out loud and also so, so dark, this is a weird little book and I would expect nothing less from Allie Brosh.
YESSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSS

"Having to be personally responsible for justice in the world is distressing. It makes it seem like maybe there's something wrong in the Universal Fairness and Balance Department. Like maybe the higher-ups have lost control and they need help." I haven't read anything more timely since the pandemic began, or more "me," for that matter. Allie Brosh's drawings and perspectives just click for me. I laughed until I wept at Hyperbole and a Half, and was so sad when there was no more blog or books for

Okay, so stay with me here:

I was thinking, while reading this book, that I wished that one, and only one thing about The Hunger Games could be real.
None of the actual games part, no competition, no death, no murder, none of basically anything, EXCEPT....

Imagine if you could send the authors and other artists that you loved those little parachute balloon thingys with exactly the thing that they needed.
As much as reading something as brutally honest as Allie Brosh‚Äôs first book makes you feel like

Allie Brosh makes me feel seen. Her work is definitely something that anyone can appreciate and enjoy, but she writes about depression and anxiety (without always naming them as such) in a way that feels like home. Someone else out there gets how it's both simple and complex, crushing and absurd. Also, "The Poop Mystery" is the funniest thing I've read in a long time.

Side note: Brosh writes in her acknowledgments about a woman who received the uncorrected manuscript of this book in the mail by

I‚Äôm so glad another Allie Brosh book is in the world! I laughed so hard I cried at many of these stories, and I forced my coworkers to read or listen to me read them. She‚Äôs at her funniest when she‚Äôs writing about her childhood or writing about animals. I love the kooky sentence structure she uses as she imagines what they‚Äôre thinking.

There‚Äôs been a lot of sadness in Brosh‚Äôs life in the years since her last book came out. She writes about that too, so not all the chapters are a laugh riot. The

It's a semi long story, but I got up at 4am to get this book and read it before it's actual release. I'm dog tired (whatever that means) and it was worth every moment of sleep deprivation.

Allie (much like Tina Belcher) is my spirit animal. We speak the same language. The language of, lets discuss this deep topic and also farts. I read her first book during a bout (if you call roughly 2 years a 'bout') of depression and it brought me joy. I read her words now, at my most joyous and it still does

This is much more melancholy than the first book (for very understandable reasons), which means that it wasn't quite as funny. (Although I did laugh out loud in many places.) Mostly I'm giving this a four rather than a five because a lot of the chapters end very abruptly, almost as if they've cut off rather than come to a natural ending point. That did grate on me after a (very short) while, and ultimately curtailed my enjoyment of the book.

"I am a tragic, greedy animal with too many dreams to feel satisfied by reality. I want to know what everything cool feels like. I want to ride dragons into battle. I want to be important. I want to know what it would be like if everybody believed in me."
It‚Äôs my first time reading anything by Allie Brosh and everyone seems to love her humor but I‚Äôm... kind of bored?
I laughed. I cried. I am grateful for this book.

I think I pre-ordered this in 2014, and it was worth the wait.

I also hope Allie Brosh is doing okay.
This is a wonderful book and I love it. You should buy it and read it too. After such a long time since the previous book, my expectations were unfairly high, and I still thoroughly enjoyed this.
Hilarious and devastating.
*chef's kiss*
Worth every minute of the wait!
No real surprise that this was exactly the hilarious, heartwarming, relatable, and emotional storytelling style that is uniquely Allie Brosh.

Me last night like it's so hard to be friends w urself but i think it's the Key. Me this morning reading Allie Brosh's step by step plan on how to be friends with yourself like oh my god she KNOWS.

Also I like how she draws animals. She captures their Essence.
It takes a lot to make me actually physically laugh. I am a stoic muhfucker. But Allie Brosh cracks my tough exterior and makes me feel like a human with actual emotions.
Definitely worth the wait. Still funny, but this time it‚Äôs also sad?

I love Allie Brosh. Her artistic style, her sense of humor, the way she opens her heart to her readers. Reading this book was like bouncing around inside a crazy person‚Äôs head...in the best way. If I‚Äôm totally honest, though, I didn‚Äôt like Solutions and Other Problems as much as I liked Hyperbole and a Half. There were a couple of stories that lost me...that I didn‚Äôt quite connect with. But there were plenty of other stories where I loved every word. Because this is a book of impressive size. I‚Äô

I'd first like to express my infinite gratitude to meera for informing me that this book was going to be released, thus giving me the biggest boost of serotonin I've had in over six months. I think allie brosh is a genius and it's very comforting to know that we're both little absurdist creatures experiencing life and fucking shit up. I owe a significant part of my life and my lived experiences to allie and the $30+ I spent on this signed edition was absolutely worth it. highly highly recommend
I‚Äôm just so happy to be reading anything new from Allie Brosh.

Allie managed to write something hilarious and sad at the same time
Worth the wait.
A thousand stars. I've already purchased 5 copies and will likely start handing more out on street corners. Well worth the wait, keep 'em coming Allie!

In comparison to Hyperbole and a Half, it's much sadder, but without that initial gut punch. And there's a good number of silly animal stories, but I was really expecting myself to chuckle more than once throughout the whole (massive) book.

As a side note, we are now far enough into quarantine that book layouts can be designed around it. I'm looking at you, Chapter 25.

I HATE IT.

I have never returned a kindle book I purchased so fast before.

I loved her last book and read her ‚Äúcomic‚Äù for years. I also lauded her for writing so honestly and accurately about depression.

This book üôÖüèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è it‚Äôs an awful, boring memoir with some added illustrations‚Äîand it has that super annoying ‚Äúblogger writes self help book‚Äù feel üëé only to be followed by a depressive spiral. I‚Äôm sad for Allie.

It‚Äôs not the poignant, funny, insightful book I expected.

Allie Brosh is truly original. I've never read anything quite like her writing, and her art is incredibly evocative, strange, and hilarious. Although there were parts of this book I didn't care for, there were other aspects so brilliant and unique, I'm sure they'll stay with me for years. It's important to know going in that there are heartbreaking sections of this book. Allie Brosh has had some really difficult stuff to deal with in the past few years. But she's channeled it into this book, whi

I laughed so hard I set off my asthma!
My only critique is that the hardcover is almost three pounds, so maybe get the ebook if you don't want to injure yourself when you inevitably drop it on your face like I did.

Full review coming for Shelf Awareness.
But oh man, this made me laugh till I cried, and also made me cry. Allie Brosh has a gift!

GUYS GUYS GUYS GUYS GUYS OH MY GOD
IT'S FINALLY (MAYBE????) COMING????????
SEPTEMBER 22. A NEW COVER. 528 PAGES. I'M HYPERVENTILATINGGGGGGG

https://www.simonandschuster.com/book...

I really, really wanted to like this. I tried very hard. I‚Äôm deeply disappointed that unacceptable slurs like ‚Äútard‚Äù and ‚Äúgimp‚Äù made it into print in 2020. I thought better of the author than that.

Maybe I‚Äôm missing the point. I‚Äôm sure I am. But it felt disjointed, unorganized, and lacking in the witty sharpness that I‚Äôd remembered from Hyperbole & a Half. I want Allie Brosh to be successful. I want only good things for her because she deserves so, so much credit for making the internet a better

Wow, and I thought her first book was dark. I would say that Hyperbole and a Half was dark in a very introspective self loathing kind of way. Solutions and Other Problems is dark in very grand existential way. I love and can identify with both. It feels deeply satisfying to witness Allie's pessimistic musing expand and mature. It really does reflect the way my own angsty thoughts have developed from utterly self absorbed to the begrudging recognition that the rest of the world is also worth payi
I would just like to make a giant copy of the panel that says ‚ÄúToday‚Äôs theory is: I feel lonely because nobody is as smart as me‚Äù and put it on my wall.

I haven't read a book book in months. Not all summer. Yes, I've been reading a bunch of graphic novels/manga (I have a huge backlog of titles to log here‚Äîand the longer I put them off, the worse it gets), but nothing that's, like, a novel or anything.

All that changed late last week when a friend shared a link to Allie Brosh's blog (hyperboleandahalf, of course) where there was an update about a new book. I started crying.

It's a complicated set of emotions. On the one hand, I don't know author Al

I excitedly pre-ordered this the second I saw a September 2020 release date. I've always loved the Hyperbole and a Half blog, and seeing that this was able to come together after all of this time made me so happy (and hopeful that the author was doing better).

There are very few books that are actual "laugh out loud" types, but this is one of them. My boyfriend was on the other side of the room trying to concentrate on some particularly challenging Magic the Gathering games, and I was shaking wi

Gosh, I adore Allie Brosh.

I have loved her ever since 2010, when I stumbled across her Hyperbole and a Half blog and proceeded to laugh so hard I sounded like I was sobbing over something heartbreaking. Her words brought so many giggles into my world when I was most in need of them, and when she disappeared for several years, I thought of her every so often and hoped she was happy.

Solutions and Other Problems shows us that Allie has had a rough seven years, and my heart goes out to her - and al

I liked a lot of Solutions and Other Problems. Looking back at my review of Hyperbole and a Half, I see that I really didn't enjoy that one. Not sure if it was my head space a year ago when I read that or if this book is that much better but Brosh is a great storyteller and while the style is a bit unexpected compared to the typical graphic novel (large blocks of text!), everything works together somehow. The crude drawings compliment the text really well and make for a quick read and enjoyable

OMG, could it be that 2020 will finally offer something good? That there will be one small ray of hope, one little piece of enjoyment this year? AND, just in time for the inevitable dumpster fire that will be the election? Will I really have something meaningful, poignant, and hilariously touching in my hands to help me get through that?

Well, apparently so. And I guess that all I have to say is this: whatever workings in the universe delayed this book so long, that's ok, I'm not mad at all, bec

Here are the major themes of this book:

-There‚Äôs no underlying purpose to the things that happen to us
-We are powerless, though we trick ourselves into thinking we have some level of control in our lives
-MORTALITY!!!!
-Life is unfair, and that‚Äôs just the way it is

All this nihilism is colored by Brosh‚Äôs trademark wit and humor, but there‚Äôs no denying that this book is significantly darker than her first. And who can blame her? She doesn‚Äôt talk about her trials in huge amounts of depth, but Brosh

Brosh has famously been absent from the internet (at least publicly) since 2013. Solutions and Other Problems chronicles the whys and hows of that, without feeling as though we‚Äôve been given too much access. We do get a view into her life, and more specifically her worldview, and all that‚Äôs changed and evolved since last we saw her. In some ways reading this felt like sitting down with a friend I hadn‚Äôt seen in a long time and just having an in-depth rambly conversation for a few hours to get ca

The existence of this book makes me so happy. The existence of Allie, too.

There are funny chapters, sad chapters, weird chapters, weird funny sad chapters. There's an explanation why Allie disappeared for so long and my immense happiness at her return. So much has happened, decades ago and months ago. It feels like being reunited with your best friend in the world ever (the final chapter talks about Allie's best friend in the world ever), demanding a COMPLETE update on everything, and getting it

The book is like asking a friend how they're doing and they tell you, and it's not good, and you feel so bad for them, but you were really hoping they were doing better and that they'd cheer YOU up, and you realize no, you need to be there for THEM.

If you want to know how Allie Brosh has been doing, this book will tell you. It won't make you laugh much, but it'll make you think, and probably worry.

I have such mixed feelings that I can't rate it. Am I glad I read it? Yes, because I loved "Hyper

Is it totally worth it to wait so long for more from Allie, known for her Hyperbole and a Half?

It certainly is just as batsh*t crazy, if not more so, then her first book.

In this one, she deals with being alone, and I‚Äôm sure that is why it took so long to pull this book out of her. Humor as sort of therapy. Humor in sadness. Even though her drug trip in the countryside is funny, it is also sad. Even though her thoughts about having to make friends with herself, since she was all alone are quite

(c/p from my review on TheStoryGraph) Oh my gosh y'all. I know we've been waiting for this book for a very long time and I know saying "It was worth the wait" is clich√© as all hell but! I am just so happy this book exists in the world. At once both so funny I almost dropped the book a few times and so deep and sad that I cried into its pages. There is so much hope and humor inside these pages. It feels like talking to a friend you haven't seen in awhile but still 100% gets you and you get them.

It's here!

Fans of Hyperbole and a Half have been waiting too long for the newest book, and it was worth the wait. This book is filled with ridiculous tales of Allie Brosh's life, like how she got stuck in a bucket and how she stole her neighbor's cat, all hilariously and horribly illustrated in Paint (which adds to the comedy).

She again deals with more serious subjects throughout, which help explain her long absence from the internet and the delay of this book, like her divorce and loss of her s

I can pretty much copy my review of Hyperbole and a Half: Unfortunate Situations, Flawed Coping Mechanisms, Mayhem, and Other Things That Happened verbatim: "Uneven, but generally amusing and sometimes laugh-out-loud funny." I'm giving this one fewer star due to fewer laugh-out-loud moments and a couple sections that were legitimately disturbing. Still recommended for all fans of the first book.

Hyperbole and a Half is one of my all-time favorite books and for years I've waited for Allie Brosh to write/draw another book, as she went through some very difficult times in her personal life. This is it - hilarious because it's all so true; just as off-kilter as the first; with illustrations that make me howl.

So why not 5 stars? Because I've recently started following her on Facebook and she's posting the story behind the story and what had been charming and innocent is now...well, I can't h

I love Allie Brosh and her humor and her art. I love her fearlessness and willingness to talk about the hard stuff. I wanted Solutions and Other Problems to be as funny as Hyperbole and a Half, but at the end of the day I guess this book is more about what Brosh needed to get on paper.

It would probably have been 5 stars except I couldn‚Äôt handle the format. A hardback? With a real spine? Printed on heavy-ass paper because it‚Äôs an art book? It makes zero sense. I wanted to crack the spine to be a

Hyperbole and a Half is one of my favorite books of all time. I followed the blog before the book came out, and I reread both the blog and the book whenever I need a laugh. Solutions and Other Problems has been on my Goodreads shelves since 2016, and since then, I've checked the blog every couple of months to see if there were any updates.

All this to say, my expectations were WAY too high. I think it might have been literally impossible for this book to meet them. So I was a little bit disappoin

(3.5) There are so many things I like about this book. I would give several chapters 10/5 stars: particularly the ones about Allie's sister, and the little between chapter observations.

If we're talking about reader identification here, there are so. many. good faces and postures and likenesses that I totally identify with across the pages.

I didn't inhale this one like I inhaled hyperbole and a half. There are some essays/chapters/stories that just didn't work for me. But I'm glad she's still w

As many stars as she wants!It was well worth the wait.There is a very helpful q and a on the back page which clarifies everything in the book.All authors should be forced to do the same.She has overcome her depression by giving herself prestigious awards such as...(see back book flap).The introduction was as original as any I have read.So was the entire book.I even enjoyed the acknowledgements.Which rarely happens.I will now wait patiently for her next book.Hurry Allie.

4,5*

No one can do funny & depressing like Allie Brosh. Hyperbole and a Half is one of my favourite books ever and Solutions and Other Problems is another masterpiece. This book feels a bit more grown up and cohesive than Hyperbole, although nothing can top that one for me. I wish nothing but the best for you, Allie!

*Disclaimer* I received this book through a GoodReads giveaway. It's only the second giveaway I have won, but I am certain it will be the best.

I don't have a rating just yet, because I'm only halfway done. I read the first half in a couple of hours, but I have to step away for a bit. Having a dead sister myself, the Dead Sister chapter has destroyed me. I'm going to take several days of deep breaths then pick it back up.

‚Äî‚Äî-

Ok, it‚Äôs been 6 days and I've finished. Allie has always been very open a

I was cracking up during the first half of this book, and really saw more of Allie's struggle through the second half. Working through the death of a loved one is extremely hard, and the struggle with fear really resonated with me. Same with dealing with being alone.

Allie can really cut to the core of weird thoughts and ideas and I think a lot of people can benefit from seeing that on a page.

The only review I can think of is just a series of emojis that are like sobbing, cry-laughing, laughing, heartbroken, heart, hug. I'm not entirely sure I can put into words how this book made me feel. Amused, sad, shocked, confused, bewildered, rolling on the floor laughing, deep introspection - sometimes all at the same moment.

This book really drives home the point that life is absurd. Sometimes it is absurdly silly. Sometimes it is absurdly sad. Always though, it is absurd.

This is a brilliant follow to her first book, and is something I think everyone should read.

4.5? 5 stars?

Review to come, but I will say again that I truly admire how Allie Brosh can write such hilarious stories, quickly followed by such truly personal and devastating ones.

CW: death of a sibling by suicide

I laughed so hard I was wheezing for air at some points, at another I was crying into my scrambled eggs. I had what the absolute heck moments and moments of thank goodness someone else thinks these things too.

My husband keeps asking me why I‚Äôm laughing. I show him a picture and he‚Äôs like ‚Äúwhat?‚Äù I just say ‚Äúit‚Äôs hard to explain‚Äù. And continue laughing out loud.

I‚Äôm glad I‚Äôm not the only one laughing as the weird thing is this book is sad. The honesty is what makes me smile. Thank you, Allie

Okay, the first half of the book wasn‚Äôt as good as Hyperbole and a Half but at least I had a few good laughs and some explanations about the 7 years delay of the new book which is something.

But the second part is really weak and boring. I wanted to like this but it‚Äôs barely interesting and a big disappointment for me. Sorry.
‚ÄúIf I believe something will work, that is very dangerous.‚Äù
This is one of the few good things to come out of 2020. I needed this.

I love (and really respect) Allie Brosh. This is one of those books, same with Hyperbole and a Half: Unfortunate Situations, Flawed Coping Mechanisms, Mayhem, and Other Things That Happened, that I just can‚Äôt not give 5 stars. They give me feels. These are books I will actually laugh out loud reading too.
I want to give Allie a big hug and then take her on a picnic. Some of the chapters were absolutely heartbreaking, some were hilarious, but all were heartfelt and honest.

Solutions and Other Problems by Allie Brosh is her follow-up book to the hilarious Hyperbole and a Half. It‚Äôs full of some of the same hilarious insanity from her first book (and art work) Stories from her childhood and now. There are also some serious words that explain why she disappeared for so long after her first book was published. She talks about her mental health struggles. And the Pile Dog. Lots of pages full of her signature drawings. If you liked the first book, you‚Äôll certainly like

(3.5) Like in her first book, Hyperbole and a Half: Unfortunate Situations, Flawed Coping Mechanisms, Mayhem, and Other Things That Happened, Brosh does amazingly evocative and hilarious things with very simple illustrations--my favorite being animals and herself.

This is a hefty follow-up and while there are many funny and poignant parts, she didn't dive into the biggest events of the past seven years--her sister dying (suicide?) and her divorce--and it felt really disingenuous because she is s
Incredible. I laughed hardest at "Bananas" and "Sister"; the stretch from "Throw and Find" to "Friend" is devastating and kind of hopeful and so, so well done.

Charming and weird

While not as entertaining as her first book, this was still a solid go. Her artwork amuses. Her topics delightfully random. But I could put the book down easily. That's a 4 star for me.
I had been waiting a long time for this to be published and it was well worth the wait, equal parts heartbreaking and hilarious.
I laughed and I cried and I was very sad when it was over.

Take every single expectation you've built up for this 'Hyperbole and a Half' follow up over the past seven years and forget all of them. 'Solutions and Other Problems' exceeds any and all expectations with its stories of powerlessness, loneliness, absurdity, and vulnerability. Yes, this volume does discuss all of the events that Allie Brosh has experienced in the last decade or so (severe bouts of depression, the death of her sister, and a serious cancer scare just to name a few), but does so i

The pile dog was a silly-looking animal. We had to cut eyeholes in her fur so she could see. It made her look way creepier than would be ideal, but you can‚Äôt let your dog be blind just because it looks creepy when you can see its eyes.

This appeared on my Kindle at midnight and I had forgotten about it but then I obviously had to stay up ridiculously late reading the whole thing from front to back. Arthur also had to stay up ridiculously late because I could not. Stop. Laughing.

Oof.

Allie chooses to utilize her impressive artistic talents by drawing in a crude (yet surprisingly effective) style best described as ‚ÄúMS Paint,‚Äù which fools the reader into expecting content reflective the lighthearted style. Her latest book, however, deals with several life crises and philosophical dilemmas, illustrated in MS Paint style. It‚Äôs a bit of an emotional hammer, in between stories about goofy dogs and the weird kid next door.

In short, all those years I spent wondering occasional

I got this as a birthday present from my wonderful sister and devoured it within 24 hours of opening.
It made me explosively laugh-cry, which is a good thing. Allie Brosh is the perfect quarantine companion. We‚Äôve all gone to some weird, dark, and ridiculous places this year. She was there first and made this gift for us.
That Chapter made me a sobbing mess but it's fine

It was definitely an "I laughed, I cried" situation. Not as LOL as David Sedaris or Chelsea Handler. But much more heartfelt. I'm glad I read it. I especially liked the parts about befriending yourself and loneliness.
Amazing and ridiculous and the best amount of weird. I loved almost everything about this book!!

user_name: Mario the lone bookwolf (semi reviewing hiatus )

review_text:
This year -2020 - has turned me into a political junkie: books, TV, Radio, podcasts, and a little social media ....I haven‚Äôt been able to stay away. The ongoing devastations of this year changes people.
So... I read another Trump book.

Bob Woodward‚Äôs, RAGE, is comprehensive, and up-to-date....
....a truthful unfolding on Trump‚Äôs Presidency.
A very honorable book resulting from scrupulous journalistic ultracareful fastidious fact-checking.

The November 3rd election is counting down‚Äî only 46 more

SPOILER ALERT: WORST PRESIDENT EVER

Back when I was a younger man, protesting the invasions of Iraq and Afghanistan, there was no one on Earth I hated more than George W. Bush. These days, I would take him back in a heartbeat, but I guess I'll settle for Biden this fall instead. And I wonder why more Republicans don't agree, because there are ways in which the Obama administration made even Reagan's seem liberal by comparison. I guess it's like Chomsky said, how politics in this country is sort o

I was not going to read this. Not another Trump book. Alas, my friends, I am weak. I won't get too much into the details, because, honestly, the book contains little that would surprise you at this point. What is astonishing, however, is that Trump allowed Woodward to record all the imbecilic, narcissistic things he said in all manner of crises. He made time to chat with a journalist for hours on end to pump up his ego, while a war with Iran was not out of the question, people were protesting ra

Seemed more like ranting then writing. He seems utterly amazed he founded a successful restaurant because of pure luck.

This book is in the vein of ‚Äòeveryone feels they have to write a book‚Äô. It also reads rather impersonally and makes David Chang seem like a jerk. If you‚Äôve never heard of David Chang or his accomplishments, it‚Äôs fine. He will fill you in on everything. Then keep telling more and more. Vulnerable, yes. In depth, maybe not. Chang tells us, but doesn't show us, what his flaws are.

First I would like to state that I have received this book through goodreads giveaway in exchange for an honest review. It's funny how celebrity memoirs are usually fluffy cotton candy bites of anecdotes, while Celebrity Chef memoirs are a litany of traumas. This is no exception, right out the gate we open with stories of what is now somewhat stereotyped Asian parental abuse, followed by mental illness. 4.5 stars. I really like David Chang. That feeling has only intensified since reading this book.

I was first introduced to David Chang through his Netflix show, Ugly Delicious. I watch a lot of food programming and am picky about what I like. Chang's career has been subtly dedicated to subverting the norm and playing up the unexpected. He is a Korean American who make

[4,5/5 stars]

EAT A PEACH by David Chang is an honest and insightful memoir about food and Chang's life.
Starting with his childhood, Chang gives us a glimpse about his struggles regarding otherness and religion, plus his early talent with golf.
From cooking school to complex culinary dishes, there was plenty of immense effort and detailed preparations meticulously described that drew me in. We feel the tenuous balance between real world and kitchen, as it also happens in other areas of life.

I so

Reading experts on food talk about food sort of feels like listening to a really nice song in a different language. It is so pleasant!! My favorite things about it were the emphasis of his writing on process instead of outcome and the credit he gives to his community.

I never knew the descriptions associated with Michelin stars; 'a one-star restaurant as ‚Äúhigh quality cooking, worth a stop.‚Äù Two stars is ‚Äúexcellent cooking, worth a detour.‚Äù And three is ‚Äúexceptional cooking, worth a special jour

Coronavirus (update: Coronavirus + Rebellion 2020) book review #47 ‚Äì 3.75 stars

Eat a Peach is one man‚Äôs battle with depression and anger whose workaholic tendencies to escape himself made him a superstar chef at a fairly young age. That man is David Chang, head of the Momofuku empire, and I want to eat all his food.

Kudos to David for being self-reflective on how harsh he‚Äôs treated himself and the people who have worked with him throughout his rise to stardom and yet, he‚Äôs one of those people wh

Honest and enlightening. David Chang not only deserves our respect, but also our support. He recognizes his past as imperfect, he looks back with a critical eye. How he has moved forward and fallen into the lovely life he has now is nothing short of a miracle to him. The future is bleary and certainly filled with more hurtles, challenges, and self-bettering. This is book that not only shows you the road up to now, but also let‚Äôs you gaze into the horizon with hope. That‚Äôs how it left me feeling,

I expected this book to be a fun, semi-arrogant recap of David Chang‚Äôs adventures with cooking and famous people. This book (and the chef) are so much more complex than that though ‚Äî he talks in detail about his own mental health, his challenging relationship with his father, the biases he has experienced as an Asian American and how he used all that to fuel his restaurants. Parts read like a cheat code for understanding his restaurants, which is cool to get inside his mind. He‚Äôs also super hone

I‚Äôm already a big Dave Chang fan, and have always been interested in the way his brain works, and the questions he brings up. This book was right in line with what I expected, very genuine to him. The way it talks about depression and mental health is truly stunning. It made me miss the experience of eating in restaurants BAD haha. Such an interesting look at paradox, success and making your mark BECAUSE OF your pain (not in spite of it) was something I‚Äôve heard described like this only once or
Brutally honest, deep and thought provoking. I'd probably rate it a 4.5 if I could, was great to have the audiobook narrated by David Chang as well.

I like it when an author reads his own memoir, good or bad, it's his voice. That said, I found this memoir sometimes interesting, sometimes not. I worked in the restaurant industry as a young'un when dinosaurs roamed the earth, and have read several memoirs in this vein (Kitchen Confidential, Service Included, BloodBonesButter). I've never eaten at one of David Chang's restaurants, but have seen him on my teevee and he seemed an interesting personality. I'll bet his food is spectacular. Aaannnyw

A good read for anyone who is interested in the restaurant industry and how the concept of dining out has changed in America over the past ~20yrs. Also a thoughtful discourse on mental health and obsessive compulsive disorder as it pertains to one‚Äôs career
Three Michelin stars.

I picked this up because I enjoyed Chang's philosophy about food. I kept reading because of his unflinching discussion of mental illness. Accessible and easy to read, EAT A PEACH is about running a business, building a team, and being honest to who you are.

notes compiled from a whatsapp convo (hi julia):
