Book Review: Eat A Peach: A Memoir
Author: David Chang; Gabe Ulla
Publisher: Crown Publishing/Clarkson Potter
Publication Date: September 14, 2020
Review Date: April 14, 2020

I received a free copy of this book in exchange for a honest review.

From the blurb:
‚ÄúFrom the chef behind Momofuku and star of Netflix‚Äôs Ugly Delicious‚Äîan intimate account of the making of a chef, the story of the modern restaurant world that he helped shape, and how he discovered that success can be much harder to understand t

David Chang's much-anticipated memoir was pretty good, but not great. I'll preface by saying that I don't know a lot about David Chang. I've seen a few episodes of one of his shows, Ugly Delicious, and I know of his famous noodle bar Momofuku. So I'm definitely not the target audience to read this memoir - it's written with the idea that readers will be familiar with Chang, his multitude of restaurants, his magazine, his attitudes in the kitchen, etc. I had very little prior knowledge of these t

I won an ARC in a Goodreads giveaway; this did not influence my review.

I've been familiar with David Chang for several years, and though I did not know a lot of details about him or his life, I did have a few perceptions of him - particularly as an eminently confident chef and TV personality. The reality, as Eat a Peach shows, is much more complicated. This is not your typical foodie memoir that recounts tales of learning to cook from a mother or grandmother as a small child on the perch of a st

Eat a Peach is an autobiography of David Chang and written with Gabe Ulla. It is the debut memoir from the star chef and restaurateur.

Chang, Momofuku restaurateur and star of Netflix's Ugly Delicious, starts this self-effacing, heart-on-sleeve memoir with a disclaimer about not understanding his appeal. Chang writes about being a hard-driving Korean-American kid with an anger problem who channeled his frustrations into an eagerness to test limits.

He left a soul-sucking post-college finance job a

3.5 stars, rounded up. This was much more self-aware than I would have expected from a ‚Äúcelebrity‚Äù memoir (although to be fair I haven‚Äôt read too much in that genre), and quite dark.

Chang‚Äôs candidness in talking about his struggles with mental illness was an unexpected highlight of the book for me. Any sense of a triumphant arc in his career is tempered by discussion of where his head was at in the given moment, and the impact of his single-mindedness on those around him. It‚Äôs not a feel-good bo

This is more than the memoir of David Chang, chef and founder of the Momofuku restaurants. Written in a very readable, honest, darkly humorous, manner, DC lays bare his mistakes, his battles with mental illness, and his struggles with his success. I also really appreciated the separate list of "33 rules for Becoming a Chef" which also contains many life lessons for us all:

"I've found that the cooks with the brightest prospects are the ones who are hardest on themselves. The trick is to direct th

I first became obsessed with the Momofuku story through milk bar, because who doesn't love birthday cake truffles. Since then I've come to be a big fan of Chang (and Tosi), and was blown away by his vulnerability and transparency in his podcast. (The episode that stands out is the conversation with Steven Yeun on being Asian American...but I digress)

Still a fan of the podcast, I first listened to the episode about the writing of this memoir, where he talks about the writing process, questions wh

This was a solid audiobook. A look into the restaurant industry and excellent for fans of Kitchen Confidential: Adventures in the Culinary Underbelly. One thing that stood out to me was that David Chang does a really good job of not glossing over his shortcomings as a leader, his intense mental illness, Imposter Syndrome, and anger issues. He is wonderfully candid and is very upfront about all the mistakes he has made and continues to make.

There was a brief nod to restaurant roles in #MeToo and

This is a book that I was really looking forward to reading and it did not disappoint me. I know Chef Dave Chang from watching him on the Netflix show, Ugly Delicious as well as his appearances on other food and cooking programs. This book reveals a lot about his life and about the inner workings of a startup restaurant in New York City. From this book I started listening to his podcast, The Dave Chang Show, which is also very eclectic and enlightening on a variety of topics relating to family,

I read this book so quickly. Chang writes about the Asian American, Korean American experience. He is also a celebrity chef. He is a father. He is, in his own way, an intellectual. He is an entertainer with a tv show and a podcast. He is famous. There is no other voice like his and it gives me such joy to read his book, and relate so deeply to parts of it - to relate to parts about being a child of immigrant Asian parents to being a workaholic who identifies too greatly with the act of working.

Excellent! Eat A Peach by David Chang is everything you want in a memoir. It is honest. It is insightful. It is told with humility and humor. Readers looking for a bragfest or gossipy tell-all will not find it here. Instead, readers are given an enthralling and unflinching account of Mr. Chang's struggles with mental illness, what has shaped him, and what drives him to this day. Mr. Chang also includes advice and thirty-three rules to follow if you aspire to become a chef. However, these rules c

If you've heard of David Chang, you probably remember him as the angry, screaming bro chef from his early Momofuku days. But he has really tried to transform himself and he describes his journey in this compelling memoir. He has told some of these stories and discussed his philosophies in his podcast, but this book has so much more. I particularly appreciate how he emphasizes honoring where a particular food or dish comes from culturally. I find Dave to be honest and sincere about his struggles

Four stars might be a little high, but it's a good read by a fascinating guy, looking at how his vision for food became an empire. There's very little gossip and if you're expecting a lot of insight into the food at Momofuku (and elsewhere), there's surprisingly little of that as well. This really is a memoir, a look more at Chang's struggles with depression, anger, working too much, etc. than anything else (although the tips for aspiring chefs afterword should discourage anyone from ever pursui

I‚Äôve always loved David Chang as a food personality and public figure, even though my knowledge of cooking is primordial. Upon reading this memoir, I was skeptical as to whether or not Chang‚Äîsomeone with a restaurant empire and so many accolades under his belt‚Äîcould write a book that was both humble and accessible to readers outside of the cooking world. The best memoirists reveal the universal through what is unknowable to readers, and that is exactly what Chang has done here. In the course of

I would say that I‚Äôve watched all of the Netflix content with David Chang so I expected a funny, light-weight book. I am so glad it‚Äôs so much more than that!

As previous reviewers mention, Chang dives deep into his own demons and talks in-depth about his struggles with mental health. I appreciate that he neither tries to sugar-coat his thoughts nor make excuses or try to gain sympathy from the reader. A lot of his stories hit a personal note with me.

Favorite quote: ‚ÄúMy answer is no, I don‚Äôt think

I loved this book. It's an easy, well written read by a very interesting person. It's packed with behind the scenes details and drama about the food, the shows, his famous chef friends and his family. He's very honest about his struggles with serious mental illness and how that both drove him to succeed while at the same time being responsible for much of the interpersonal conflicts that marks all areas of his life. His instant success and likability as a celebrity chef in contrast to his strugg

To me David Chang presented as such a grounded man with a million cool stories to tell. Underneath, he's a boiling inferno of anger trying to outrun imposter syndrome and mental illness.

I loved Momofoku. I never did get into the original restaurant, though did get to Milk Bar. It was one of those books that give me inspiration to cook. This book, not so much. And I'm not sure what I'm supposed to take away from this book. Maybe more sad that a man who achieved such heights into the culinary wor

This is the most honest memoir I have ever read. The candid nature with which he looks back on his past simply blew me away.

I found myself dog earring pages, and pulling the book out to quote particularly well written parts to my friends. To be clear, I finished this 2 days ago and I've been finding ways to work it into conversations since.

And the last line of the 33 things to be a chef (effectively the last thing written in the book) is simply flawless.

I don't generally like memoirs, which is

I like Dave Chang so was predisposed to be a sympathetic reader but Eat a Peach exceeded my expectations.

Finding redemption for past personal failures requires a clear reckoning and Chang airs his shortcomings without flinching or ignoring the harm to others. He provides a lucid and honest description of his own mental health challenges in a way that hopefully continues the effort to destigmatize them.

Chang also wrestles with the implications of success for someone who has always conceived of

3.5 stars. I really didn't know anything about Chang and I've never eaten at a Momofuku restaurant (though I totally would; now I'm curious). On one hand, Chang sounds like a *raging a-hole*. But he also is someone who has done a lot of therapy and is aware of it and trying to do better. Being a celebrity chef is a totally bonkers life. I thought the most interesting parts of the book (scattered throughout) were about racism, and how it plays into cooking/restaurants/dining. I appreciated his ca

(I received a free copy from Clarkson Potter in exchange for a free and unbiased review!). David Chang's memoir is pretty fascinating- hearing the creative processes behind the creation of the numerous restaurants and concepts under the Momofuku umbrella is pretty wild. Chang is honest about the things that failed and why as well as his successes. It's also honest about his mental health and the role that's played in his career. I didn't realize how far this brand had spread until reading this.

4.5 ‚≠êÔ∏è I love a good memoir. I‚Äôm not sure what made me choose this one since I don‚Äôt follow the author and knew little about him prior to reading it, but something about him being at the top of his career game and still struggling with mental health intrigued me. This book was amazing. I love the ‚Äúafterword‚Äù and the possible scenarios as a result of Covid-19. Glad I rolled the dice with this book.

Not the usual chef autobiography. Though Chang describes a few mouth-watering dishes and describes the trajectory of his culinary career, the bulk of this story is about his life-long struggles with manic-depression. His writing style is conversational and easy to read, but the subject matter is heavy, so I did not want to read this book in one sitting. I appreciated Chang's candor about his angry outbursts and bouts of depression and the effect that his manic depression had on his colleagues, c

To me, a good memoir feels like an in-depth conversation with a friend - the highs, the lows, the faults and the triumphs. David Chang's memoir is successful in all this - it's funny, self-deprecating, proud, shameful and kindhearted. I was only marginally aware of his personality, having only been a fan of cake truffles from Milk Bar and possessing of the Lucky Peach cookbook, but I enjoy his philosophy in the kitchen and look forward to seeing what he comes up with next.

This is slightly different from many of the chef memoirs I have previously read. Along with Chang's perspective of how he got to where he is today, he touches on many social and mental health issues (sometimes, successfully; sometimes, with the truths of being {like us all} a flawed human). The closing with the worst case / best case scenarios for what the world of food (and beyond) will be in 2035 is really an artful summation of it all.

I think I enjoyed this book primarily for the fact that I have worked in commercial kitchens for several years. I appreciate how truthful the experience of working in one (noisy, cruel/abusive staff and managers, internal politics, evolving to stay alive, etc). It is not a profession to make a living on, and he is overt and explicit at every turn in this book. What also makes this good is the fact that it is a different memoir from others in that it reads like an anti-memoir. His brashness throu

I loved every page of this book. His personal life, career, leadership, mental health journey, leadership methods and and approach to cooking are all explored in this book which, unsurprisingly from Chang, makes this book difficult to categorize. I'm sure it's been through 1000 edits but it reads like journal/stream of consciousness. His voice challenges the status-quo and I hope more books like this come from Chang down the road.

This ended up better than I thought it would be. Perhaps because I also suffer from the twin maladies of mental health issues and restaurant ownership. Chang is extremely honest and sincere throughout. He could have gone more into depth, but I think this provides good insight into a complicated man while also being a cautionary tale to anyone foolish enough to want a culinary career.

If for nothing else, this book is worth it for Chang‚Äôs openness and transparency around his mental health and journey with therapy and meds. This was an illuminating look into his mind. I‚Äôm Gen X, and Kitchen Confidential was the chef memoir of my generation. I suspect Chang‚Äôs book is going to be the touchstone for Millennials and Gen Z. It‚Äôs a great fucking book.

Not only is this book an interesting read from a business and entrepreneurial stand point, but it is an honest account of facing your demons and being honest with yourself. It touches on racism and sexism in business in a way that I found insightful and useful as a man in the US business world.

Definitely worth your time.

I love memoirs, and this is definitely a good one. It takes so much bravery to speak on personal struggles with mental illness, and I admire David so much for talking so deeply about it. I also have increased respect for all kinds of chefs and everyone in the restaurant industry. I've never read a memoir even similar to this, and enjoyed it tons.

(#goodreadsgiveaway, though my review is in no shape a reflection of that)

5 Stars

A wonderful autobiography that you won't want to put down. The style of the book is an easy read-as if you are sitting down with David Chang ; learning who David Chang is, his personal growth, as well as the thinking behind his successful restaurants.

Yowzah! The author gives a truly honest portrayal of himself. He's a bit scary, I wouldn't have wanted to work for him, that's for sure. It was a good read although went off into details about the financial and logistical problems of restaurants that kind of bored me. I preferred the parts where he wrote about his personal life. Next time I'm in NYC (if that day ever comes again), I want to try one of his restaurants!

Possibly the best book I read so far this year. I‚Äôve never visited Chang‚Äôs restaurants but Eat A Peach was such a raw, honest homage to food, Asian American heritage, and loneliness. I don‚Äôt usually read food books but I believe that Eat A Peach is truly one of a kind.

Reading this definitely felt like watching a person in the midst of making sense of himself, coming to terms with himself. I am not overly interested in the restaurant business but appreciate the insight his story gave to me, especially as context and illustration for his struggle. That said, his passion is what speaks loudest. You can feel the teeth-gritting, the dust-wiping after repeat falls. So it was kind of a rough read, which i guess is unavoidable given that DC really seemed intent on ba

Chang tells quite the story of working as a chef and opening his own restaurants. I have only been to Milk Bar and I love it! And I have read Lucky Peach a few times. If you like cooking, food, and the life behind the scenes this is a good book!

This was less a great literary work and more a fascinating journey along with someone as they both mature and tackle their own demons. Is it beautiful prose? No but I found it a fabulous memoir and a great ride for anyone who was swept up in in the 2005-2010 food scene. It was also a mini tribute to Anthony Bourdain and a reminder to invest in therapy.

This was a great read. It was nice to see the story of the man behind momofuku. He didn't hold back, he admits to all of his shortcomings, and that fact he can be a complete asshole.

I would never want to work for him, but I do know people that do

It was a good memoir and I hope his restaurants continue to do well. I've never had a bad meal at any of his establishment.
Super good. really enjoyed this one
Love him as a person & as a chef!
Brutally honest, he's openly talking about mental health, racism, about his restaurant business and his relationships with his employees/partners throughout his career.
Memoirs are one of my favorite genres to read. This was a delight and I always enjoy reading about the restaurant industry. Chang is dark, sensitive, and introspective.
3.5 stars
A hauntingly honest read.
I freaking love David Chang and after I read this I have decided to pivot from teaching to becoming a chef.

A brutal and surprisingly relatable memoir. The best sections of this book are gold, although not every section is.

Recommended for folks who love reading about delicious things and also mental illness.
A really honest memoir from David Chang, touching on some tough topics and points in his life. This was a great book and a really excellent audiobook.

I'm not a foodie but I'm surrounded by them and this was the pick for my book club this month. Despite not being a foodie (I'm probably almost at the other end of the spectrum) and being a vegetarian, I find food writing really interesting. I've read a couple of chef memoirs and will probably read more in the future.

This book was a wild ride. It was an eye-opening peek into the world of restaurants in NYC - I should clarify: the bro-ey world of restaurants and chefs. I don't think I quite like D

I give four stars mostly because it is profoundly satisfying to read a good memoir written by someone you really like.

As he preaches in his book, Chang is intent on always molting like a lobster, shedding his skin, changing, and growing. He does this in food, but in this memoir he applies the same approach to his life.

This was exactly what I wanted: not so much a chronicle of his life‚Äôs work with Momofuku ‚Äî though it is that, and it is good ‚Äî but an analysis of Chang‚Äôs driving ethos, his intro

David Chang makes great food. But he sounds like a very challenging boss- and for reasons I can identify with. The part of this book i enjoyed the most was not the description of the food - which is great- but the honest and frank discussion around his mental illness. It is an eye opening read about the challenges with balancing leadership and creativity and meant so health.

I also appreciate the fact that Chang seems to a air ownership of his mistakes and his part in creating a boys club in the

I've enjoyed Ugly Delicious and follow David Chang on Instagram, and I'm glad I checked out this audiobook to get to know more about both his personal and career story. The only part that didn't keep me engaged was in the middle, some of the nitty gritty details of the restaurant biz and some stories involving others in the culinary world (which hey it's his memoir, he's allowed to get into as much detail as he wants...). I read Kitchen Confidential when it came out in 2007 and was surprised by the gorilla warfare chefs engage in in the name of fine dining. I became a Bourdain fan and from there a Top Chef fan, which is ironic since I don't cook. I loved everything about Chang's book, especially his honesty as he battled addiction on two fronts, as an addict and a workaholic. I've attended many AA meetings with my recovering husband and know that recovery is a difficult and often unsuccessful journey. And anyone

What is it like to walk a line as thin as a knife's edge between success and failure? David Chang is an internationally recognized, adored, hated, and envied chef - but he is foremost a quirky Korean American trying to make it in the world outside of stereotypes and without math skills.

I don't often read memoirs but when I do, the perspective in question balances on the spectrum of anti-hero, and served with a huge side of underdog success. David Chang grew up with the unique stresses of Asian i
Dude tries to convince you he doesn‚Äôt take himself too seriously for 300 pages; proceeds to take himself too seriously for 294 pages.

I enjoyed reading this immensely. It took me 3 days to finish. Could not put it down. I'll start by saying that I've always admired David. He started with literally nothing‚Äîno knowledge of how to start a restaurant/business, no background in cooking, and no money‚Äîand yet he redefined everyone's dining experience, acquired Michelin stars, won a James Beard award, and has gone nowhere but up since then. He talks openly about his upbringing, his depression/bipolar disorder, his manic episodes in th

Vivid, electrifying, and close-to-the-bone memoir/manifesto from one of the era's most revolutionary chefs (Momofuku, etc.). Chang manages to be edgy and confrontational while also self-deprecating about his own mistakes and at times unwilling membership in the boys' club of celebrity chefs. Delicious, thoughtful, and exciting.

Listened to this all in one night. I've always liked David Chang, even knowing what an asshole he can be. (It's nice to know that he knows and is working on it.) I've eaten at a handful of his restaurants and loved learning more about him in Mind of a Chef and then again in Ugly Delicious, so this was a natural extension of both of those. It's fast-paced but also reflective. He was a good reader of his own book (sped up, of course).

I had heard about David Chang before reading this book- however my impression of him from Netflix + eating at Momofuku didn't prepare me at all for the David Chang I met reading this memoir.
It is written with such honest clarity, and is highly relatable. On every page, I taste the food he describes, while also having some serious laughs.

I was excited to read this book mostly to learn more about his mental health journey. I've heard him speak honestly about his mental health struggles on his podcast and I was eager to see if he talked more about it. I wasn't as interested in his restaurant success.

Food as entertainment has become big business in the 21st century. Food-based television programming and celebrity chefs are major parts of the culinary landscape, with their importance spiraling upward as each enhances the other. Food TV makes more famous chefs and famous chefs make more TV.

One of the beneficiaries of this development is David Chang. Founder of the Momofuku restaurant empire and host of Netflix‚Äôs ‚ÄúUgly Delicious,‚Äù he could be considered o

Chang welcomes you in, puts some amazing food in front of you while a kickas* conversation with someone that you seem to know takes over the evening. By the end, your food might have grown cold, but the taste lingers as you are left in awe of the journey David took to bring his love of food to your table; This reluctant memoir cured my latest book hangover

How we as Americans are viewed, how we treat those we consider other, untrustworthy, unwanted. How it feels to be the other, judged, condemned, trying to fit in, live alongside, be part of, but never quite fitting. After 9/11 judge and condemned as a whole, hated, attacked,

Cleaving a path between the soul-bearing honesty of memoir and the crafted narrative of fiction, the novel unearths a fresh reflection on how diverse identities impact a distinctly American Dream and experience: its promises, rewards, and inevitable shortc

A masterpiece. This is a monumental work exploring a love that is constantly frustrated - a love of family, community, faith, country and humanity. . . All frustrated by secrets, lies, fear of the unknown, politics and our deepest need to belong.

I don‚Äôt want to give away too much. But weeks after reading it, I still carry the feeling of Homeland Elegies, and the authors heartbreak. And likely will - for years to come

I completely devoured this in just a few days. It's nothing short of brilliant, breathtaking, and moving. It is at once a deeply personal and gut-wrenching look into the author's life as well as an incisive and unflinchingly honest examination of our country's heart and soul. An exhilarating, vivid, and cinematic read. You will laugh, you will hurt, and you will weep. The most remarkable and explosive memoir I've read in recent memory.

Ayad Akhtar puts his life and his perception of America on stage. Storys of the country he was born and raised in, which now is living on the idea of opportunitys long gone. Disarmingly honest in his storytelling and profoundly well researched. A great read.

In his opening letter to the reader, the author shares that he wrote this book ‚Äúin something of a fever dream‚Äù following the death of his mother, the election of Donald Trump and when his father was showing signs of decline. He wanted to reflect on what had brought his parents from Pakistan to America fifty years earlier, their lives, their hopes and dreams for themselves, as well as for their children, whose homeland was America, how the country had changed and what those changes had meant for

While the author insists the book is fiction, it appears to be written more as a collection of essays, and has the ring of a truth telling memoir to it. The writing felt a bit pedantic and condescending at times, but generally not too off-putting.

Some chapters/essays were more engaging than others, but overall they did become the sum of their parts to create a whole which, by my interpretation, was meant to be an ode to his father, his mother, his life in America that he was given through their

user_name: Catherine at The Gilmore Guide to Books
review_text:
(4.5)

These days, I‚Äôm attuned to fiction that takes my mind off reality. Not necessarily easy or soothing, but novels that grab me with their drama or distract me with their lovely prose. It‚Äôs with some surprise then that I‚Äôm reviewing Homeland Elegies, a complex novel I‚Äôm still not sure I fully understand. Ostensibly, it‚Äôs about Sikander, a highly successful cardiologist from Pakistan who emigrates to America, and his son, Ayad, a playwright, who was born here. The novel focuses largely on their

Homeland Elegies is the story of the American-born son of Pakistani immigrants whose faith in America is challenged by Donald Trump and the xenophobia he faces. His father was once Trump‚Äôs doctor and the gloss of knowing him long ago lets him ignore the anti-Muslim bigotry, assuming he means other Muslims, not ones like him. His mother has never been quite so trusting of America and after her death, before the book begins, he learns more about her dissatisfaction.

The narrator shares a name, pers

Well-written and passionately read by the author. From what I have read in reviews and interviews, Akhtar is cagey about how much of the book is autobiographical but it doesn‚Äôt make much difference. The voice of Ayad, fictional or not, is powerful and brave in what he shares of himself and those close to him. I never doubted his authority in telling his tale. The story has a lot to say about America and what it is to be an American right now, much of it disturbing.

This is an interesting one. At its heart, it's a story about a man and his father, living in the United States under late stage capitalism, as well as an exploration of what it means to truly be "home." It's also full of digressions on other things, some of which are fascinating and others of which don't really go anywhere or rise to actively irritating (dude, stop talking about your dick, please).

Do whatever you need to do to get a copy of this book. Whether it‚Äôs buying from your local independent bookstore (preferably Vroman‚Äôs), borrowing it from your local library, or asking a friend to lend it to you, you need to read this book. Cover to cover, a brilliant, sophisticated, story of relevant topics, humorous banter, and inquisitive perspectives.
Welp. so bracing it was like being slapped in the face every other page. Read it in a single 4 hour sitting. Made me feel shame and glory. What else do you want from a book?

Homeland Elegies is a sort of hybrid book. While it's listed as fiction, the author is writing in a variation of his own voice about experiences that overlap significantly with the experiences of his own life. Homeland Elegies explores the evolution of Pakistani-American identity over the last twenty years. The book alternates between narrative and reflection, so in places it reads like a novel; in other places it reads like a collection of essays (it never really reads as fully fictional, but I
Brilliant, poignant, and timely. An American Pastoral for current times. Highly recommended! I will be revisiting this masterpiece many times.

4

Akhtar's Homeland Elegies is a thoughtful and incisive novel about contemporary USA. I read it in the week leading up to the USA presidential election and found it to be incredibly revealing about many of the issues dividing and shaping the nation.

The book is something of a novel, memoir, reflective essay, historical and political analysis written from the particular perspective of a Pakistani family immigrant experience in the USA. The narrator (sharing Akhtar's name) isn't particularly a pra

I seldom start reading a book as soon as I buy it.
And the last time I stayed up into the wee hours in order to finish a book was in the late '80's, for Scott Turow's "Presumed Inocent". I finished off the last 120 pp of this last night, most of it the lengthy last chapter about his father's problems.
It seems all the readers have an issue with this being called "A Novel" - it is obviously autobiographical, and more a memoir than a piece of fiction. I did read a short interview with him, somethin

Weaving together fact, fiction, auto fiction, memoir, and history, this is erudite, fascinating, compelling, and brilliant. There are so many entwined topics - art, writing practice, economics, civil rights lawyers, Bork, Partition, from which, among other things, Pakistan came into existence, friendship, medicine, the concept of "home" and more - as the first person narrator, named Ayad Akhtar, a dramatist and Pulitzer Prize winner like the author, explores the American Dream through the eyes a

Part memoir, part fiction and part essay, this is a book that is not easily categorized. Ayad Akhtar was born in the US to parents who immigrated from Pakistan. He writes of his experiences as a Muslim American and the appearance and the reality of the American dream.

Reading this made me remember a conversation I had once with a man who immigrated to the US as a child. He spoke of his parents' lack of feeling like they belonged anywhere - when they were in the US, they wished they were back in G

A very well written thought provoking consolidation of memoir, fiction, socioeconomic and cultural analysis from the perspective of young American of Pakistani heritage in a pre and post 911 society. A fantastic read!

Whoa. This was amazing. I can't stop thinking about it. It's accessible and readable but also deeply intellectual in parts. I want to read it again and discuss with someone. It's a work of fiction but clearly has elements of fact. Ayad Akhtar, main character and also the author, is the son of Pakastani immigrants. He was raised largely in WI with very little fall-out from being the only brown kid in most situations. Akhtar's dad is/was a highly respected and well known cardiologist and his mom i
A fine novel of 21st century America brought to life by the Pulitzer Prize-winning Muslim-American playwright, Ayad Akhtar. Akhtar‚Äôs reading of the audiobook is exceptional.

This well written sojourn into the heartland reveals a very accurate picture of who we are and who we aren't as Americans. The author has a unique perspective as a native born son of Pakistani immigrants and he shares his heartwarming experiences as well as bearing his soul by revealing some of less laudable moments of his family's life. He masterfully depicts what America has become and how we ended up with Trump as president by comparing us to Bedford Falls and Potterville from "It's a Wonderf

I loved this book which was well written and told a story about a muslim's experience in the US after 9/11. I know many south asian people and had no idea of the prejudice they frequently experience. This book gave me much to think about. Would love for my book club to read and discuss.

I used to gravitate towards this sort of book, starving for some connection and representation. In Homeland Elegies, Akhtar gives us not one South Asian (Pakistani) Muslim story, but a dozen, each distinct and recognizable. And I have to appreciate this.

But as a novel, this book is uneven and doesn't quite hang together. Which means when it's good it's very good but when it's bad it's bad. It's obvious the writer is a playwright; the strongest parts are the dialogues. The writing owes much to Ro

"...America had begun as a colony and that a colony it remained, that is, a place still defined by its plunder, where enrichment was paramount and civil order always an afterthought."

"...my mother never found in the various bounties of her new country anything like sufficient compensation for the loss of what she'd left behind. I don't think Mother ever felt at home here. She thought Americans materialistic and couldn't understand what was so holy about the orgy of acquisition they called Christ

4.5 stars
An essential read.
An insight into what it is to be American, and to be successful in America, and why the country is where it is right now.
It's too bad I can't recommend this higher than five stars. Re: what fiction can do to comment on contemporary America, it is excellent.

Terrific read. Highly recommended.
Felt like a much darker, grittier and serious, book-version of Hasan Minhaj's "Homecoming King".

I loved this so much. Each chapter is a snippet from the author‚Äôs life, including the author‚Äôs reflections on his parents, his career, the possibilities (and lack thereof) inherent to a life on the US, and hisbeing of Muslim descent. While I know nothing about being Muslim, I do know what it feels like to be disillusioned and it‚Äôs that feeling of disillusionment, of cynicism, of world weariness, that the author captures so well.

Ayad Akhtar's new novel kicked me in the gut, hard. The story seems close to autobiographical, which made it all that more gripping. Ayad's parents immigrated to the USA from Pakistan, where Akhtar was born. Akhtar's life story includes the extreme difficulties of being accepted in our xenophobic country before and after 9/11.

AA's description of religious and racial bias is not something new. Still, his insightful report of his mother's constant religious faith is surpassed by his story of how h

(FROM MY BLOG) Ayad Akhtar's parents were immigrants. From Pakistan. They didn't fit the Ellis Island stereotype: both his mother and his father had medical degrees from a Pakistani university, and his father had become one of America's premier experts in a certain area of cardiology.

Ayad himself was born in New York, and grew up in a suburb of Milwaukee. His father was an atheist, but many of his relatives -- including the many family members still living back in Pakistan -- were devout Muslim

Its bio fiction presentation makes it urgently organic. It‚Äôs exploration of a first generation Muslim Pakistani American and his relationship to America was specifically fascinating and something I‚Äôve come to expect from Ayad Akhtar‚Äôs writing. What I didn‚Äôt expect was to feel so satisfied that this very specific story and perspective was so universally resonant in terms of what it means to be an American.

A timely, important, and prescient novel in this time of American cultural awareness and divisiveness. Homeland Elegies explores race, religion, culture, and economics through the voice of Ayad Akhtar, an immigrant and Muslim from Pakistan. And while this story reads like a memoir, it is indeed a gripping novel.
A great novel. Well written. Good plot and good characters

There is no Kamal Morse.

There is definitely no Kamal Morse, All-Pro linebacker for the Oakland Raiders, who retired from the NFL to start a mosque. There appears to be no Kamal Morse, period, not on Facebook, not on Twitter, not on LinkedIn.

There is a Khalil Mack, former All-Pro linebacker for the Oakland Raiders, who did not retire from the NFL to start a mosque or do anything else. Instead, he was traded to the Chicago Bears for wanting more money than the Raiders thought he was worse. He sti

Told through a mix of memoir and fiction, which is deliberately impossible to tease apart, the reader is taken through the complex journey of growing up a Muslim in modern day America. There is a careful and cutting examination of American norms and ideals; the fact that their very society is built upon the drive and need to consume; that human beings are judged by their financial success rather than their moral fibre. Juxtaposing this with the foundations underpinning the Muslim religion and th

I don't even know how to review this book, except to say that it blew me away from the first 10 pages.
First of all, Ayad Akhtar is a writer in every sense of the word. He is also insanely intelligent, and I won't begin to lie and say that I totally understood every word. There were many parts of this book that I struggled to understand, even as I read the words multiple times.

So what is this about? A lot of things. But above else, it's about an immigrant family's desire and attempt to identify

2 Stars, and this is being generous.

"...I ejaculated in a nightmare about the Trump wives and daughters, a cabal of buxom blondes who took turns putting lipstick on my penis...." - Ayad Akhtar

And that was just the tip of the iceberg. Such despicable vulgarity from this self-confessed social climber who no one's ever heard of.

This is the only book I ever returned for an exchange.

How unfortunate that this otherwise competent writer could not restrain himself and goes off kilter from

Homeland Elegies by Ayad Akhtar
343 pages

What‚Äôs it about?
Ayad Akhtar is a Pulitzer Prize winning playwright and novelist. His newest book is written as a novel, but at times seemed more like a memoir or a collection of short stories. Much like Akhtar, the narrator is a American born man of Pakistani descent. This novel gives us vignettes of the Muslim-American experience and insights into how America got to the place it is now.

What did it make me think about?
Family, belo

The most fascinating aspect of this book is its genre-bending: it's a novel, a memoir, a collection of political and social essays, a historical commentary, fact AND fiction, all at the same time. And, it meets the criteria of each with precision. How much of what Ayad Akhtar includes in this somewhat autobiographical text is pulled from his own life leaves the reader wondering all the way through the author's exploration of being a Muslim after 9/11, an outsider in the America that is,
"[f]or

I just finished this autobiographical novel, Ayad Akhtar's unspooling of what makes America awful, magnificent and promising. It's the story of a Pakistani father and son, finding their sea legs before and after 9-11 and Trump's nomination. It's also so many other stories: The damaging effects of unchecked free enterprise; conflicting national allegiances, racism from the perspective of Muslim people, the seduction of wealth's trappings and yes, syphilis.
The first couple of chapters had me wonde

I can only make thing up about things that have already happened - Alison Bechdel

During a class on life under early American capitalism, Mary, clearly interrupted by her own tantalizing thought, looked up from the floor at which she usually gazed as she spoke - her left hand characteristically buried in the pocket of the loose-fitting slacks that were her mainstay - looked up and remarked almost offhandedly that America had begun as a colony and that a colony it remained, that is a place defined

When I first requested to read this book through my library, I expected this to be a fictional tale. To my surprise, I realized that the author tied fact and fiction when writing this novel to demonstrate the paradoxes of the American Dream and capitalism. It is difficult to categorize this novel, but it feels like a memoir and series of personal essays on politics all in one book.

Overall, I would have to give this novel 3.5 stars. I liked the different style of writing since it is different. I

This book has a lot of 5-star reviews, making me wonder where it went so wrong for me.

This is the second "is it a memoir or a novel?" book I've read recently, and I think I am going to avoid books of this type for awhile, as I didn't like the other one either.

"Seamlessly blending fact and fiction" ultimately means you don't know what is what, making one question everything. Not about the things you thought you knew, which is likely the point of the book, but about everything in the book itself

I enjoyed this book but am confused by it at the same time. I had watched an interview with Mr. Akhtar online and realized that I was reading a novel based on his life and relationships. I wish it had been one or the other. There are some very telling stories about what it is like to be an immigrant, a Muslim, and a person of color in America. Some truths here that may help us move forward in positive ways. But a lot of the story gets on a different path around wealth, economies, capitalism, and

This is sort of a strange hybrid of a book. I was never sure if what I was reading was fact or fiction since it is both fiction and non-fiction. Nevertheless, many parts were fascinating reveals of what appears to be the author's family's journey as immigrants from Pakistan and their experiences in the States. At times heart-breakingly personal, at others a political diatribe, yet others a treatise on American greed.

Thanks to NetGalley and Little, Brown, and Company for the ARC to read and revi

First, I have to say that Ayad Akhtar's narration of the audiobook was exceptional. Generally authors cannot do justice to their own work, but his inflections and accents were outstanding.

This is a very peculiar and intriguing work, couched as memoir though the author disavows it as such. An odd device, and the reader can't help wonder which parts are fact and which are fiction. I had the same feeling about many of the setpieces, extensive descriptions of the world view of different characters,

This book is wonderful. An exciting blending of fiction and nonfiction. A father and son story like none I‚Äôve ever read. As a younger man, the father is a doctor who is helping a younger Donald Trump with a health issue. Years later, when he makes his presidential run, the author‚Äôs father is pulling for Trump, much to the horror of the son. But this is just the tipping point as the author dives into what it means to be an American Muslim. I was blown away by the anger, sense of injustice and con

fantastic and brilliant. utterly engaging from the first pages up to the end. i could not stop, nor did it want to stop, reading.

for me this is book is an example of how fiction can be just as, if not more, informative than non-fiction, particularly his experiences as a immigrant/poc/muslim living, working, existing in america pre and post 9/11. it dives right into the duality of that experience and never lets it go.

amazing book.

Brutal and uplifting

It has been some time since I have read anything that so consistently made me recalibrate my assumptions or to clarify some long held beliefs. I would recommend it to anyone and have done so with some misgivings about whether or not I was being presumptuous in the case of friends who are Islam or otherwise religious. I look forward to the discussions.
Akhtar's smooth writing style is easy to read and he gives interesting insights into both the immigrant and Muslim experience in the US. Book received through goodreads contest
4.5 stars.

Had this on hold at the public library. I was able to pick it up on the library's Lucky Day shelf so setting aside my other books to read this before I need to return. This was a tough read about a group of Americans I don't know well. It is a novel but felt very autobiographic. Needs to be read to the very last page for his final paragraph. I have seen all his plays to was excited to read this book.

Mixed feelings- at times this read as a memoir, other times as a higher ed lecture, sometimes like a novel, sometimes as if ripped from the headlines. had to go back at times and relisten. I have not had the experiences expressed by the author, but remember all too well the backlash against all people who "looked like an arab" after 911. Hard to imagine what that felt like then, or what the continued discrimination feels like now... but trying to understand what the ignorance, anger and despair

Literate, well written fictional memoir based on experiences from the author‚Äôs life. Although it centers on living as an American Muslim in a post 9/11 world, it is far reaching in its astute observations of many aspects of society including politics and economics. Profound, insightful, honest, poignant, relevant, thought provoking.
Very interesting view of American capitalism, racism and the author‚Äôs quest to understand himself in these contexts.
Wow, What a beautiful book, I am SO happy to have bought this and read this, This is a must read!

I couldn't put this down. If you've seen Akhtar's play Disgraced, you'll have some idea of what you're in for, but Homeland Elegies goes deeper and wider. The core of this semi-fictional memoir deals with the author's difficult relationship with his father, a Pakistani immigrant cardiologist who treated Donald Trump's heart irregularities almost 3 decades ago and became besotted with him. Along the way a lot of dirty laundry is aired, including Akhtar's case of syphilis and his discovery of a ha
Caustic, infuriating, exhausting, hopeless at times, but undeniably a towering work of fiction. Wouldn‚Äôt be surprised if Akhtar walks away with another Pulitzer in 2020.

Akhtar's novel is a fascinating mashup of autofiction, essays, and social commentary. It blurs the line between genres. The audiobook, read by the author, adds an extra layer of verisimilitude, and his background as a playwright is evident throughout. A lot of the novel focuses on the Muslim experience of America, particularly since 9/11 and persisting into the Trump era, and that's interesting and layered, then there is also social commentary and discussion of various topics such as a conversat

Profound, raw, insightful immigrant story about his Pakistanian American parents. Yet it's an American story narrated by a playwright with the same name as the author- seems autobiographical of the author who is also a playwright, set in contemporary times with relevant references to Trump, His Wall, & dishonest means toward wealth. Father is a cardiologist who becomes Trump's cardiologist and a Trump supporter despite being a Muslim himself. Significant events occur 9-11, Trump presidency, fami

Homeland elegies

WOW, I just finished reading this wonderful book. The writing is exquisite, the stories flow beautifully. It opened my eyes to the life experiences of a person different from me, I learned a lot.

Breathtakingly beautiful. I think a lot of the focus has been on the type of book this is -- is it memoir, essays, novel -- which really takes away from the content of the book. It is a powerful and often searing review of what it means to be American (specifically). I can't recommend this book enough.
Brilliant
My earlier comment still stands, but his analysis of some aspects of American life seems accurate to me.

I'm always drawn to bombastic immigrant narratives that try to pin down Americana, so it was inevitable that I was going to read this. I loved the first few chapters of the book, which offer a smart and hilarious dissection of Trump's rise and an interesting background of the author's parents growing up in Pakistan.

But, in the middle section, as the author turns toward himself--a Pulitzer prize winning dramatist‚Äîthe book loses some of its power. It reads more like a series of long-form pieces (

Having not read Akhtar's plays, I found this "memoir" (technically it is a novel) absorbing, disturbingly honest, and written with an eloquence of a person whose skillful observations paints what it meant to be both an insider and an outsider to American society.

Although written as a novel, this felt more like a series of connected essays. For me, that helped solidify the complexities of being a Muslim in America, and particular a Pakistani. It also helped illustrated how American foreign policy has failed in many ways. If I had to make a ‚Äúrequired‚Äù reading list for understanding other cultures, this would head the list.
There was a great deal to learn from this book - thus my favourite kind. I listened to the author read - which added value as well.
An unexpected find, I opened it by chance and couldn't put down; funny but also disturbing and very absorbing - one of the main surprises of the year for me and highly recommended

Ayad Akhtar is an amazing writer; gifted and articulate at a level far beyond that which I normally read. Whether HOMELAND ELEGIES is memoir, fiction, novelization of someone else‚Äôs life or autobiography, I have no clear idea, nor am I convinced that it matters. The tale rings true for first generation children with immigrant families tethered to their disputed, unreachable homelands. Unreachable because they exist mostly in memory rather than reality. And the American children spend their lives
Beautifully written, but it can be difficult to get through. Many parts read more like an essay than a novel. Worth it in the end. Interesting critique of American life.

This is one of the most insightful and intelligent musings on life in America in a post 9/11 world that I could imagine. If I was a billionaire I would quite honestly deliver one to every American home before election time in the hopes of yielding some compassion and understanding.
Although the majority of this book is clearly memoir and factual, Akhtar admits to embellishment and therefore cites this as a novel - and thankfully, that is how it is written, creating a far more compulsive read tha

This is one of the most insightful and intelligent musings on life in America in a post 9/11 world that I could imagine. If I was a billionaire I would quite honestly deliver one to every American home before election time in the hopes of yielding some compassion and understanding.
Although the majority of this book is clearly memoir and factual, Akhtar admits to embellishment and therefore cites this as a novel - and thankfully, that is how it is written, creating a far more compulsive read tha
This is an engrossing, insightful, and timely work of autofiction.

Homeland Elegies Hits The Spot
By Daniel Palugyai

If only Americans knew the real Donald Trump, the author‚Äôs father laments in this new, imaginative, Non-fiction, Novel-marvel, Mishmash of Memoir.

Author Ayad Akhtar‚Äôs father treated Trump for a heart condition and was touched by the future president bringing two cups of coffee to their appointment the morning after Donald‚Äôs thoughtful questions on how to pronounce his name, how his stay at his hotel was, and his poetically vulnerable admission of

This book tugged at every heart sting of my soul and was so moving, raw and thought provoking. The characterization and story was spot on and still a current issue even though this is a work of fiction, the central events actually happened. This is definitely a re-read and to own book, and I can see this as an Oprah book club choice and a huge discussion in all book clubs. It is just wow and unforgettable.

Thanks to Negalley, Ayad Akhtar and Little Brown & Company for an ARC in exchange for an ho

This is a multi-layered, original work that is true to its title: an elegy to America from the perspective of a writer who is the child of immigrants. Akhtar is a gifted writer who has pulled together the myriad facets of American life and culture, added complex, relatable characters seeking to find their places in the modern version of the American dream, and crafted an unforgettable story. There are so many aspects to this novel that it is hard to distill into a brief review, as it is part aut

A novel written in the stye of a memoir, HOMELAND ELEGIES by Ayad Akhtar is the first person account of a first generation Pakistani American playwright, the son of doctors, born on Staten Island and raised in Wisconsin. He struggles between his identity as an American and a Muslim, and differentiates as we‚ÄîAmericans, and we‚ÄîMuslims, throughout the book, never fully identifying as either, eventually feeling more Muslim if only because he is clearly not accepted as American. Adding to the conflic

"They call it a melting pot, but it's not. In chemistry, they have what they call a buffer solution - which keeps things together but always separated. That's what this country is. A buffer solution."

Technically I like this book more than the three stars I'm awarding it, but I don't like it enough to warrant it a fourth. It definitely has its merits. But there's a lot to be desired here as well.

Homeland Elegies is a blend of memoir and fictional tale where the narrator shares the same name as th

I wouldn't be surprised to see Akhtar win another Pulitzer prize for his latest fictional novel that runs along the razor's edge of being a memoir. What identifies a great novel in my mind is one that shines a light on part of the human condition that one has never really considered before. What is it like to be identified as 'other' in your own homeland, the place of your birth?

Ayad Akhtar is an award-winning Pakistani-American playwright, born on Staten Island, raised in Wisconsin, with paren

A magnificent, energetic chimera of a book that utterly resists classification, and (at least as far as I'm concerned) description. It's unlike anything else I've read: part memoir, part essays, part social commentary, part meditation on "the immigrant experience," part examination of what it means to be a Muslim in post-9/11 America, part fiction -- hell, it even has an episode that might have been taken whole from an X-rated movie. It's all these things and more, and the reader (or in my case,

Homeland Elegies is Ayad Akhtar's story, a combination of fiction and truth. An exploration of what it meant to be growing up Muslim in post 9/11 America.
Its not very often I describe books as intimate but this book is written in a way that feels so personal, so raw and in all honesty must of taken a lot of courage to write.
It reads like a memoir and although Ayad admits embellishment it doesn't make it seem over dramatised or romanticised in any way.
I love the way he writes about the relation

The narrative of this self-proclaimed "novel" (which reads like a memoir) explores the fictionalized lives of various members of the narrator's Pakistani family and friends.

It offers a perspective from the American "other" - Muslim immigrants before and after 9/11 and their experience of "America".
However, unlike in many stereotypical immigrant "underdog" stories, the narrator is (like the author) a Pulitzer winner coming from a well-educated, economically stable family.

It is easy to see why A

Homeland Elegies is a contemporary and historical history novel written by Ayad Akhtar. It explores the conflicted place in United States society in a searing work of autofiction.

The narrator, Ayad, was, like the author, born in Staten Island to Pakistani immigrant parents and raised in Wisconsin, and wrote a Pulitzer-winning play. In eight well-developed chapters structured as musical movements, starting with an overture and ending with a coda, Ayad traces his often complicated personal, philos

I was immediately drawn to this book for its Pakistani-American author. After all, there aren‚Äôt that many South Asian voices that get published globally. But nothing prepared me for the deeply personal nature of the writing. What was I reading? A memoir, a novel, a series of essays, an expos√©, or a lesson in history, economics and political science? This book is all of those things, and while I struggled with the idea of calling it a novel (on the title, no far less) - I have my reservations wit

Ok... this is really more of a 3.5... I will explain.

I picked up this book because our library had a program where the librarians would choose a book for you based on your stated preferences. I will admit I was not initially excited that this was their choice for me.
I got around to starting it and, as some other reviewers have stated, it was not obviously fish or fowl... biography or fiction. It also starts off very slow. The initial chapter about the author's father and his love of a certain

This was mostly a book I enjoyed reading - and I did gobble it up in a few short sittings, though its claim to be a blend of fiction and nonfiction is confusing rather than illuminating.

I can't see the point of the qualification. Some episodes prove interesting and gripping, many others feel tedious. None of the fiction is explicitly postmodern, or explicit at all. Maybe the courtroom scene the author writes in screenplay format is fiction; or a scare with syphilis and priapism while his mother

I've been crushing on this man for the last fifteen years.
So you best believe I pre-ordered this book immediately.

Matthew McConaughey has been keeping journals, diaries, and random writings for the past 35 years. Greenlights is all of those writings in one perfect little book. We get to hear about his childhood, his rise to fame, his Hollywood hiatus, his wife and kids, and so much more.

I have to say, the first 25% of the book was not the spark I was looking expecting from Matthew McConaughey.

LOVED! Amazing, amazing, amazing. So authentic and genuine. Matthew has lived an impressive life. He loves being a dad, loves his wife, and has tried to remained true to who he is. Hilarious story telling, tidbits of life tips along the way, and lots of greenlights. Highly recommend listening since he narrates it!

Matthew McConaughey is one heck of a story teller!
I listened to this on audio book and was truly engaged the whole way through.
This book is raw, witty, insightful, uplifting and had me laughing out loud

And lets be honest, with that voice, I would listen to McConaughey read the phone book!

I heard the audiobook read by the man himself and considering he is an Oscar winning actor, he sure knows how to perform a book well.
This was charming, honest, hilarious and written better than I expected. Through the fetishisation of Lord Byron and the Amazon River, Matthew‚Äôs amateur poetry and writing in this memoir has beautiful lessons to convey, yet in the spirit of his Lincoln ads, it sounds more profound than it really is.

I‚Äôve been looking forward to reading this for a few months and it was more enjoyable than I could have imagined. A refreshing reminder of how down to earth and human some high profile people can be. However, it‚Äôs an important account and reflection on life, regardless of who the author is. I started reading it 5 hours ago after picking it up at a local bookstore and didn‚Äôt put it down until I finished it. Quick and easy read.

Never have I ever read a book about the soul written in that way.

I've read books about the mind, successes and all that stuff.

This book has some things about success. It's called Greenlights after all. But this book is about the boat shaken, the frequency, and the story of a man who connected to his own natural frequency. It's raw, honest and most of all it's damn funny!

That's a book I want to have on my table and read throughout life.

Tara Westover is the child of a religious fanatic, someone who sees the government as pure evil. And by government, he means schools, hospitals, vaccines, seat belts, car insurance, etc. Everything we think o

A monumental memoir that should be required reading for all. The description doesn't do it justice. It's not about getting a PhD, it's about growing up in a family that doesn't believe in school, thinks doctors are a part of a sociologist conspiracy, and that any day the government will shoot them dead--if the end of times don't come first. The experiences Tara describes are horrific, yet oddly relatable--even if your family is nothing like hers (and let's hope it isn't). By the end, she has to

Everything about this book amazed me. I will not stop thinking about this book for a very, very long time. I don't think I can even do this proper justice in a review other than telling everyone to go out and READ THIS BOOK! Easiest 5 stars ever. Loved it.

Yeah, I made that sound like one of the sleazy thrillers I'm fond of but Educated is a memoir, not a potboiler. I don't normally read memoirs but I decided to take Random House up on their offer when they came knocking.

Well, this one was a special book. I didn't like what I read in the beginning. But it's a reminder of what harm religion can do. But quickly we came out of this Sam Harris-like territory, and went into more chaos.

There are a few cases like Tara's. But not everyone of them can write like her. She reminds me of Beryl Markham with her biography, West with the Night.

Reading this book was very much aligning with the values that I hold sacred. The written word, if acquired, can be a formidable weapon.

Educated, Tara Westover

Tara Westover was 17 the first time she set foot in a classroom. Born to survivalists in the mountains of Idaho, she prepared for the end of the world by stockpiling home-canned peaches and sleeping with her "head-for-the-hills bag".

In the summer she stewed herbs for her mother, a midwife and healer, and in the winter she salvaged in her father's junkyard. Her father forbade hospitals, so Tara never saw a doctor or nurse. Gashes and concussions, even burns from explosions

Apparently, I need to reevaluate my opinion of beach-reads.

We've been watching the Mindy Project (a rewatch for me, first time for my husband) so when I saw this series of six essays by Mindy Kaling it was an obvious download. The Kindle version is free to Amazon Prime members and after you download them you can access the audio free as well. Obviously I listened to this in audio read by the author - it's about exploring her religious heritage once she became a mother. (Did you know she had a second child September 2nd?) This one was short - 21 minutes

I love Mindy Kaling. Not only was she an excellent writer and Kelly on The Office, but I enjoyed her Is Everyone Hanging Out Without Me? very much. She is so real and down to earth.

In this first installment she talks about motherhood and how your own faith can become very important when you think about the fact that you are responsible for your child's beliefs. At least the formation. That doesn't sound particularly funny, but Kaling makes it so.

The general review: a series of essays that don't quite add up to the length of her two prior outings, each bite is nevertheless a nice look into Mindy Kaling's life and thoughts. She's been more or less a part of the pop culture landscape since The Office, which is a long time, and her works are worth reading.

EDITED: to fix some unnecessarily snarky commentary in the middle with some more nuanced thoughts that get across my actual point without distracting petty BS.

As the title states, Kind of Hindu, is an essay about religious identity and how people, especially those who identify as Third Culture Kids, incorporate beliefs and traditions from their home and host cultures; their life experience is one where they have partial belonging to multiple cultures without having full ownership in any. Child-rearing in your Heritage
Review of the Amazon Original kindle eBook (2020)

Funny short essay about writer/actress Mindy Kaling's so-so relationship to her Hindu-faith heritage and her attempts to raise her daughter Kit in that heritage regardless.

Kind of Hindu is one of the six-part Nothing Like I Imagined collection of autobiographical short comedy essays by Mindy Kaling available through Amazon Originals.

This was super sweet and she absolutely nails what it's like to be a diaspora child culturally tied to your religion but not actually religious. That said, I think this would have hit harder if the Mundan story hadn't also been an episode of The Mindy Project.

Also, who styled her for this cover? I'm insulted on her behalf. She is too pretty and desi clothes are too nice for this to be what they did to her.

I thought this essay (book? chapter?) was quite delightful and poignant, which was a relief since I found the essay "Please Like Me" to be kind of awful in a way that made me doubt my enjoyment in everything Mindy Kaling has done! I don't know if there's an order for reading this collection, but clearly I've done it incorrectly.

The story came to my catalog as a free, short kindle story. I like when the author does the audible. I see the story being free as a nod to the totally massive world of Hindus raising kids their own way in a modern world. ‚ÄúKind of Hindu‚Äù is a great essay.
sweet story

Sweet

Short,sweet and funny too. Mindy and Kit's "kind of" religious experience sweetly brought her closer to her Mother who has passed away.
I mean, should I rate any Mindy Kaling book/essay higher than 5 stars?
Oh Mindy! You make feel normal, less weird, and nudge me to embrace my old and new in its entirety! Fun quick read :)
A fun quick read.

Mindy Kaling has a series of short stories on Amazon Prime books. This was my favorite, exploring her status as a Third Culture Kid, and having a child of her own. Third Culture refers to a mixed identity where they are influenced by both their parents native culture and the culture of the country they are being raised in. In some circles, there may be shame in this. However, Mindy Kaling is debunking this by saying it is actually okay to be "kind of Hindu" and learn and grow as you go. I listened to all of the stories from Mindy‚Äôs new collection, Nothing Like I Imagined. Annoying that they are separated here.

This one and ‚ÄúHelp is on the Way‚Äù were my favorites as Mindy opened up about missing her own mother as she took on the responsibilities of motherhood herself. The other stories kind of felt like blog entries‚Äî they were fun to listen to but weren‚Äôt really too meaningful. (In the same breath I would love it if Mindy brought back her old shopping blog ‚ÄúThings I bought that I

So I'm kind of annoyed that Goodreads made all of these short stories into six separate books instead of just one. But anyway...

This was a fun start to Mindy's new essay collections. This one talked about culture, religion and identity. Mindy wonders what religious aspects she wants to introduce to her daughter as she raises her. I was laughing from the start, of course and it was cute to hear a story about her daughter.

Ready for the next one!

3.5 stars. I'm giving all 6 essays in this collection the same rating since it *is* a collection. Mindy is a fantastic writer but I mostly found this collection "meh". Perhaps it's because there were only 6 so I felt dissatisfied--I don't know. I just didn't feel as connected to her as I did in her previous books. I'd still recommend the collection--it's a fast and light read, and Mindy's writing voice is extremely personable.

This is the first in a series of six essays that Mindy Kaling wrote for her new Amazon book series Nothing Like I Imagined. In Kind of Hindu Mindy reflects on how the birth of her daughter forced her to re-evaluate her connection to her family's Hindu faith. I found this to be an interesting and insightful read. It's not laugh out loud funny but I don't think that it was meant to be. I enjoyed it and I am looking forward to reading some of the other books in the series.

A brilliant essay on Indentity, Culture and Religion. Mindy captures the emotions and self-doubts of first-generation "western-born" child & parent beautifully. I can see myself in this essay and it really gave me an insight on embracing our roots no matter where we are and how far we have come. I could not give a 5 star because I felt like Mindy could have shared more on the topic of being an American-born Confused Desi.

A brief glimpse into Mindy's as she questions what it means to be Hindu while living in the United States and what cultural values she wants to instill in her daughter. Kaling makes a beautiful revelation about the connection she has with her mother because of the faith and traditions she grew up with, and how those traditions and faith will be her daughter's connection to her grandmother. I look forward to reading more of Kaling's essays.

I thought Mindy Kaling is kind of awesome as an author and that's why I picked this quick read up. There are others in the series, but this was a first Mindy Kaling book.

Sadly, this did not work out for me at all. I was disappointed and wondered why I picked it up in the first place. I get that she is being honest, but there were so many comparisons regarding the baby and mundane that I just couldn't enjoy it as much I hoped to.

Another excellent essay, brimming with humour and pathos. And as the mother to a half-Hindu, half-Catholic, yet also kind-of-secular child, it was very reassuring to read about Mindy's own experience and the uncertainty she feels, as religion is and will be a complicated presence in my family life (thanks largely in part to my wholly-Catholic guilt).

Sweet story of inter-generational connection

I wish Kaling was always writing books and also I relate pretty strongly to her feelings about parties.

Please Like Me [But Keep Away] is an apt title for the anecdotes in this hilarious and refreshingly honest essay. Mindy gets vulnerable as she reminisces about her ninth birthday, where her parents volunteered to throw her a party. While this offer would make most kids jump for joy, Mindy was filled with dread because she (incorrectly) believed that her South Asian (Tamil/Bengali) parents "would accidently mess up some important aspect of the quintessential American birthday party". She had me at the title! This short read was filled with Kaling's humor and down-to-earth thoughts/feelings. It was a fun way to spend a little time.

The Office is my husband‚Äôs favorite show and I totally hate it. I have glimpsed bits and pieces while he was watching and I hate Mindy and her body language on that show. Mindy's description of her mom buying white cheese slices is so relatable - even to people who didn't grow up in a minority culture family. Can't we all remember a time when our parents just didn't get it?, but in reality it was just us wanting society and our peers to accept us. It's comforting to know that even still as an adult, she struggles with social anxiety, especially since celebrities are so often portrayed as attention seeking and confident.

My favorite of all of the essays, and the one I related to the most (and read more than once). It's SO difficult to make friends - real friends - at any age, but there's so many extra pitfalls as an adult female and I feel like Kaling nailed so many of the ones I've dealt with. (That insanity about restaurant ordering? I've experienced that firsthand, but with no one I consider a genuine friend).

The Answer Is...Reflections on My Life by Alex Trebek offers the reader a view into his life and a look at his influence on a program that has endured for decades. His approach to life and to death speaks of a simple man who lived a fascinating life. There is food for thought here, from his love of family to his courage when faced with a terminal diagnosis. All proceeds from this book are to be donated to people who live in poverty or have special needs.

Not a typical autobiography, but rather this book is exactly what the title states- Alex's reflections on things throughout his life. It didn't feel overthought or overworked.

SUMMARY
Long time Jeopardy! host and television icon Alex Trebek reflects on his life and career. Since debuting as a host of Jeopardy! in 1984, Alex Trebek has been something like a family member to millions of television viewers, bringing entertainment and education into their homes five nights a week. Last year he made a stunning announcement that he had been diagnosed with stage four pancreatic cancer. What followed was an

As a huge fan of Jeopardy! for over 30 years, I often imagine what it would be like to be a contestant on the show. I don't worry that I might not measure up to the competitive standards the show expects of its contestants, even though I am realistic enough to know that I would require a good deal of luck to actually win even one contest. But I do worry about how I would conduct myself during the short on-air conversation that the contestants are required to have with host Alex Trebek ‚Äì especial
I love Jeopardy and Alex Trebek so I felt I had to read this book. I‚Äôm glad I did, but ultimately it was not all that special. Pleasant and quick read.

I love Trebek, but what he said at the beginning of the book is spot on: he's really not that interesting or remarkable. He just has a public job and he's been doing it for a long time.

That said, I still enjoyed listening to his stories. It was a little odd to have Ken Jennings perform the bulk of the book, since it really made me start hearing this AS Jennings's memoir, instead of Trebek's. Trebek does a few of the chapters, but otherwise, Jennings does it.

A quick read.
Totally enjoyed his own telling of his life.
I felt like I was just hanging out with Alex.

I really enjoyed this autobiography and the method used for him to tell his story. It felt like having a conversation with an old friend. And, let's face it, Alex Trebek feels like an old friend who has visited in our home for years. I didn't need an in-depth portrayal of his life to get a sense of who this man really is and what matters to him and so, while there are many who have complained about the approach taken with this autobiography, I think it is brilliant.

This was the perfect way to wrap up Mindy's essay collection. It started with a funny story and, like Mindy does best, took lighthearted, fun stories to talk about deeper things. She talks a lot about her issues with generosity and overcompensating as a minority compared to the white men in the industry, as well as her struggles with constantly wanting people to like her. I think this is something that almost everyone struggles with, but it's not something that especially celebrities talk about

being generous is being absolutely above expectation. Even a thank you, to the point that it may look like you don't care, but you should care but not care for the after in a way that doesn't make you look callous or irreverent.
One of the better essays

3.5 stars. I'm giving all 6 essays in this collection the same rating since it *is* a collection. Mindy is a fantastic writer but I mostly found this collection "meh". Mindy Kaling has such a real voice. She is able to talk about her life in a way that gives you a peek into the celebrity world as well as the real world foibles of a human being. I love her humor, which is both self deprecating and quick witted. As a fellow second generation American Tamilian, I am very proud of Mindy Kaling‚Äôs ability to talk about the immigrant experience in such a down to earth and relatable way.

In her final essay, Mindy talks about treating an A-list celebrity and his family to a Christmas dinner in Hawaii but not being thanked for it at the time and feeling bad about it. I wish she had named the celebrity!

A day in the life of Mindy Kaling was bonus content which was fun to read about!

I especially loved the ending as it truly shows the introspection and growth she has achieved along her journey.

In the story, Big Shot, Mindy talks about how she chased acknowledgement from others; paying for meals just to get some recognition in return. I can relate -- I always want people to like me although I don't like them. We should live life on our own terms.

I also loved seeing the behind-the-scenes portion as a producer.
