Nothing Like I Imagined


Since this is a collection of quick personal essays I‚Äôve decided to review them all in one swoop anthology style.


Please Like Me (But Keep Away) - 4 Stars - This essay reviews the time when Mindy moved to LA to write for the office and had to find/make friends as an adult. A most daunting task indeed. She speaks of wanting a close group of girlfriends and even her experience in trying to join one and of how she somehow ended up with a male BFF. Making

Short, cute and Touching

Short, cute, and touching. I think everyone can relate to wanting to have there mother by their side, especially a new mother. I loved she talked about her fears of not having her mom there with her. This will make you yearn for the love of your mother or a mother like. God knows what you need when you need and he will give it to you.
Heartwarming.

I understand the point of the story is how much she appreciates the role her baby nurse played in her life and acted as a mother figure to her, I hope others in a tax bracket high enough to afford hiring people to help with things most people have to do themselves out of necessity appreciate this one. There are some classic funny lines, hut ultimately too privileged for my taste.
Babies don‚Äôt have kneecaps ?! How am I suppose to deal with that information?

This essay explored Mindy's expectations versus reality when it came to adjusting to motherhood/ child rearing; expectations which were largely influenced by her late mother who didn't have a baby nurse and didn't rely on a nanny or babysitter, instead opting to depend on extended family to help raise Mindy. As a result, Mindy believed that when she became a mom, she'd be independent and do it all like her mother, but a friend advised her that the time after having a baby would be both physicall

The general review: a series of essays that don't quite add up to the length of her two prior outings, each bite is nevertheless a nice look into Mindy Kaling's life and thoughts. She's been more or less a part of the pop culture landscape since The Office, which is a long time, and her works are worth reading.

The story of Rose is another one in which I want to do a bit of eye rolling, like Mindy did you really not realize that having a South-Asian-descent lady around during the first few months

Mindy captures the behind the scenes of Indian - American families almost exactly as how it is, her hilarious pregnancy experiencee and the charming bond between her and the baby nurse. As always, it's honest, hilarious, endearing and a crisp short read! I think I'm definitely going to finish reading this series quick and pick up any book that Mindy writes in the future.

Extremely enjoyable!

Another great piece by Kaling. Laughed out loud at this:

And when it came to a baby, I was not prepared. I had read the baby books, of course, but could remember literally nothing but one fact: ‚Äúbabies are born without kneecaps.‚Äù What the hell was I supposed to do with that information? Invite some gangster to take retribution against me by kneecapping my baby and then laugh when he realizes it‚Äôs physically impossible? That was no good to me; I would have needed to lay the gr

3.5 stars. I'm giving all 6 essays in this collection the same rating since it *is* a collection. Mindy is a fantastic writer but I mostly found this collection "meh". Perhaps it's because there were only 6 so I felt dissatisfied--I don't know. I just didn't feel as connected to her as I did in her previous books. I'd still recommend the collection--it's a fast and light read, and Mindy's writing voice is extremely personable.

Admitting you need help is one of the hardest things to do as an adult. I‚Äôm happy Mindy used her celebrity status for good: opening up about her journey into motherhood and showing that it‚Äôs okay not to be okay. I don‚Äôt yet have children of my own but hope to some day, and I can only imagine the constant fear of whether what you‚Äôre doing is right, perfect or ‚Äúnormal.‚Äù I‚Äôm glad Mindy found her own normal.

My favourite one so far out of the collection. I have three more to go!

This was such a sweet, heartwarming essay on her first pregnancy & the relationship she built with her daughter‚Äôs nurse, Rose. We also gain some touching insight on Mindy‚Äôs relationship with her mother & her fears about motherhood and the apprehension of asking for help.

I will read anything & everything Mindy has to write! Definite 5 stars for this one. Also - that knee quote made me LOL.

"Don't complain, don't explain"; it's a quote Mindy's mother lived by.

In this part of the series she talks about her decision to hire a baby nurse and how that plays out for her. It's emotional, comedic, humane. What I liked about this part is that she has humanized a 'celebrity mom'.
She compares how motherhood was for her mother vis-a-vis herself.

She is single, has lost her mother and is somewhat terrified about motherhood. She finds her way eventually. Kudos to her!

Lovely perspective on asking for and receiving help

I love Mindy's conversational style and clean writing. This is a wonderful, emotional fast read that touches on a very difficult thing for many people...asking for and accepting help. Mindy shares her thoughts and emotions so openly that it reads like an email or text from a friend rather than a story you downloaded and read first thing before getting out of bed on a Saturday.

All of the feels

This essay, like the others released in this collection, has made me laugh and cry. Mindy Kaling has long been my idol, and her honesty and voice are comforting. Although in this particular essay she talks a lot about her doubts and fears, I still find myself asking, "Is there nothing Mindy Kaling can't do?" This is a must-read if you love Mindy Kaling and/or good quality writing.

I‚Äôve said this so far after each one of Mindy‚Äôs stories, but this one is my favorite. Mindy‚Äôs story about life postpartum without her mom really resonated with me. Like everything she writes, it is hilarious and brilliantly written. She describes things in a way that made me feel like I was listening to my friend tell a story. There were also some really touching parts that will stay with me. Short and sweet‚Äî I hope she never stops writing.

Help Is On the Way is a short story in the Nothing Like I Imagined series by Mindy Kaling. You can read these stories in any order.

I don't know what it is like to be a single mother, but I can imagine from what I've seen friends go through that it is no walk in the park. I'm glad Mindy found someone to help her get through those initial scary times and develop the confidence to rock motherhood!

Also, I saw what you did there at the end, Mindy Kaling....Fortunately, it wasn't a spoiler!

This essay from the Amazon short collection of stories by Mindy Kaling also made me a laugh. In this essay, she talks about how her baby nurse, who she didn‚Äôt think she would need, turned out to be a blessing in disguise as she helped her tremendously to deal with the challenges during the early days of motherhood.

I didn't want to like an essay about a famous person who had the luxury of hiring someone to take care of their baby. However, I can't help but love the bond between Mindy and the baby nurse. I love the way she steps in and provides such a comfort and help for Mindy at a time when Mindy misses her mom so much.

Pregnancy reality check

Kudos to Kaling for writing this book. Pregnancy and motherhood can be difficult for anyone, regardless of the mother's income and resources available to her. I enjoyed reading her stories of woe and realized that being a single parent is a tough path to follow after achieving Hollywood stardom. Kudos to Kaling ü§†

Another delightful snippet from the world's most delightful celeb. It must be difficult for her because she writes in a way that makes me, and I'm sure all of her other billion fans, feel that we actually so know her.

Whether it's a TV show, movie, book (audio, please!), I will be the first in line to hear what she has to say.

It was good to read about Mindy's own experience through having her baby as a single mom. Happy for her that despite the anxiety and fears she had Rose as her support system. Every woman could use a mother figure when she herself was on the edge of becoming a mom.
It's a hard thing to explain, it just is..

The one in which she discusses new motherhood, and the difficulty of asking for help. Definitely a more emotional one, but Mindy cuts the more touching moments with bits of her relatable humor. Leave it to Kaling to write a short story about being a parent that any young woman (and, frankly, any woman) can see herself in.

Funny and honest

Mindy, as always, is both funny and honest. She has the ability to pull at you heartstrings and make you laugh at the same time. I‚Äôm looking forward to enjoying the rest of this series of quick reads.

This one was my absolute favorite. I LOVED these 6 books released today (10/6/2020) by Mindy Kaling. I would recommend reading them and then listening to them. I could listen to her all day telling stories. They were funny, uplifting, touching and get 5 stars ‚≠êÔ∏è from me.

This set of essays really made me chuckle, the view of motherhood pre- and post-event is something exceedingly relatable, even if I couldn't relate to hiring a Rose! I still loved reading about the relationship with Rose and thoroughly enjoyed this entry in the series.

This essay is about how Mindy hires a baby nurse to assist her after the birth (and subsequent months after the birth) of her daughter. It‚Äôs not relatable to me, but I see how it could be for other single moms. 4 stars for keeping it clean.

Five epic stars. More women need to talk about their pregnancies and what comes after -- and Mindy Kaling is talking about how it feels to come home a single mother, the worries you have, and how you find a support team (even if that's a nanny) to help you.

Not a parent, but I am a daughter. So from what I read, Mindy and my Filipino-American family have similar values. Loved hearing about the ups and downs of motherhood as well as the sense of found family with Rose. Honest and hilarious.

Born a Crime, at over six months, is the longest library hold I've ever waited for. Normally, if I hadn't already lost interest by that point, I'd just break down and buy it, but I'm generally not a big memoir reader, so I was reluctant to spend money on a book I wasn't sure would be my thing. Well, I've ended up buying it anyway. And my husband and I are currently laughing our way through the audio version, too.

I just couldn't put this book down. There are many moments of com

These stories, beautifully written, are set in a world quite like our own but at the same time utterly different. Maybe "through a glass darkly". Who goes to church three times on Sunday to Black, White and Coloured ones? Who goes to jail for (not) stealing a car rather than face the wrath of his mother? Who gets a prom date with the most beautiful girl around, but one who doesn't speak the language and is extremely unsociable to boot? None of these things are extraordinary in this world,

Who cou
Exceptional ! ! ! (And yes the audiobook was superb)

If you're going to read this book, definitely listen to the audio version. Trevor Noah is one of the most effortless narrators I've ever listened to. It genuinely feels like he is sitting down with you and telling you his life story. Not only that, but you get to learn quite a bit about pre- and post-Apartheid South Africa from the perspective of someone who hypothetically shouldn't exist. Noah's mother is black and his father is white, and when he was born any mixed-race relationships were ille

Before I start my review, I want to take a minute to praise Trevor Noah's stand up shows because they're one of the few that don't rely on being ignorant. His shows are one of the enlightened ones focusing on race, white-privilege, police brutality, hate speech, prejudice, and so much more.
I‚Äôd highly recommend watching a few before reading this riveting memoir.


In Born a Crime, Trevor Noah takes us on a journey from his childhood being born a crime in apartheid South Africa. Trevor was born t

A three-part collection of eighteen personal essays, Born a Crime recollects stories about Trevor Noah's coming-of-age in South Africa under apartheid, as the biracial son of a single Xhosa woman. The memoir-in-essays centers on Noah's relationship with his mother, but it spans a vast range of topics, from the author's experience of his country's racist education system to his brief stint as a DJ while a young adult. Somewhat surprisingly, Noah mostly avoids discussing his career as a comedian.

I also often end up rolling my eyes at memoire writers who are barely out of their teens, but Noah does a smart thing here, writing about something bigger than his personal life. A lighthearted and sincere memoir by Trevor Noah, a South African comedian and current host of The Daily Show. In Born a Crime, Noah details his experience growing up in apartheid South Africa, where his parents - a black Xhosa mother and a white Swiss father - committed an illegal act just by conceiving him. Trevor Noah was the only white kid in the black neighborhood, the only black kid in the white neighborhood, and the only mixed-race kid in the colored neighborhood. He didn't always know where he fit in, but he always knew who he was.

Comedian and TV presenter Trevor Noah's stories of his childhood in South Africa are not only entertaining but eye-opening. Born to a single black Xhosa woman and a white father, he was classified as coloured during apartheid and growing up didn't really fit into any any of the divisions within the various racial groups. "Born a Crime" is an enormously engaging memoir about the early years of Trevor Noah's life. Noah is the successful host of The Daily Show, the satirical American news show on Comedy Central. He was born in 1984 during apartheid in South Africa to a black Xhosa mother and a white Swiss father. His parents could have been jailed for five years for having a mixed race child, and Noah could have been sent to a state orphanage. He spent much of his childhood indoors at his grandmother's home with hi

An interesting, sometimes funny, sometimes sad look into a childhood in South Africa during the apartheid era. I learned a lot about what it meant to be mixed race in South Africa during that time, and I now have a new appreciation for Trevor Noah. Very good narration. Powerful story.

It matters that Trevor Noah, the South African comedian Jon Stewart named as his successor as host of The Daily Show, subtitles his book ‚ÄúStories from A South African Childhood.‚Äù This book will teach its readers the ins and outs of growing up in apartheid and then post-apartheid South African, but because it shows us the way life was by telling amazing stories, it is neither didactic nor preachy. Instead, Noah just tells his stories, often with his trademark sense of humor. By reading his book I

Born a Crime is one of the best audio books that I have ever listened to. Trevor Noah's narration made this so entertaining, that hearing of his experiences as a biracial child growing up in a very racist and restrictive South Africa was easier to digest. Noah points out the significant differences in the intricacies of the way apartheid instituted racism in comparison to how racism is instituted in America. I am not well versed in the way South Africans have dealt with and tried to move forward

Trevor Noah and I are the same age. That's something I kept thinking to myself over and over as I read this memoir: the guy who wrote this is my age. And he lived and survived everything he talks about in here... Few books have made me as painfully aware of how cushioned my life actually is than this one.

Just like Trevor, I was 5 or 6 when the end of apartheid was declared, and I had no idea what that meant. All I knew was that my hippie parents were delighted and that meant I was happy as well,

From the moment he was born, Trevor Noah was an "other" - someone who defies cultural norms and doesn't fit into established patterns. Combine this with apartheid's racist restrictions in his South African home, and Noah has plenty of stories to tell. Through each story, the reader learns both funny and touching details of his reality.

Noah could have become an angry young man, but instead he chose to find humor in the difficulties. That instinct came directly from his mother, who mixed tough di

Trevor Noah is a successful comedian and the host of The Daily Show. Of South African descent, his childhood and upbringing were anything but easy. Born to a white Swiss father and a black Xhosa mother, during Apartheid, his birth was a crime. He spent the first years of his life in hiding, for his discovery could land his parents in jail and him in foster care. This is the story of his struggles and how he prevailed over them.

Part coming-of-age story, part memoir and part history lesson, this w

This book is a must-read/listen for every South African -- and also anyone interested in learning about African History!

Listening to this story was like having Trevor Noah in my living room, sharing some tea and rusks. A brilliant tale of growing up during the Apartheid era - not something I was affected by - and the impact it had on his family and lifestyle. These are the anecdotes which should be shared with our youth so that they have perspective on how fortunate their lives are today.

Nothing Like I Imagined


Since this is a collection of quick personal essays I‚Äôve decided to review them all in one swoop anthology style.


Please Like Me (But Keep Away) - 4 Stars - This essay reviews the time when Mindy moved to LA to write for the office and had to find/make friends as an adult. A most daunting task indeed. She speaks of wanting a close group of girlfriends and even her experience in trying to join one and of how she somehow ended up with a male BFF. Making
Funny essay about a night out with BJ Novak and a homeless person. So funny! I just love the way she tells a story!

Mindy's obviously a great storyteller and as I was reading, I could just picture everything that played out, almost as if I were watching a show; I could totally see how each essay could be turned into one-off episodes on YouTube. Anyways, the drifter incident was bizarre and the Mindy-B.J. duo were hilarious, but the best part was how Mindy summed up her reaction to the drifter (and all of his weirdness) with a "y tho?".

3.5 stars. I'm giving all 6 essays in this collection the same rating since it *is* a collection. Mindy is a fantastic writer but I mostly found this collection "meh". Perhaps it's because there were only 6 so I felt dissatisfied--I don't know. I just didn't feel as connected to her as I did in her previous books. I'd still recommend the collection--it's a fast and light read, and Mindy's writing voice is extremely personable.

Once Upon a Time in Silver Lake is one of the six-part Nothing Like I Imagined collection of autobiographical short comedy essays by Mindy Kaling available through Amazon Originals.
Those short stories are fantastic! They are perfect to read while talking a break from intense studying. My brain loves this.

The general review: a series of essays that don't quite add up to the length of her two prior outings, each bite is nevertheless a nice look into Mindy Kaling's life and thoughts. She's been more or less a part of the pop culture landscape since The Office, which is a long time, and her works are worth reading.

This...seemed out of place. Less an essay, more of an interesting podcast story in and of itself (ooh...how meta). The note about how Mindy never wants to listen to podcasts but wants to h

Drifter Chronicles!

My 5th short story read from Mindy on her super wierd yet super funny encounter with a homeless/drifter man and her friend,  B. J.. I can literally visualize how Mindy and B. J. from 'The Office' would have enacted such a scene.

The nice part about Mindy's writing is she shares simple stories about her life, ties it back to some lesson she learned or an observation about the larger truth of the world. This coupled with her writing makes it relatable and hence it works!

This part of the series had a lot of references I didn't get. The story also seemed pointless to me; except for her own condition at the time and her surprising, real bravado! That's a treat to look out for.

The other parts in this series are better than this one and have more substance.
It is mysterious though and like a scene from a movie, the events play out perfectly; much like fiction!

This short story was about a weird, funny story that happened to Mindy and B.J. Novak. I really enjoyed it and it was a fun story to hear, but it felt a little out of place. It's kind of a different wavelength from the other stories she has shared so far, and I feel like it shouldn't have been a standalone. But either way I enjoyed it.

Nice quick lunchtime read. I wasn't sure what to expect as I've only seen one or two movies that she's been in and sad to say I've never watched any of her tv shows, but I am familiar enough with her style of humor to be intrigued enough to read this short story. Nothing extremely spectacular, but a nice quick break from reality when/if you need it.

Short, sweet, and to the point. The tidbit about Manson and one of the Beach Boys was trippy. Not my favorite in the series to be honest. I sort of want to see this written as a fictional story though.

Mindy Kaling's latest series of essays are just as insightful and witty as her memoirs. Each essay has a different theme, though I'm reviewing the set as opposed to individual essays.

I love Mindy Kaling so I'm really excited to listen to this series!

We call it different things but it all sort of boils down to this weird, innate need to understand what in the hell we're meant to be doing here. We, as a species, really can't seem to bear the idea that there isn't some grand plan in place that would explain the casual suffering, the loneliness, the soul destroying pain we all suffer through. I hope you will allow me to tell a little story here. Some years back, I was going through a bad time with my mental health. It‚Äôs been, what feels like a lifelong struggle, but this was a particularly rough period. I had been in the hospital and was then moved to a sort of group home to recover more. One of the counselors there had two stories by Allie Brosh printed out and we read them as part of a group activity. They were about depression and were real and sad and funny.

I read Hyperbole and a Half at a time when I didn‚Äôt know I was depressed, but I found the comics ~relatable~ and funny. Now, I am fully aware, and Allie Brosh has crushed my heart to pieces again.

Solutions and Other Problems is so potent. It is, at times, the view inside my own brain. But also not. Brosh had a lot of terrible life experiences in the years between her first book and this one, out in September. She lays it all bare, alongside some fun comics about being a weird kid and having

I've been waiting for this book for so long, and I don't think it could have come at a more perfect (or needed) time. Allie Brosh opened my eyes with Hyperbole and a Half: Unfortunate Situations, Flawed Coping Mechanisms, Mayhem, and Other Things That Happened so many years ago, and while this tome is definitely tinged with more darkness, it a worthy successor.

Now that I'm a mother to two of my own impetuous children who, while not probably quite on the "Richard" level of creepy, definitely give

I think it's safe to say a lot has happened to Allie Brosh in the seven years everyone I know spent going, "Man, I just hope Allie Brosh is doing well, wherever she is." And this book really peels back the layers on that -- there are funny chapters and heartrending chapters and chapters that talk about truly awful things in small, simple sentences that sit there in your head like a rock.

Basically, this book is a testament to the power of keeping on, even when things are awful, and also on being

Absolutely worth the wait, and everyone's going to connect with a different story here. Favorites of mine that had me cackling included "Cat," "Richard," "Bananas," and "Loving Kindness." There is, in the middle of the book, the big "what happened to Allie in the last 7 years," which some of us who are periodic Googlers of her to make sure she's been okay know, but for many others, it'll be clear why she completely disappeared.

I loved this and I loved laughing, but I will say the unpopular thing

I feel bad giving this graphic novel such a low rating, especially when considering all the author went through since she published her first book, some of the traumatic events detailed in this one. I liked her first book very much as it achieved a fine balance between sadness and lightheartedness that seems to be lacking in this current book. For the most part, this book was a downer, even when the author was relating stories that were supposed to be funny. Not much of it was humorous to me, an

The long-awaited follow up to "Hyperbole and a Half" is at times funny, at times heartbreaking, and at times muddled. I think if you are looking for a "spiritual sequel" to Hyperbole and a Half or a book with the same well-cultivated, insightful humor and insight on childhood, adulthood and even serious topics like depression, you may be disappointed.

Considering the events in the author's private life which occurred in between the book's initial conception and the final release date, it is not s

I suspect many people will say this book isn't coherent or that it's a little bit all over the place, and that may be true but it is also exactly what the book intends to be. The whole point here is for Brosh to throw some not-entirely-coherent feelings at us and she makes that quite clear up front. Wanting something focused and clear isn't really in keeping with a book that is about how everything is actually terrible and random and now what do we do once we realize that?

If you have wondering w

Five years ago, I was given a pre-order of this for my birthday, because of course I was looking forward to another Brosh book like anything. I am sorry that life got so very much in the author's way, although I think we're all painfully aware of how that can happen. If just about the only good thing to come out of 2020 is the new releases, still that's a lot of good.
I am eager to dive in, but I am waiting until Saturday morning when I can look forward to lots of reading time unimpeded by work

After a seven year absence, Allie Brosh returns with a whopping 500 pages of illustrated essays that range from hysterical to heartbreaking.

Brosh made a name for herself with Hyperbole and a Half, her website-turned-book of autobiographical essays/comics. Not only were the essays funny and occasionally poignant, but their MSPaint illustrations added a layer of fun to them.

Solutions and Other Problems is the follow-up fans have been waiting for. None of the humor has been lost(her pets are still

I read Hyperbole and a Half when it was a blog and bought the first book gleefully when it came out. I reread several stories so many times (The Year Kenny Loggins Ruined Christmas and The Scariest Story were my favorites) for various reasons related to my own childhood, I guess. I didn't preorder this one when it was first announced, but I do remember seeing the release date stretch on and on, and I remember how sad I was. I googled "what happened to allie brosh" more than once since she disapp

Looks like I'm the dissenter on this one.

Hyperbole and a Half was, by turns, poignant, clever, insightful, and gut-bustingly funny. Some of the best sections involved the author discussing her battle with depression. While painful to read, there was a stunning clarity to the work. Through anecdotes and analogies, Brosh painted a comprehensible picture of a land which, thank God, I've never had to visit.

It's fairly clear, from the content of Solutions and Other Problems, that Brosh's life has tak

I tried I tried I tried to pace out the reading of this, to savor it, but two days was the best I could do.

However, that's okay. There's so much here that I know I will be revisiting. Some chapters are so funny I was nearly crying. Others are so sad that I'm still sitting with the weight of them. Brosh writes about death, isolation, loneliness, pointlessness. This is, somehow, a very 2020 book, despite being seven years in the making.

I said in my review for a 2019 reread of Hyperbole and a Half
*pterodactyl screeching*

30% the funniest things I have read in years, 70% absolutely devastating emotional stuff, I feel like I‚Äôve been blended.

Note that it goes pretty hard into grief (death of a sibling), nihilism, references to divorce and serious chronic illness. The author is very clearly writing out of being super depressed and having some seriously bad things happen, and while I found most of that extremely relatable it might be more depressing for you.

Pictures definitely worth a thousand words and there are 1

Who has not seen the comics/stories by Allie Brosh? Case in point:

I was a follower of her blog, which is also the title of her first book (Hyperbole and a Half) and loved her work. But then she practically disappeared right when her book became a best seller. It was strange and worrying. This second book explains a lot about why she seemingly fell off the face of the earth for years, and well, it's not a humorous story unfortunately for her. And it's also a little unfortunate for the re
Her last book was one one my absolute favorites. Can't wait for this one.

Allie's blog (we are clearly on first-name basis, and would be g

I loved Hyperbole and a Half, but this follow-up stumbled too much for me.

I enjoyed the first 150 pages pretty well despite a long and useless (day)dream sequence, but then the blocks of teeny-tiny typeset text started multiplying in frequency and size during a nothing story about cross-country skiing and arguments. More and more little words saying nothing much of anything. And then I started gritting my teeth every time those blocks came back throughout the rest of the books.

After the touching

I kept trying to walk away from this book because I wanted it to last.

I want(ed) more of a 514 page book.

You know the Leonard Cohen quote about a crack in everything?

This book is the crack in 2020 that will have lifted me enough to keep me going.

That is all.

Solutions and Other Problems by Allie Brosh is so terrific! I loved the first book and this one is just as good! Laugh out loud funny in spots to deep heart warming in others. Loved the clever and hilarious cartoons graphics! The cartoons alone are quite a hoot!

Solutions and Other Problems, Allie Brosh‚Äôs follow-up to her critically acclaimed first book, Hyperbole and a Half, had a lot to live up to.  Like many people, I‚Äôve been waiting for this book for years.  The book had been plagued with delays leaving her readers believing that the book may never actually see the light of day.

Then, out of nowhere, the book was scheduled for release in September of 2020.  Finally!  Something good in this horror show of a year.  However, as the content of the book s

This book is for the goofy blob people we were ten years ago who are now facing or have already faced really hard things.

I think many longtime fans of Brosh knew that the reasons for the book's delay and anticipated some of its content being different as a result, and like many, I'm just so grateful that it exists, and that Allie exists with us still. This book is different from the first -- less "adulting! i am the god of cake!" and more "mortality and loss and complex human loneliness o no" --

I laughed, I cried, and I felt very seen by this book. At the end of the day, Brosh is a master at communicating the sheer absurdity of life. She captures the way things can feel pointless, meaningless, and unfair even as we have to continue moving forward.

ebook

Harder to love than the first one. An intimate look at a gal who has had more than her share of trouble coping with the way her brain works. In some ways, I'm sure we can all relate, and in other ways, I'm sure we all say "thank goodness I'm not that confused/ disturbed/ ill."

But it's not exploitive or anything, not a daytime talk show confessional. It's glorious, heartbreaking, gorgeous, funny, and incredibly illuminating.

I feel as if I know myself and my loved ones better now, even those

I excitedly pre-ordered this the second I saw a September 2020 release date. I've always loved the Hyperbole and a Half blog, and seeing that this was able to come together after all of this time made me so happy (and hopeful that the author was doing better).

I have loved her ever since 2010, when I stumbled across her Hyperbole and a Half blog and proceeded to laugh so hard I sounded like I was sobbing over something heartbreaking. Her words brought so many giggles into my world when I was most in need of them, and when she disappeared for several years, I thought of her every so often and hoped she was happy.

I liked a lot of Solutions and Other Problems. Looking back at my review of Hyperbole and a Half, I see that I really didn't enjoy that one. Not sure if it was my head space a year ago when I read that or if this book is that much better but Brosh is a great storyteller and while the style is a bit unexpected compared to the typical graphic novel (large blocks of text!), everything works together somehow. OMG, could it be that 2020 will finally offer something good? That there will be one small ray of hope, one little piece of enjoyment this year? AND, just in time for the inevitable dumpster fire that will be the election? Will I really have something meaningful, poignant, and hilariously touching in my hands to help me get through that?

Well, apparently so. And I guess that all I have to say is this: whatever workings in the universe delayed this book so long, that's ok, I'm not mad at all, bec

Here are the major themes of this book:

-There‚Äôs no underlying purpose to the things that happen to us
-We are powerless, though we trick ourselves into thinking we have some level of control in our lives
-MORTALITY!!!!
-Life is unfair, and that‚Äôs just the way it is

All this nihilism is colored by Brosh‚Äôs trademark wit and humor, but there‚Äôs no denying that this book is significantly darker than her first. And who can blame her? She doesn‚Äôt talk about her trials in huge amounts of depth, but Brosh

Brosh has famously been absent from the internet (at least publicly) since 2013. Solutions and Other Problems chronicles the whys and hows of that, without feeling as though we‚Äôve been given too much access. We do get a view into her life, and more specifically her worldview, and all that‚Äôs changed and evolved since last we saw her. In some ways reading this felt like sitting down with a friend I hadn‚Äôt seen in a long time and just having an in-depth rambly conversation for a few hours to get ca

The existence of this book makes me so happy. The existence of Allie, too.

There are funny chapters, sad chapters, weird chapters, weird funny sad chapters. There's an explanation why Allie disappeared for so long and my immense happiness at her return. So much has happened, decades ago and months ago. It feels like being reunited with your best friend in the world ever (the final chapter talks about Allie's best friend in the world ever), demanding a COMPLETE update on everything, and getting it

The book is like asking a friend how they're doing and they tell you, and it's not good, and you feel so bad for them, but you were really hoping they were doing better and that they'd cheer YOU up, and you realize no, you need to be there for THEM.

If you want to know how Allie Brosh has been doing, this book will tell you. It won't make you laugh much, but it'll make you think, and probably worry.

I was cracking up during the first half of this book, and really saw more of Allie's struggle through the second half. Working through the death of a loved one is extremely hard, and the struggle with fear really resonated with me. Same with dealing with being alone.

Amused, sad, shocked, confused, bewildered, rolling on the floor laughing, deep introspection - sometimes all at the same moment.

This book really drives home the point that life is absurd. Sometimes it is absurdly silly. Sometimes it is absurdly sad. Always though, it is absurd.

This is a brilliant follow to her first book, and is something I think everyone should read.

Allie chooses to utilize her impressive artistic talents by drawing in a crude (yet surprisingly effective) style best described as ‚ÄúMS Paint,‚Äù which fools the reader into expecting content reflective the lighthearted style. Her latest book, however, deals with several life crises and philosophical dilemmas, illustrated in MS Paint style. It‚Äôs a bit of an emotional hammer, in between stories about goofy dogs and the weird kid next door.

In short, all those years I spent wondering occasional

I got this as a birthday present from my wonderful sister and devoured it within 24 hours of opening.
It made me explosively laugh-cry, which is a good thing. Allie Brosh is the perfect quarantine companion. We‚Äôve all gone to some weird, dark, and ridiculous places this year. She was there first and made this gift for us.
That Chapter made me a sobbing mess but it's fine

It was definitely an "I laughed, I cried" situation. Not as LOL as David Sedaris or Chelsea Handler. But much more heartfelt. I'm glad I read it. I especially liked the parts about befriending yourself and loneliness.
Amazing and ridiculous and the best amount of weird. I loved almost everything about this book!!

This is a memoir in which the author, while in law school and while having very dark thoughts, decides to seek help in the form of a group therapy session. Initially, therapy seems to do a lot of good for Tate. She‚Äôs forced to start talking about her issues with eating and sex, and the therapist (Dr. Rosen) helps her give voice to issues long left unspoken.

But as we go along, the therapist‚Äôs instructions and his role in the author‚Äôs life grows, especially as he suggests that she join additional

‚ÄúThe deep secret that I carried was that I didn‚Äôt belong. Anywhere. I spent half my days obsessing about food and my body and the weird shit I did to control both, and the other half trying

Giveaway Win!

I want to start this review off by saying that I don't think traditional forms of therapy are for everyone. I've tried going to therapy and I've tried taking anxiety medication and neither were for me. That does not mean that those things won't work for someone else. Mental health treatment is not a one size fits all type of thing.

For me these are the things that work for ME (these are not recommendations for anyone else)

1) taking time away (a day or two)from everyone (total solit
I love reading about other people's therapy, so was fascinated by this account of unconventional group therapy and its life-changing consequences.

Just what the doctor ordered to forget about the pandemic and no electricity- what‚Äôs better than reading about someone else‚Äôs crazy messed up life! Lots of humor and misery kept me engaged until the very last page!
Group is an engaging and entertaining read. The author goes deep as she brings us with her to group therapy sessions and shows how the difficult process of revealing personal secrets allowed her to develop more intimate relationships.

In this memoir, Christie Tate, a lawyer with an eat

I can‚Äôt really in good faith recommend this book to folks (unless you‚Äôre simply looking for non-fic that can be taken with a hefty grain of salt).

This was salacious and entertaining and... honestly kind of iffy.

Tate is a crassly funny narrator, and this book presents a no-holds-barred account of her experience with group therapy and coming to terms with traumatic memories and eating disorder recovery. I liked the metaphor of the scored heart that she uses throughout the book. Just like how one

This is a complex review for me!

I got to read this book as an ARC and I was super excited about it since I am first-year therapy graduate student. I think that I was coming at this book from a different angle. The book is from the perspective of a client in therapy, specifically group therapy. Christie is a very successful law student and professional who finds herself in need of help.

My main critique of this book (it is a memoir) was that I really struggled with ethical issues throughout the

I love reading advice columns and shows about people in therapy. I find the way people see their own problems fascinating, and I find them even more fascinating when taken through another person who is there to consider and possibly disagree with the way a person sees their problems. I am frustrated that I can't read a million books about people sharing their experiences in therapy. But I get it. Sometimes when I watch/read/hear these stories I think, "Wow, how can anyone be okay sharing this mu

‚ÄúMy turn, your turn. Back and forth. So this was how it happened. This was how you built an intimate relationship. Word by word. Story by story. Revelation by revelation. Just like group.‚Äù

An intimate debut memoir centering on group therapy and how opening up to strangers saved a life.

I‚Äôve often wondered how freeing it would be for a stranger or group of strangers to know my secrets. To have a group of people that did not hold back, judge or even tell you what to do. Simply a group of individuals
Thoughts soon.
Review to come but I definitely recommend this one.

This is difficult to rate because I didn't have any problems with the writing or how the author presented herself as a person, but the whole thing made my skin crawl. Everything Dr. Rosen did felt gross and unethical and over the line. There were so many times when Christie was about ready to quit going to group, and I was like "Good for you! Recognize that this isn't ok!" and then she always went back. I am glad that she ultimately got what she wanted and is in a good place. However, I don't th

I didn‚Äôt really ‚Äòfinish‚Äô this book as such, I gave up sixty pages in. If this is an actual memoir and not simply a piece of fiction, then there is a psychiatrist out there in the world somewhere that seriously shouldn‚Äôt be practicing. I am a huge supporter of therapy, but this type of ‚Äòtherapy‚Äô is unethical and just plain wrong. What a weird thing to decide to write about and share with others..

Oh wow. Five stars all the way around.

I know that several reviews I‚Äôve read are stuck on the ethics of Dr. Rosen and the way he chooses to practice in his group therapy, but you know what? It didn‚Äôt bother me. I see the value in the way he makes everyone uncomfortable and let‚Äôs them feel things and get angry and work through it as a team. Having a support system is so important. Having a place to go every week at an exact time to keep the feeling of purpose alive in people who are struggling to

This book was really uncomfortable to read. At times I also found it horrifying and disturbing. I applaud the author's desire to seek help, but the group she attended came across as "cult-ish" and/or something that would be endorsed by Gywenth Paltrow (Goop). Any group that requires you to come to their organization 3 times a week for 90 minutes $800/month screams cult-ish. This kind of "therapy" is not realistic or sustainable for the average person. Most people cannot dedicate that much time t

review_text:
I listened to the Audible version of the book, read by the author.

Memoirs are difficult when the writer comes across as unlikable, more so when that writer narrates her story. I suppose a certain amount of self-importance is necessary to assume one‚Äôs life is worth a story, unless you‚Äôre someone famous like Michelle Obama or you‚Äôve had an extraordinary life experience or deep insight, none of which applies to Christie Tate. She comes across as privileged and unlikable, but that wasn‚Äôt my biggest

Tate's evolution of self through totally honest, soul-baring & nontraditional-style group therapy will leave you feeling mentally taken apart & put back together. 'Group' is raw w/ insight & vulnerability & it was kind of therapeutic just reading it, as it creates a sense of hopefulness & positivity. Fantastic non-fic story!

As someone who has had therapy as a part of my life for as long as I can remember, I have always been fascinated by what it is like for other people. I am so grateful that especially during this last decade mental health and therapy have been normalized so much.

I started attending therapy when I was just a child during my parent's tumultuous and quite painful divorce. While it was something that was monumental in my ability to process many hard encounters and feelings, it was also a very isolati

****Now available!****

Thank you to Christie Tate and Simon & Schuster UK for a copy of the book in exchange for an honest review.

As I've said before: I LOVE a memoir. The more ordinary the person, the better! Me and nosey self just love a snoop into other peoples' lives and BOY did I get a snoop!

Christie is a law student battling with an eating disorder and intimacy issues and finally decides to take the plunge and start therapy. She is recommended Dr Rosen by one of her friends and she goes to
DNF at 22%. Just didn't care about all these different people in the group's complaints. Was grossed out by some of the therapist's the sexual comments.

Welp so, full transparency here, I have an eating disorder. I used to go to this awesome group a few years ago and now struggling to drag myself to this new group therapy. I tried reading this to find me some motivation to go, but it ended up being an upsetting read for me personally.

Dr. Rosen's therapies are strange and unorthodox and not alike anything you'd find normally. If you have questions about normal group therapy, ask google, your therapist, or myself. -- This book is not about anyone

This is quite a strange read and one that I alternately liked and didn't like.
It is extremely personal and I found the parts where there are lots of reference to sex a bit much.
I didn't particularly like the characters and found the whole American obsession with therapy hard to understand.
We basically join Christie on her journey, via group therapy with Dr Rosen, in her search for personal enlightenment and the opportunity to free herself from a lifetime of crushing self-doubt, self-harm and lac
I would go with 4.5. Refreshing and honest - and full of hope.

I usually do not read memoirs, but one of my friends is a librarian and had an advanced copy of this book. As a retired psychotherapist, I have to question some of Dr. Rosen's techniques and ethics. He could have directed the group to intervene more and could have helped the author better handle her emotional outbursts, which were over the top, creating havoc in her life, and really distressing to her. While I agree with his stance on not keeping secrets, I would hope readers understand that go

I have no idea who Christie Tate is but reading her memoir was perhaps one of the most intimate experiences I‚Äôve ever felt reading about someone else‚Äôs life. Group is raw, powerful, funny, tear-jerking, and honest. I flew through the pages in a few short hours soaking it all in; every page left me wanting to know more, read further. I 100% recommend for a cathartic reading experience!

I'm no stranger to recovery memoirs or tales of therapy but I can honestly say I've never read a book like this before! Unpredictable, heartfelt and absorbing, I read this book and can't stop thinking about it.

Book was " off" for me. Something fishy about it.
Group was not a book for me. I just could not connect with the information or the author. The information felt too forced for my liking.

"I can be mad at you and still love you, you know"
No, actually, I didn't know that. I had no idea.

There are so many revelations like the one above in Group: How One Therapist and a Circle of Strangers Saved My Life by Christie Tate that made me realize how much we assume how others feel.

Christie Tate had just been named the top student in her law school class and had her eating disorder under control at last. Why then was she driving through Chicago fantasizing her own death? Enter Dr. Jonathan Rosen, a therapist who calmly assured her that if she joins one of his psychotherapy groups, he can transform her life. All she has to do is show up and be honest. So begins her entry into the strange, terrifying and life-changing world of group therapy. ( trigge

I just loved this. It was so entertaining that I flew through it in one weekend. But I offer one caveat: this therapist seems certifiably nuts. While I‚Äôve never been to therapy, some of his prescriptions and recommendations seem so far off. That said, everything seemed to work out for our memoirist here and I‚Äôm stunned that she chose to share these same (and embarrassing) stories with the world. Group seemed safe enough... at one point it seemed the entire city of Chicago would have known all he

Christie Tate has always been an overachiever. She buried herself in her textbooks and earned first place in her class at Loyola Law. She lands a plum job working for one of the nation‚Äôs leading law firms, but Christie wants more. All her life she has had trouble building and maintaining close relationships. She longs for a family and wishes for death. Told by her mother not to share her personal business, she nonetheless seeks help from Dr. Rosen who assigns her to one of his groups.
A raw, hone

I am found this memoir such an interesting read. I have never had therapy for myself so it‚Äôs an interesting look into a probably less conventional group. I‚Äôm not sure Group Therapy would be for me but I do like the idea of everyone working together.

Thank you Simon & Schuster Canada and Netgalley for my review copy.

Bravo! I‚Äôve read and loved many memoirs but this one was hands-down my favorite. If I had to sum it up in one word I would call it CATHARTIC.

Dr. Rosen insists his clients tell all because anything less is more toxic than everyone knowing your business so Tate bears all to her quirky, Einstein-like therapist and six strangers - from bulimia to her childhood friend‚Äôs father drowning to finding a man who will love her. It‚Äôs raw. It

To start, this is intimidating to write a review that has the potential to be taken to group! I am sure Dr. Rosen would have something interesting to say about my fear.

That being said, this book was just this book for me. I neither liked nor disliked it. At times it made me uncomfortable, while at times I identified with it. The writing was uneven and at times confusing. It was also, strangely intriguing and relatable at times.

I am not sorry I finished it, but not sure I would ever read it again

Therapy is an essential part of getting to the core roots of your problems and essentially taking back your life. I personally have never done group therapy but Christine Tate has hit the nail on the head. Her experience with group therapy after overcoming anorexia is quite an achievement. Any one who has experienced depression and suicidal thought can relate to this book. I think the unconventional way that her therapist ran the group saved quite a few people. I give this amazing book five star

Thank you #Netgalley for the advanced copy.

Wow! I loved following the progression of Christie and really seeing therapy work for her. The concept of this group therapy seemed so unique! I applaude Christie and the others in the group share such personal things and to really make connections and force each other out of their comfort zone. So many things seemed so relatable about her thought process, but she trusted in the program and it ended up working for her.

I LOVED, loved, loved this book!

Thank you to Simon & Schuster for this advanced reading copy--I was SO excited to win it, as these types of books are my jam! (anything, pretty much, person growth oriented). Though one never knows if they will be any good.

To my utter surprise...wow, Ms. Tate can write. Much has and will be made of the content/material about which she writes. But writing-wise, she definitely is far more skilled than I expected from her being a hotshot lawyer (her career in this me

Group - How one therapist and a circle of strangers saved my life // by Christie Tate

Sometimes I come across titles or blurbs that leave me thinking "THIS WAS WRITTEN JUST FOR ME." Now, I'm not that delusional that I think that is literally true but I still wonder if someone, something, somewhere had me in mind when this book idea came into existence. For someone that was not even into memoirs until last year, I sure to race through them at full speed now, especially those related to mental heal

I've read three "therapy" books in the last 18 months. I think I'm hungry for stories of transformation, to be reminded that change is possible. Of these, "Maybe You Should Talk to Someone" is still my favorite, but I really enjoyed Group.

Unlike the other therapy books I've read, Group is written from the POV of a patient, not the therapist; it is the story of Christie, a high-achieving law student who is rated #1 in her class and secretly falling apart. When a friend recommends that she go to a

So I‚Äôve been rolling this review around in my head since I finished the book, and to be honest I‚Äôm still not sure where I land. From a strictly entertainment standpoint, it was good. I listened to it and found myself really looking forward to the times when I could get back to the story. Christie is no holds barred- and from what she shares in the book we know that complete honestly was something she struggled with before therapy so for her openness, I applaud her. That said, I love to get deep

I am not quite sure what to make of this book, on the one hand it is honest, well written and ultimately uplifting, on the other hand it is a gross invasion of others‚Äô privacy, disturbing to read and I could have done without the yucky intimate details of her sex life. I wonder if part of my distaste is that engaging with therapy appears to be mainstream in the USA whereas it is less common in the UK.
Certainly Christie suffered from post traumatic stress disorder after she witnessed a friend‚Äôs f

This book was right up my alley topic wise, and that aspect of it was fine. Nothing groundbreaking, the writing is okay, and the stories were also okay. There is a lot of emphasis on sex and intimacy which I wasn‚Äôt expecting, kudos to Tate for putting her bare life out there for everyone to read. It did get repetitive towards the end where the behaviours were repeating themselves just in different ways, but as is the nature of mental illness I guess.

BUT, my biggest concern with the book is Dr R

this book is fun to read because it's messy, but wow is the author a narcissist. I have seen people criticize the book because she mentioned group members stories, but honestly it's mainly about her and her boring life. Her life is not interesting, its the average mid 20 year old woman experience, she just breaks a few more plates. Her fellow peers sound way more complex and I was very worried while reading it about the ways the therapist could be taking advantage of their emotional state. That

Some of the stories and fears shared in this was great and it definitely had some LOL moments; however, there must be some kind of rules broken by the therapist who leads the group when she starts over sharing to the participants in group. If I was going to support, I would feel creeped out when the therapist is taking over and spilling her guts. Still a worthy read for people that find comfort for their issues in a setting like this but it may not be for all.

Goof writing and some stories but ta

"Group" is an intimate memoir exploring author Christie Tate's experience with mental ill health and an eating disorder, and the support she found in an unconventional group setting. Whilst therapist Dr Rosen's methods seem unorthodox, there is clearly validity in his approach. Tate really opens herself up, exposing her vulnerability in a warts and all manner. Yes, this makes for an uncomfortable read in places but I figure if Christie has taken the time to bare her soul, the least I can do as a

An engaging and entertaining memoir of one woman‚Äôs experiences with the healing power of group therapy. The author goes deep as she brings us with her to her sessions and shows how the difficult process of revealing her most personal secrets allowed her to develop more intimate relationships.

Listened on audiobook. I enjoyed this book and had no trouble with the pace of the story, but unlike the book ‚ÄúMaybe You Should Talk to Someone‚Äù I didn‚Äôt put it down feeling like I had many, structured actionable lessons or takeaways from Christie‚Äôs story. There certainly are lessons but it didn‚Äôt feel like the story was written with those in mind.

The whole time I was reading this I was wondering - why am I so invested in the author‚Äôs relationship history? But I couldn‚Äôt put it down, and flew through it in just a couple sittings. Her story isn‚Äôt exactly remarkable, but it was told in such a way that kept me engaged and curious (and laughing), and hoping for her sake that her group therapy would finally ‚Äúwork.‚Äù

This book was a really honest and absorbing exploration of group therapy, and the impact it has on people. At times it was an uncomfortable read, and covered a lot of issues from eating disorders, to trauma, to sexuality and attachment issues in a lot of visceral detail. Overall the story was really interesting, and the personal development of the characters made me keep coming back for more. Not for the faint hearted! Overall I enjoyed this.

I read Group by Christie Tate via Pigeonhole, which released a stave a day for 10 days. I have never been in therapy and have no intentions of ever seeking help from a therapist. I was fortunate to receive a copy of this ARC from Pigeonhole.

It feels wrong somehow to review an autobiographical book, because what right do I have to critique someone's life?!

However, I did find this a difficult read. The therapy setting in America is very different to my experiences in the UK, even group therapy, and some of the work done was quite shocking. It didn't always feel like Christie was receiving the right support and some of Dr Rosen's treatments seemed ethically and morally
Found the author to be self-centred, self-indulgent, attention seeking, over sharing and was uncomfortable reading this book.

This is different from any book I‚Äôve ever read. I read it in a group, and have to admit to getting annoyed a few times with people judging the author and her therapist on his ways of dealing with the group he was leading. I admit it was a different way of handling his group as therapists usually go with secrecy. I am not going to say I enjoyed the book. But I can say it was well written and there was times I could put myself in Christie‚Äôs place. I gave it 3 stars. And I would recommend it.

I don't really know how to review this book. "Enjoy" seems the wrong word. It's a very honest memoir of a person's journey through therapy. Lots of the author's thoughts and feelings really resonated with me so it was sometimes a difficult read. Overall I'm glad I stuck with it.

The group therapy angle of this book had me hooked, especially this being a memoir. Christie made me laugh, cry, and feel. Read this book if you want to feel something.

Okay so let me start out by saying I did have high hopes for this book. I love self-improvement and I was hoping I could learn something. I was under the impression is was majority non-fiction and factual. After about the half way point I was confused.

I believe this book is a blend of memoir and fiction (I‚Äôm really not sure how it falls into non-fiction). It does explain the behaviour of a very strange therapist who

Group by Christie Tate is a free NetGalley ebook that I read in early October.

Overstressed suicidal author Tate goes to group therapy to sort things out. She's initially reluctant to share things, be asked questions, acknowledge a complicated relationship with food, then gradually sharing all her inner stressors, realizing her inner worth and reasons for living.

Christie Tate is at the top of her law school class, but unfortunately, she still just isn‚Äôt happy. When her friend tells her about her group therapy, Christie decides why not give this Dr. Rosen a chance. Now she is meeting with a group of 6 people every week and telling them everything about her and her life. Christie is put off by some of Dr. Rosen‚Äôs ideas at first, but over time she comes to love these people like family. Doesn‚Äôt mean she doesn‚Äôt hate them at some times too.

Group: How One Therapist and a Circle of Strangers Saved My Life by Christie Tate was a really interesting exploration of the author's experience with group therapy. Going into this, I knew very little about what group therapy actually looked like. That said, this was also a very unique therapy experience, so the book is really about exploring the author's specific experiences versus a commentary on any type o

I've done a huge amount of therapy, both group and individual, in my life time. I enjoy learning about other's experiences and what they may have picked up during their time in therapy. Everyone has different needs for therapy and I appreciate the way people can learn from each other. The account just seems extreme and far fetched. I don't want to down play or criticize someone else's experience and I'm very glad this worked for the author. But my deeply personal opinion is that I would have lef

I really enjoyed this author's voice, but did not enjoy the read at all. Tate expressed herself well and I felt like she was the friend you talk about saying "She's such a great catch, why can't she find a man?" I wanted to relate to her, but as soon as life takes a turn she doesn't like, she is literally on the floor screaming like a toddler in the middle of her group therapy. I couldn't sympathize with her and I also couldn't get behind Dr. Rosen's method. It felt like she spent 5+ years being

Thank you to Avid Reader Press and Simon and Schuster for sending me this ARC to review.

I laughed, I cried, I got mad, and I cared a lot about the characters in reading this book. Christie Tate has really put her life out there in this memoir. The book starts with her fixation with wanting to die. This then leads to her sharing of her struggles with bulimia, anxiety, depression, social angst and lack of relationships (both friends and romance). The back drop for this book is mainly Dr. Rosen's

Group is an interesting memoir on the experience of group therapy.

Tate is a skillful autobiographical writer, approaching her subject with brutal honesty and striking just the right balance between humour and misery. Her story makes for a compulsive, engaging read.

The therapy itself made me a little uncomfortable at times, with Dr Rosen's unconventional approach and problematic line-crossing. In many ways it was a bit like reading about a cult.

But red flags aside, it was interesting to see the e

When I started reading Group I assumed it was fiction. Imagine my surprise and awe when 1/4 way in I realised it is a memoir. This is a layered account of Christie Tate's all out efforts to create meaningful relationships in her own life. She came to her first group, having made quite clear to the therapist that she wanted to end her life, and if group therapy didn't work within five years, she would do so. So she raged, loved and crumpled at rejection - all witnessed and supported by her group

Loved this memoir!! So brutally honest and refreshing. Also very funny! I laughed out loud in parts :) Group is all about the authors journey through years of group therapy with a bunch of very unique individuals and a quirky therapist. I just fell love with everyone by the end of the book and kind of wanted to go to Group myself :)

Personally I had a hard time finishing this book .I did not care for the way the the therapy Dr led this group or much of the advise given . I am thankful for the oppotunity I had to read this book, however this was a book I did not personally enjoy.
I received this book as a giveaway on Good Reads. I am glad the author received so meny 5 star reviews as it makes me know meny meny people loved and learned from the path this particular therapy group went through. Thank you .

This book is all kinds of ridiculous! I honestly don‚Äôt think I‚Äôd believe half the stuff Christie did or heard or saw in group therapy if I wasn‚Äôt in therapy myself.

Christie particular mental illnesses are addressed not just in the therapy setting but in flashbacks that add to the memoir quality of the book.

My only qualm was the what felt unnecessary obsession with everything sex. I feel like I get that enough on TV and movies and now books. It just felt like a lot, even though I know it was on

I received this book from the giveaway. This was an interesting ride. I enjoy memoirs and I enjoy books about therapy but this one wasn't my style. I'm not sure for whom this book was written. Christie Tate gets very real and honest and explicit about her past and relationships. I felt it was a little heavy on sex and, as almost everyone has mentioned, the therapist in this book raises some alarms. This is why I am only giving three stars: I doubt most people can relate to Christie's experience

I won this book on Goodreads. Unfortunately I didn't like the style of writing and could not finish the book.

Mommy blogger Christie Tate (aka Outlaw Mama) recounts her earlier years in her debut memoir, GROUP.

On the day that she is named top of her class in law school, Christie wants to die. Thoughts of self-harm have been floating in her head for some time. She can‚Äôt form a lasting romantic relationship or any type of personal connection. She can talk about football and the weather with her family, but nothing more substantial. She fills this void in her life by immersing herself in her work. She also

I love books about psychology and memoirs, and this book combined that. I was really amazed that the author was so good-looking, because the way she described herself, I had the image of a really fat woman with enormous breasts. I guess that may say something about her self-image. I've never been a fan of group therapy, since it means that the therapist's attention is divided among all the members of the group, and in most groups you have ignorant or naive people spouting their opinions about ot

Purchased this book rather than wait for a library copy as I usually find Reese‚Äôs Book Club picks to be good and thought it might rank up there with Lori Gottlieb‚Äôs ‚ÄúMaybe You Should Talk to Someone‚Äù. I was thoroughly disappointed and rest assured ‚ÄúGroup‚Äù doesn‚Äôt compare at all to Gottlieb‚Äôs masterpiece. Firstly, as a non-fiction memoir of sorts by author Christie Tate it frightens me terribly of how she has relied/ relies on her psychotherapist and the various ( and there are many ) therapy gro

This memoir is one working professionals account of her personal experience seeking help with intimacy, self-harm, and an eating disorder with group therapy in the early 2000s. If I had to give this a rating I would say 3 STARS out of 5.

I have extreme interest in the mental health field and thus based my decision to read this memoir on the fact it is author Christie Tates personal account of her many years in group therapy. Having earned my degree in psychological sciences I feel inclined to que

In this memoir we experience an unusual version of group therapy through the experiences of Christie.
Christie is suffering from passive suicidal ideation and has a history of eating disorders.
Her key issue seems to be ‚Äústuckness‚Äù an emotional inability to attach, or form an egalitarian relationship with a future male partner.
Her initial and ongoing wish when seeking therapy is to score her slippery heart, to be able to find love and be truly loved in return.

In this memoir we experience an unusual version of group therapy through the experiences of Christie.
Christie is suffering from passive suicidal ideation and has a history of eating disorders.

‚ÄòThis is Going to Hurt‚Äô (2017) is essentially Adam Kay‚Äôs account of his time as a junior doctor in the UK‚Äôs National Health Service.

This is a non-fiction read all about the NHS and the way that the system works. It's told in a diary format from the years when Adam Kay was a junior doctor and was part of the system. We see how the NHS has been struggling as time goes on to keep up the standards and staff levels, and we see the strain it can take on a doctor. We also get to see the way that Adam Kay dealt with many of the tests on his own time and relationships.

This Is Going to Hurt is the best-selling memoir of junior doctor turned writer/comedian Adam Kay, about his experiences working in obstetrics & gynaecology in the NHS. It should be required reading for any person contemplating a career in medicine, and their parents if they‚Äôre still a teenager, which most would-be doctors still are in the UK. 'It's funny - you don't think of doctors getting ill.'
It's true, and I think it's part of something bigger: patients don't actually think of doctors as being human.

I agree with all the reviewers who call it "hilariously heartbreaking" or "painfully funny" - these phrases capture the essence of the book very well.

This book should be required reading for anyone thinking about studying medicine and becoming a doctor.

experiences as a junior doctor, everything from his early days to becoming a registrar and then his decision to quit medicine

This book. This damn book. It appeared on my Goodreads feed as a recommendation in non-fiction, and I randomly decided to flip through it to see if I like it, I was hooked right away. I'm not going to review this book. I'm just going to say read it - you need to. I'm going to be thinking about it for a very long time.

Yes there are some funny bits, and lots of gross disgusting tales - you'd expect that - it's all part of a doctor's day-to-day life. What's important is the insiders view of what working for the NHS is like - the highs and terrible lows, the long hours and the strain on personal relationships. Doctors are heroes and often that is something people forget.

I laughed out loud, but also cringed reading about some of his experiences as a doctor. A book that sheds some light on what it's like to be a doctor in the UK, the hard work, the endless hours, the responsibility, as well as the shortcomings of the system. If a Romanian doctor wrote a book about the system in our country, it would definitely be a tragedy, where people get even sicker or die at the end. But that's another story.

A hilarious, eye-opening account of a junior doctor working for the NHS. We all sort-of-know-something about the NHS and those who work in our hospitals, but we rarely, if never, learn anything with this much honesty.

Sad, raw account of the life and untimely death of Paul Kalanithi, neurosurgeon.., there are so many reviews on this book, so I really needn't add more. I really liked reading about the surgeries he performed and his life as a resident. A good read.

It has been a phenomenal year of great reading, and this memoir stands near the pinnacle of that list. A neurosurgeon in the prime of his life discovers he has Stage 4 lung cancer. And then decides to write about his final two years. As Abraham Verghese writes in the Foreword, "See what courage looks like."

I spent my career years as a Registered Nurse and always considered that I was someone dedicated and compassionate towards those for whom I cared, but as Paul Kalanithi explains in this wise and lyrical account it is remarkable how quickly and dramatically our perception of terminal illness changes when the patient is us or someone in our own family. Paul is a gifted young neurosurgeon who confronts the life threatening conditions of others daily , and whose own life is tragically cut short. Bef

A short and powerful memoir about living in the face of death.

At 36 years old, neurosurgeon Paul Kalanithi was diagnosed with stage IV lung cancer. When Breath Becomes Air was written in his final months. In this thoughtful and deeply personal memoir, Dr. Kalanithi explains the questions of life-and-death that drove him to become a neurosurgeon. Over the course of the book, he ponders the role of the doctor and what makes life meaningful enough to go on living.

The physician‚Äôs duty is not to s

Memoir of a cancer patient which is not depressing or seeking for sympathy. Rather it is full of life, experiences and eventually death.

Paul was diagnosed with a cancer in his lungs. From being a neurosurgeon himself, he became a patient in an instant. He studied literature/philosophy in order to understand what makes life meaningful and neuroscience to understand how brain could give rise to an organism capable of finding meaning in the world.

Despite the diagnosis, he continued his practice be

(Any quotations were transcribed by me from the audio so it is possible there are inaccuracies.)

I read this not long after reading Being Mortal: Medicine and What Matters in the End, and that is the order I would recommend reading the two books. I do think they pair nicely together. When Breath Becomes Air has changed my life. No, that's not an extreme statement. When your perspective is broadened, your thinking changes, and your own way of living opens up for self-examination. All of this impacts how you move forward with your life...thus the change.

Paul Kalanithi's memoir offers perspective about living in regards to the detached medical science of function, the philosophy and theology of being present, and the desperate need we all have to process and feel human emotion.

This is one of those books that's difficult to give a poor rating to. Does a substandard review criticise the subject matter, the style, a life?

In this case, I found the style of writing tedious, I'm a voracious reader but the flow of my reading pace was often broken in looking up a word here or there as Paul used quite, we'll be honest, pretentious words and references which made him harder to relate to. He wanted to come across as well educated and intelligent, and yes he did, however, it's d

Wow-What a book! Paul Kalanithi was such a brilliant, courageous and inspiring man. To have written this book after his diagnosis and living in great pain is such a testament to the person he was. He was always trying to give to other people, whether it was through his practice as a neurosurgeon or in writing his story for this book.
I believe this novel is as much about living as it is about dying. Living a purposeful life- a life with meaning. Always moving forward even under unthinkable circu

Oddly heartwarming and incredibly insightful, this book is the ultimate read for anyone feeling a little lost in the chaos of life.
I don't have any words that could do this book or Paul Kalanithi any justice, so I'll let Paul do the speaking here:
"Human knowledge is never contained in one person. It grows from the relationships we create between each other and the world, and still it is never complete."

This brief memoir is interposed between a foreword by Abraham Verghese, the brilliant author of ‚ÄúCutting for Stone‚Äù and an epilogue by author‚Äôs wife, Lucy Kalanithi. It is a beautiful, heartrending, deeply philosophical piece by an accomplished young man who dedicated heart and mind to his work and study in neurosurgery. He discovers that he has terminal lung cancer at the age of 36, just before completing his grueling neurosurgical residency and embarking on the career he has worked so hard to

This is a brilliant book as the author grapples with the knowledge and consequences of a terminal cancer prognosis like most anyone would. How Kalanithi is different is that he pulls together and synthesizes CP Snow's Two Cultures, as his life is equally immersed in the humanities with philosophy and literature, on one hand, as it is in the science and technology fields, on the other. There are no ideologies left behind from his analysis of his and our mortality and struggles to understand our a

At the age of thirty-six, neurosurgeon Paul Kalanithi was diagnosed with stage IV lung cancer. What happens when the doctor becomes the patient?

Unfortunately, this one was simply not for me. I sympathised with Kalanithi, but at no point did I feel any real connection with him, which I think is crucial in order to fully appreciate this kind of memoir. I found his writing style to be quite dry and clinical, and I would zone out at times

While reading the book, I had to put it down many times to think. It took dying for Paul to write. It'd take me a lifetime to learn from it.

We all know that we'd one day die, but we're always surprised when that day comes. Paul, as his wife wrote in the epilogue, not only described the terrain but also traversed it bravely. In the process, he taught us to find the meaning of our own lives, to be the best possible versions of ourselves, and to face our own demise. Death is not an enemy that we ne

This was always going to be an emotional read. Paul Kalanithi was a young man of 36, just a few months shy of completing ten years of training as a neurosurgeon when he was diagnosed with stage IV metastatic lung cancer. He had a great academic career ahead of him as a neuroscientist and neurosurgeon but suddenly that is all taken away from him. In his memoir he reflects back on his life, his search for meaning, his studies in English and philosophy before deciding he wanted to become a doctor.

I've found books in the same genre of young folks facing their sudden mortality a little full of platitudes and false bravado so I was on the fence about picking up When Breath Becomes Air. But I read an excellent review from a reviewer I greatly respect on Goodreads so I bought it. This is a profound read, deeper than any other book in the genre, and searingly honest. Paul was extremely vulnerable with his own insecurities and doubts in the face of mortality despite being a lifelong philosopher
5 stars plus
